PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Harry Jenkins) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown), raised, as a matter of privilege, certain actions and attitudes in connection with the charging of fees under the Freedom of Information Act in respect of requests from members. I have given the matter careful consideration.

INTERJECT.PARA: Members will realise that, as members, they enjoy certain privileges and immunities; that is, some laws confer special rights or exempt them from certain obligations. The fact is, however, that these provisions are part of the law of the land. But, as I understand it, members do not enjoy any general or overriding exemption in respect of charges under the Freedom of Information Act. I understand rather that certain guidelines have been issues under the Act which outline circumstances in which charges in connection with requests from members may be remitted. Bearing in mind the fact that the Freedom of Information Act is an Act of the Parliament, and that guidelines have been issued to deal with this aspect of the operation of the Act, I can see no privilege or immunity which is being breached.
A second aspect, however, arises from the well known definition of contempt. I refer to page 143 of volume 20 of May's Parliamentary Practice:

Any act or omission which obstructs or impedes either House of Parliament in the performance of its functions, or which obstructs or impedes any Member or officer of such House in the discharge of his duty, or which has a tendency, directly or indirectly, to produce such results may be treated as a contempt even though there is no precedent of the offence.
Later, at page 158, it is stated:

Conduct not amounting to a direct attempt to influence a Member in the discharge of his duties, but having a tendency to impair his independence in the future performance of his duty, will also be treated as a breach of privilege.

Whilst I understand that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and perhaps other honourable members may feel that the failure to provide comprehensive exemptions from charges under this legislation may serve to impede them, I do not consider that the circumstances outlined by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition indicate any obstruction or impediment such as would be held to constitute a contempt, bearing in mind that the Parliament has passed a law on the matter, albeit in the broad, and has not made any special comprehensive exemptions in respect of members.

I remind the House of the general reluctance to extend the ambit of privilege and contempt and the reluctance to resile from the principle that the House should exercise its penal jurisdiction as sparingly as possible and only when satisfied that to do so is essential in order to provide reasonable protection for the House, its members and others from substantial interference with their functions.

I acknowledge the importance of this matter that has been raised and the good faith of the Deputy Leader in raising it, but my conclusion is that, on the information available, no prima facie case has been established. It would seem rather a matter of public policy which the honourable member may wish to pursue in other ways.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1985[COGNATE BILLS:INCOME TAX (INDIVIDUALS) BILL 1985INCOME TAX (COMPANIES, CORPORATE UNIT TRUSTS AND SUPERANNUATION FUNDS) BILL 1985MEDICARE LEVY BILL 1985]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 October, on motion by Mr Hurford:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the House that it was agreed that a general debate would be held on this Bill, the Income Tax (Individuals) Bill, the Income Tax (Companies, Corporate Unit Trusts and Superannuation Funds) Bill and the Medicare Levy Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reviewing the purpose of the Bills before the House, I mention that by and large, as we realise and as my colleague the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) indicated yesterday when speaking on this matter, there have been problems over a very lengthy period regarding people's compliance with the taxation laws of the land, in terms of both principles and fact. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985 contains a number of measures. Some of these are aimed at closing loopholes that result in unfairness in the tax payments system, a number of which enable deductions for specified purposes. I will mention a number of these as we go along. One loophole which had been enabling people to opt out of the system or at least minimise their tax responsibilties concerns non-leverage finance leases and similar arrangements. That measure which now stops the use of non-leverage finance leases and similar arrangements will, on the one hand, assist the Government in reducing the deficit-I am sure that all members of the House will approve of that goal-and, on the other hand, help the Government to redirect the responsibility for tax payments to where it ought to lie.

SPEECH.PARA: One cannot help mentioning a number of very positive innovations in the Bill. The Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) has always been very concerned to ensure that local government be given its due place in the Australian governmental scheme of things. I think this measure is a credit to him and his diligence. The Government has over time indicated its concern to improve the place of local government. In fact, as honourable members are aware, at the recent somewhat lack-lustre Australian Constitutional Convention the Government, with the support of local government organisations throughout Australia, was concerned to ensure that some agreement was reached to include local government within the Constitution, in other words, to give it a formal status. It is unfortunate that, while there was such a great amount of support for this measure, the Liberal and National parties could not see fit to give it their support. Perhaps they do not quite understand the significance of the role of local government in Australia.

Local government is poised to assume a more enhanced role, especially within the provision of community services. The Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services certainly believes that this is extremely desirable. He believes that local government provides a protection for citizens against the tendency towards undue centralisation of decision-making. So the provision in this Bill that amends the income tax law to allow candidates for local government elections and those for the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly to deduct $1,000 for expenses incurred in election campaigns will be welcomed. This will have the result of enabling a number of people who could not otherwise present themselves for office to do so.

I am sure many people will approve of this measure on those grounds alone. In other words, not only are we concerned to give local government this significant placement in the Constitution but also we wish to make it easier for as many citizens as possible to present themselves for public office. One of the ways of doing that, of course, is to ensure that they do not incur large expenses for their election campaigns. So by this small measure the Government has enhanced local government and reinforced the democratic process of government in this country.

The Government also has taken measures necessary to protect the superannuation funds of employees by introducing statutory rules to ensure that not more than 10 per cent of the assets, measured at cost, of an employer-sponsored superannuation fund should consist of equities in or loans to the employer or associated persons or entities. We recognise the sad history of this. A great deal of concern has been expressed, sometimes without much action, unfortunately, as happened with the previous Government. Once again it is up to the Australian Labor Party to take these reformist measures on board.

TALK.START.PARA: —It always is.

—It always is, as my colleague the honourable member for Charlton says. The Government has included special provisions to protect the viability of businesses where the system has been used otherwise. There will be something of a phasing-in process. This is a long overdue measure and one which is desired by the community.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard from a number of sources, including members of the Opposition, that capital gains taxes on investments should be seen as a form of superannuation for the investor. This is a good catch-cry, and one we hear a lot of in the community. Of course, it is simply a smoke-screen. Such a measure, if it were construed in this way, would perpetuate the unfair accrual of benefit at the expense of legitimate taxpayers. That should be self-evident, but for some it is either not self-evident or they want to make certain that people do not see it that way.

It is not reasonable to confuse the two issues. A capital gain is what it means. Superannuation is what it means. It is possible, and has been possible for many years, for self-employed people to take up their own personal superannuation package. Many people have done this, rather than riding on the backs of other taxpayers, as some have been doing with capital gains. To date it has been possible for people to do that and also to take out a superannuation scheme. In other words, it is a form of double-dipping.

This Bill increases the allowable deduction for personal superannuation schemes from $1,200 to $1,500. The Government recognises that this needs to be done and will encourage it. The Government has estimated that this measure will result in a cost to revenue of $14m in 1986-87 and $10m in 1987-88. Those who claim that a tax on capital gain is a penalty fail to look at the possibility of contributing to their own superannuation fund to provide security similar to that of people in other funds. When the Government introduced a tax on lump sum superannuation it intended that the cash limits to be taxed at the minimum rate of 15 per cent would be increased. In this Bill the Government has honoured that intention by increasing the sum to be taxed at 15 per cent from $50,000 to $55,000. One thing that must be said about this Government is that it does honour its undertakings.

The Opposition has made considerable criticism of the Government's measure to exempt from income tax the income derived by racing clubs, particularly horse and greyhound clubs. This is aimed at removing an anomaly and is not particularly contentious. I am sure that clubs such as greyhound clubs, which largely are conducted by people of very average means, will be particularly appreciative.

Opposition members probably have very little feeling for those people who patronise greyhound meetings. For many years it has been the sport of those who just could not afford to own a racehorse. At least they could own a dog and they take a great deal of interest in dogs. In other words, it is the battler's sport. What is often not recognised is that racing in all its forms, whether it be the gallops, harness racing or greyhound racing, represents an industry that generates many thousands of jobs in our community. The Government should be congratulated on assisting the industry in this way.

I wish to make a few comments about Medicare. It was astonishing to listen to the honourable member for Page (Mr Ian Robinson) yesterday when he criticised the Government for continuing to assist those Australians who, for whatever reason, are required to live on social security benefits. That was absolutely astonishing. Obviously he has no real understanding of the conditions and circumstances that lead people to seek social security benefits. He spoke of the need for these people to use their ingenuity and not to rely upon government social security payments.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is unreal.

—As my colleague the honourable member for Lilley said, that is quite unreal. I challenge the honourable member for Page to speak in that way to those people who have to survive on social security benefits in his electorate. He speaks for the inhabitants of fantasyland-those who occupy the Opposition benches in the Parliament. Perhaps he will ask the poor not to seek assistance from the Government but rather to eat cake instead. That has been said by similar sorts of people with similar mentalities in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee)-a very good member, I might say-indicated that the Government is increasing the maximum rebates of tax and the taxable income levels at which the rebates for social security recipients are to be shaded out. They are to be increased from 1 July 1985. The Government has introduced this measure to ensure that people who depend mainly or wholly on social security benefits will not have to pay tax. Without this measure, there is the likelihood that through fiscal drag these people would be drawn into a taxable bracket. That is something that the Government is concerned to ensure does not happen. This means that married beneficiaries will have the maximum rebate increased from $75 to $220 and no tax will be payable in 1985-86 on taxable incomes to $8,795. All other recipients will receive a maximum rebate of $170. That has been increased from $50. No tax will be payable on taxable incomes up to $5,275.

I was surprised by the intensity of the Opposition's attack on the Medicare Levy Bill 1985. Honourable members opposite formed the Government that changed the original Medibank program five times in order to destroy it. For many decades the Labor Party was accused of being the hard line ideologues of this society.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is absurd.
—As the Minister indicates, it is absurd.
—It is one of the most flexible parties we have ever seen.

—Absolutely. The hard line ideologues appear to be those honourable members on the other side. It is an ideology of prejudice and privilege. They had the strange belief that there was something noble about a private health system that did not apply to the public provision of health care. The fact that at least two million people were not covered for health care during the years of the Liberal-National Party governments of the 1970s and early 1980s had no real significance to the dinosaurs who sit opposite. They thought that somehow or other those two million people were privileged to be able to live with a hospital and medical system that they could not afford. I wonder where some of these honourable members spend their hours. It cannot be in their electoral offices because they would have encountered the suffering of these people there.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members are particularly proud of their attempts to return this system to the standards of the 1960s, but the Australian people will not cop that, and nor should they. I take great pleasure in taking part in this debate today because, once again, it makes me particularly proud to be part of this Government, which is a government of action, a government that is concerned to ensure that all Australians receive a fair go. I commend the Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALKER.NAME: Mr COHEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable members for their contributions to the debate on these Bills, which cover various aspects of the taxation law. I am pleased that the measures, as wide ranging as they are, have the general support of Opposition members. Two issues raised during the course of debate warrant comment. First, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) raised what he called an anomaly in the imposition of Medicare levy because of the different amounts of levy payable by families that receive the same total combined taxable incomes in a year. However, it must be remembered that Medicare levy, like personal income tax, is imposed on the taxable income of an individual, not that of a family unit.

SPEECH.PARA: The law also allows exemption from payment of the Medicare levy for those on low incomes. This exemption is initially determined by having regard to the individual's income for the year. Where the person also has responsibility for maintaining dependants-this includes married couples and sole parents-a higher exemption threshold is available having regard to the family income. This threshold increases if there are dependent children or students in the family. If the level of a person's taxable income or the combined incomes of his or her family exceed the levels at which the relieving provisions operate, the Medicare levy payable is determined on the person's own level of taxable income. Medicare levy is imposed on taxable incomes and, while ever we have an individual unit tax system, it will be extremely difficult to move to raising the levy on a family unit basis.

As to the second matter, some concern was expressed that the superannuation loan-back rules might affect employees' ability to share in the success of the employer's business. In that regard, I note that the purpose of the rules is to protect employees who, in the event that an employer's business fails, stand to lose both their jobs and their superannuation benefits where there is excessive investment by their superannuation fund in the employer's business. While there may be some limitation on the extent to which an employer's success can reflect in the superannuation fund's earnings for the benefit of employees, the rules will also limit the extent to which an employer's lack of success-or failure-is reflected in the fund's earnings and thus in employee benefits. I note also that, in many cases, there are other avenues through which employees can share in an employer's success. I refer to schemes under which employees can directly-as against indirectly through superannuation funds-acquire shares in employer companies.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALKER.NAME: Mr COHEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 27, page 29, line 19, omit `of the present values'.
(2) Clause 27, page 29, line 27, insert `of the payment portions' after `values'.

These amendments are of a technical nature. Clause 27 of the Bill as introduced will insert provisions into the income tax law to treat certain non-leveraged finance leases and similar arrangements as if they were loan arrangements. Under those provisions, only the interest component of a lease payment will be assessable for income tax purposes to the owner of the property. That component will be calculated by reference to the single effective interest rate underlying the transaction. The amendments will correct a technical deficiency in the formula to be used to calculate the interest component and will ensure that the formula operates as intended. I commend the amendments to the Committee.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report-by leave-adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: REFORM OF THE AUSTRALIAN TAXATION SYSTEM

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 October, on the following paper presented by Mr Young:
Reform of the Australian Taxation System-Statement by the Treasurer dated September 1985, together with attachments.
and on motion by Mr Cohen:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has given the Parliament the opportunity to consider in total the package of taxation proposals which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in this chamber announced on 19 September. Of course, honourable members will have the opportunity to canvass the essential elements of that package and give consideration to those aspects of it which are of interest or concern to them. Presumably, giving the Parliament this general opportunity to examine the package should at the same time reduce the need for honourable members to consider, perhaps in greater detail, the essential features of particular legislative proposals which are introduced into this Parliament in order to give effect to the decisions which the Government has made and which the Treasurer expressed on behalf of the Government when he presented that total taxation package last month. I hope that will be the case and I hope the Opposition accepts it in that spirit. The changes are substantial, and quite clearly they will require a substantial volume of legislated material coming before the Parliament. That is particularly significant because the claim has been made, quite correctly and legitimately, by the Treasurer that these changes, which are included in that total taxation package, represent the most substantial taxation changes which have been brought before this Parliament and the nation in living memory.

SPEECH.PARA: I had the opportunity to act as an observer in this chamber when the Taxation Summit was being conducted. Like a number of other members, I had the opportunity to see people who were representative of the broad expanse of thinking, of interest groups, organisations, authorities, structures and governments in Australia giving collective consideration to the important issues that were of concern in connection with the taxation system. That summit confirmed the concern and the belief that was widely held by many, including leading figures within the Government, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer, that it would be extremely difficult to obtain unanimity and a common position from all sections of the Australian people in relation to taxation reform. Of course, the summit indicated that that concern, that belief, was well placed. Despite that belief, that understanding, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer quite correctly pursued that path. They gave the opportunity for all those people, all those representatives of various groups within the Australian community, to come together in this chamber and give consideration to the matters which were of concern.

Arising from that, as we indicated before the summit was held, the final responsibility for putting together a package of changes to the taxation system rested where it should rightfully rest, and that was with the Government. The package which was finally announced by the Treasurer was the Government's response not only to its understanding of the inequities, inefficiencies and injustices of the present taxation system but also to its belief about the direction in which the taxation reform should proceed in Australia for the benefit of all Australians. It has been extremely well received in general. I will refer to just two editorials. One is from a major metropolitan daily, the Sydney Morning Herald, which on the following morning stated:

As with all taxation reform, the losers from yesterday's tax measures will scream and the winners will remain silent. And yet the Government's package deserves broad community support. Nothwithstanding a number of unfortunate concessions to particular interest groups, it will substantially reduce tax avoidance and evasion while reducing the extraordinarily high marginal tax rates on middle and high incomes.

TALK.START.PARA: —An excellent editorial.

—It was an excellent editorial. In fact, I am often impressed by the quality of the editorials that come from the Sydney Morning Herald. I now turn to a major provincial daily. I know that the honourable member for Robertson, the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen), who is at the table, is also very familiar with this major Australian provincial newspaper, the Newcastle Herald.
—A great newspaper.
—It is a great newspaper. The editorial of the Newcastle Herald the following day stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The tax reform legislation presented to Parliament yesterday was far milder than the package that the Treasurer, Mr Keating, failed to have adopted at the July taxation summit. Compared with Mr Keating's favoured Option C, with its 12 1/2 per cent no-exclusions turnover tax on goods and services, the latest measures are almost bland.
The editorial goes on to say quite tellingly:
Yet they live up to Mr Keating's assertion that they will bring in the most fundamental changes to the Australian taxation system in memory.

They have done precisely that. This Government can take a great deal of pride in the initiative which it has shown in connection with taxation reform. One of the unfortunate realities of life is that for only a comparatively small proportion of the time that this nation has existed as a nation a democratic socialist government-an Australian Labor Party Government-has occupied benches on this side of the Parliament. That decision has been made by the Australian electorate according to its judgment and I have no argument with that except that I believe that on many occasions that judgment has been deficient. Had it been possible for an Australian Labor Party Government to be in place in this Parliament for a greater proportion of that time all of the abuses and misuses of this taxation system would not exist as they do now. All of the inequities and injustices would have been significantly minimised. Unfortunately, we have not had many opportunities during the time that has been available to us to do the sorts of things that a national government should do.

During at least two major election campaigns when the Australian Labor Party, like its opponent, appealed for a mandate from the Australian people, it presented a policy which was adopted, accepted and endorsed. That provided us with a mandate to pursue the types of reforms within the Australian taxation system and wider in the Australian economy which would ensure that justice would be reintroduced, that inequities and abuses would be removed and that the misuse and contrivance of our economic system by conservative forces in Australian politics would not rule forever. We have done that and we will continue to do it. While we have the support of the Australian people to continue to make the magnificent achievements which we have made, we will continue to have the opportunity to work on their behalf and represent them as adequately and, in some cases, as magnificently as we have done.

Our approach to the whole question of taxation reform has been, in the first place, to increase the penalties for those people, those authorities, those institutions, those businesses and those company boards that want to rort the system and take advantage of it in any way they can in order to reduce and minimise their own taxation responsibilities and in the process transfer the burden of paying greater taxation on to those people who cannot escape their taxation responsibilities. Of course, I refer specifically and emphatically to the ordinary wage and salary earners in Australia who are locked into the pay as you earn tax system.

The first thing we did was to increase the penalties. That has been done. Increased penalties are now in place. Secondly, we asserted and legislated to ensure wherever we were able that where people are still sufficiently foolish or courageous to attempt to rort the system and take advantage of it, if they enter into artificial, contrived or blatant schemes and arrangements to reduce their taxation liability we will, whenever we have the opportunity-we need the support of the Senate-introduce retrospective legislation to ensure that those people will be brought to book from the time those artificial, contrived and blatant schemes are identified and we will go back to the time those schemes started to operate to pick up the tax that should have been paid, and would have been paid, had they not been able to get around the law through artificial schemes.

We have not been able to get the support of the Senate in all of these matters. I have given examples of this before in connection with the bottom of the harbour legislation. We should have been picking up, on behalf of the Australian community, the national government and taxpayers of Australia, $570m. That sum was lost to the Treasury as a result of schemes which put companies on the bottom of the harbour and avoided taxation responsibilties. Everyone in this Parliament knows how much of that $570m we have picked up. We picked up not one cent. The people who can claim the credit for that are the conservatives on the Opposition benches who, when in government, were dragged screaming into this chamber to legislate against the tax avoiders and evaders. Those opposite here and in the Senate can claim the credit for that and have it rest on their consciences-if they can rest.

In addition to the two approaches that we have taken, we have also knocked out some of the other artificial, contrived and blatant schemes. As a result of this Government's determination and legislative initiative we saw a shift in the emphasis within the tax avoidance and evasion industry to other areas where it was possible for those involved to avoid their responsibilities. In particular, they moved into tax shelters. I do not want to discredit all those people who quite legitimately have invested money in primary industries, which are among the great industries of Australia. They have been and are tremendously important.

We all know that Australians today are drowning in a flood of avocados and macadamia nuts. They are practically surrounded by pine plantations. One of the essential reasons for this is the tax shelters that have been provided for primary production. Members of the Opposition know this as well as we do. If those tax benefits and concessions achieved the objectives set we would have no argument. They would have resulted in the development, expansion and encouragement of our primary producers. But they have been used as a means to avoid taxation responsibilities. I refer to tax shelters, not only in connection with primary production, but also in the film area. There are many other examples.

We also know the way that fringe benefits have been abused. Of course, some fringe benefits are quite legitimate. We do not argue with that. We are not legislating against legitimate fringe benefits, only against those that have been abused and misused. For example, a fairly highly paid executive in Australia on a nominal salary of $60,000 has a real salary of about $100,000. Let us not lose sight of this. The other $40,000 consists of all types of fringe benefits-the school fees paid by the employer, the low interest personal and home loans, the free car, the overseas trips, the business club fees and gratuitous share issues. We can go on and on. All those benefits are untaxed. At that level of income, a person should pay 60 per cent in tax, on present marginal rates. That person is not paying tax at all.

It is quite obvious that the Government had to confront these matters head on. They have gone on for too long. As the Treasurer said, all the ramps and rorts in the taxation system, the abuses, injustices and inequities that the overwhelming number of Australian people have tolerated ever since Federation, exist because of the short time that we have been in government. We are pursuing the opportunity that we have now been given to remove these rorts; and remove them we will.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are invited to respond to the statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of 19 September which was labelled `Reform of the Australian Taxation System'. We do not accept the description of reform that is applied to this package. It is a package of changes squeezed out at the fag end of a debilitating struggle between the Treasurer and a coalition of the Australian Labor Party's left wing and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. What began as a respectable direction of change which, although containing features objectionable to the Opposition, could honestly be labelled as a reform package-I refer to option C as described in the draft White Paper-has been reduced to a miserable assembly of changes possessing neither coherence nor economic rationality.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer's grab-bag of 19 September contains remnants of some of the worthwhile ingredients of his preferred option C but it has a heavy overlay of measures imposed by the ACTU Labor left alliance and further encumbered by the crude demands of the Australian Taxation Office, intent on simplifying its revenue gathering task regardless of the practical consequences for businesses and individuals. On behalf of the Opposition I move the following amendment to the motion that the House take note of the paper:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`this House,

whilst welcoming the promised relief of double taxation of dividends and the promised reductions in marginal taxation rates, believes that the tax package presented by the Treasurer falls well short of the fundamental and lasting reform of our taxation system so frequently promised by the Government, and more specifically-
(1) condemns the proposed introduction of the new capitals gains tax;
(2) notes that under the Government's proposals the share of revenue carried by personal income tax will continue to rise;
(3) condemns the arbitrary nature of the attack on fringe benefits and entertainment expenses;

(4) expresses grave concern over the effects on enterprise, investment and employment due to the additional cost burdens on business arising from the capital gains tax, the higher rate of company tax, the fringe benefits tax and the loss of deductions for legitimate entertaining expenses;
(5) regrets the package will have an adverse and discriminatory impact upon rural Australia;
(6) notes the particular discriminatory nature of the attack on the deductibility of farm losses against non-farm income, and
(7) condemns the proposed foreign tax credit system as likely to discourage investment by Australian companies in our region.'

The Opposition has taken a responsible position throughout the whole tax saga. We have made it clear, both before and after the election, during the uncertain progress of the Treasurer's tax cart down the bumpy road of ACTU and ALP politics, during the Taxation Summit and over this past couple of weeks, that we would support sensible reform measures. Let me remind honourable members of what we said before the last election. It is something of which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) would not want to remind honourable members opposite because in his policy speech for the 1983 election campaign he said:
And here let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it, and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentation and distortion-there will be no new capital gains tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—The Prime Minister in his policy speech before the 1983 election. So much for that promise, and hence our reservations about many of the forward commitments made in the Treasurer's statement. Our 1984 election tax policy contained these essential elements: A commitment to cutting the cost of government, a shift away from income tax towards indirect taxes, a lowering of the high marginal rates of income tax, income splitting for families, tax rebates for child care expenses and a move towards the more equitable taxation of dividends as recommended by the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. In addition to these reform measures, we also committed ourselves to opposing any new capital gains tax and to repealing such a tax should Labor introduce it. Despite many pressures from various interest groups and the temptation to act opportunistically we have stood by these principles. Where the Treasurer has put forward proposals in line with these principles we have supported him. Where he has deviated, we have opposed him.

SPEECH.PARA: So what of the Treasurer's package of 19 September? Measured against the Treasurer's own criteria for tax reform, let alone against ours, it represents a major failure on the part of the Government and a big victory for the ACTU, the left wing of the Labor Party and the bureaucracy. Essentially it is an anti-entrepreneurial package. Failure to attack the problem of government spending over three Budgets and failure to move towards indirect taxes have meant that the Government has had to rely on mugging the business community to achieve any reduction in marginal tax rates. Where there has been a choice between inconvenience for bureaucrats and hardship for the entrepreneur, the Government has chosen hardship for the entrepreneur.

The Taxation Office has found it difficult to distinguish between Mick Young-type lunches and genuine entertainment expenses; so to relieve the Taxation Office of this wearisome task the Government has wiped out all entertainment deductions, even for a few miserable savouries and drinks at a new product launch. That is very convenient for the Taxation Office but expensive for those who are trying to create the nation's wealth.

Indeed, the confusion, the uncertainty and the downright unfairness of this proposal become more evident day by day. While small entrepreneurs serving lunches in restaurants are already beginning to close down, in-house lunches continue and lunches served at anything described as a seminar appear to be untouched. Yet the Treasurer continues to pour scorn on the plight of the restaurateur, the innocent victim of this bungled proposal.

The Taxation Office has also found it difficult to determine what are legitimate fringe benefit deductions in the hands of employees. Again to relieve the Taxation Office of this wearisome task, the Government has decided to hand the job and the resulting approbrium over to the employers. That is very convenient for the Government and the Taxation Office, but it will have the effect, particularly as a result of trade union pressure, of adding significantly to payroll costs. It is a de facto payroll tax. It could double the extra cost to employers already to be imposed by the Government's so-called productivity deal with the ACTU under the accord. Also, the new substantiation requirements for deductible expenses will generate an avalanche of new paperwork, further adding to costs.

Let me talk about the capital gains tax. The killing thing about the capital gains tax is its effect on entrepreneurial activity. It is those very capital gains that exceed the inflation rate because of the application of business acumen, creative talent and hard work-the very things we want to encourage to generate growth-that will be most hit by this tax and, of course, it will be levied at the top marginal rate. We need entrepreneurs in this country, we need economic growth, we need outstanding performance and we need the risk-takers. Therefore, we do not need a capital gains tax. We will oppose it, we will vote against it and we will repeal it.

In line with our commitment to support elements of the package that we believe are sensible, we support the reduction in marginal tax rates. Setting the top marginal personal tax rate for individuals at the same level as the company tax rate will discourage tax avoidance. However, we also note the timescale over which these commitments are made and express some doubt as to whether changes in economic conditions over that period will enable those commitments to be met. After all, the top marginal rate is not to be reduced from its current level of 60 per cent to the then company rate of 49 per cent until 1 July 1987.

Remembering the alacrity of the Prime Minister in abandoning solemn commitments only a week after the election in 1983 and remembering also the fragility of his promise not to introduce a capital gains tax, we have good grounds for being sceptical about this latest commitment. If honourable members think that a commitment from the Treasurer is more valuable than a commitment from the Prime Minister, let me remind them of the tax reform cart, of the Treasurer's passionate commitment to option C and the wheels that fell off the cart. July 1987 is a very long distance away. How steadfast will the commitment of this Government to taxpayers in the top bracket be in an election year?

The other concern we have about the revised tax scales laid down so far in advance relates to the effect of bracket creep on the promised tax cuts for those on more modest incomes. Because of bracket creep-that is, the movement of taxpayers into higher tax brackets because of wage increases-1.6 million taxpayers will have moved out of the 29 per cent marginal tax bracket and into the 40 per cent bracket either by the time the new rates commence in July 1987 or by shortly thereafter. This exposes the fallacy of claiming tax reform without the advantage of a broadly based indirect tax to provide genuine and lasting reductions in personal income tax.

Another aspect of the package of which we express qualified approval is the imputation system for dividends. When we were in government we began a move to reduce the double taxation of dividends, but this was snuffed out by the Hawke Government when it took office. We want to examine in greater detail the wide-reaching effects of this measure. In particular, we want to examine more closely the effects on companies and their shareholders in those many instances where the company is now paying less than the full company tax rate because of genuine deductions. We will also want to look at the effects on the capital markets both for private financing and for the operations of government. The detail of the legislation will be of great significance. We will need to examine it closely before determining our final attitude.

I will not deal with the sales tax changes now, as we will be debating the Bills next week. Also, there are other aspects of the package that I just do not have time to deal with this morning. However, let me refer to an aspect of the package that is causing grave concern to rural industry; that is, the quarantining of farm losses. This proposal, which limits the amount of income earned off the farm which can be offset against farm losses, when added to the other aspects of the package such as the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax, is highly discriminatory in its effect on rural industries. Once again, the Government is bashing the farmer. A number of my Liberal and National Party colleagues will be taking this issue up in depth in this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —No genuine farmer is affected, and you know it.

—If the honourable member wishes to listen to a number of speakers on this side of the House in this debate, he will understand in detail the practical effects on rural industries of this package of measures.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the proposal to introduce identity cards, to be called, in true Orwellian fashion, the Australia Card. It seems to be implied that it would be unpatriotic to be opposed to it. The Opposition has said that it will judge the final proposal as it emerges under three criteria: First, effectiveness in combating tax evasion and social security fraud; secondly, infringement of privacy; and, thirdly, cost benefit. On the last criterion alone, we note that almost $300m will have been spent before there is any return. Indeed, the whole system, on the Treasurer's figures, will give its first positive net return of a miserable $19m in the year 1989-90. What a fine introduction that will be to our third century of nationhood! We remain profoundly sceptical of this scheme and will be very interested to see the detail of it. The photograph having been removed, when will the signature perhaps also be removed?

Finally, I turn to the proposed foreign tax credit scheme. Such a proposal was floated when we were in government, but we dropped it when we saw what great damage it would do to Australia's investments in nearby countries. We had hundreds of concerns put to us when we floated this proposition before, and we accepted the weight of those concerns. We are opposed to this measure because it will do grave damage to our business activities in the surrounding region. In summary, we regard the tax package not only as representing a failure to tackle the difficult problems of cutting government spending and moving towards greater reliance on indirect tax but also as anti-growth. It adds to the cost of doing business when we are already internationally uncompetitive and it inhibits entrepreneurial activity on which growth and employment depend. We do not know what the final shape of these packages will be in legislation. We will examine each one carefully as it comes. We will oppose the capital gains tax and we will treat the other measures on their merits as we see their final shape. We expect many changes in their shape as they go through public discussion and amendment by Caucus.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I formally second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard the biggest collection of humbug and hypocrisy to have been proposed in a debate and discussion of a serious economic issue. If this is the sort of quality that we are to get from the shadow Treasurer, heaven help this country. Not only will the people opposite never get into government, but democracy will be undermined by the fact that we do not even have an opposition that knows what it is talking about.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say something about what happened in this House three weeks ago. Three weeks ago, before the tax package was even released, a motion condemning the Government was moved by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard).

Of course when the package was brought down we saw the very glum faces of honourable members opposite. Why were they so glum? They were glum because the predictions we made about the taxation package were correct. The package is an historically significant and comprehensive package, as I said on the day prior to its announcement. Indeed, it is a package which will have an enormous impact on the shape of the economy of this country for many years to come. I mentioned the word `humbug'-a word I do not often use in this place. One sees that that word can be applied to the amendment moved by the Opposition. The Opposition's amendment in part states:

expresses grave concern over the effects on enterprise, investment and employment due to the additional cost burdens on business arising from the capital gains tax, the higher rate of company tax, the fringe benefits tax and the loss of deductions for legitimate entertaining expenses;

There is no mention at all of the enormous major concession to private enterprise which this taxation package gives. There is no mention of the historic concession for the imputation of dividends-the most significant structural change to this economy that has taken place for many years. There was no mention of that by the Opposition. The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), mentioned it in a byline when he said that the Opposition agreed with some aspects of it, and he left it at that. He made no mention of the fact that for many years the Opposition when in government failed to implement such a policy. As a consequence, the Australian economy was distorted away from productive enterprise, and into what? Into speculation and property holdings.

That happened for two reasons: Firstly, failure to implement the imputation; and secondly, failure to introduce a mild and generous capital gains tax. As a result of those two failures those opposite failed to steer the Australian economy towards a growth path. We heard the shadow Treasurer in his concluding comments dare to talk about growth when in fact the previous Government's record of growth in the seven years it was in government was appalling.

TALK.START.PARA: —They devastated the economy.

—As the honourable member for Charlton says, they devastated the economy. Why is it that the Opposition totally fails to understand the significance of these tax changes and has not proposed anything that looks like a coherent alternative? If this taxation package can be described as historically significant, then the response of the Opposition so far to the challenge to put forward proposals which sound credible in relation to taxation reform can be described only as insignificant. The fact of the matter is that the Opposition cannot do that because it still does not understand how to operate a functioning capitalist economy. It believes in the fairytale theories of monetarists such as Milton Friedman. The Opposition believes in theories which when put into operation in the British nation devastated that economy and created social and economic disorder such as had never been seen before in that country. Given the growth of other economies, those theories have resulted in a massive increase in unemployment, massive social division and very substantial destruction of the industries of that country.

SPEECH.PARA: Rather than learning from what happened in Britain, honourable members opposite seek to put to the Australian people the proposition that we should follow the same path. They are proposing that we return to the pre-Menzies days of economic thinking. When Sir Robert Menzies formed the Liberal Party of Australia in 1945 he made it perfectly clear that the tories and conservatives had learned some lessons from the past. He realised that it was not possible to operate a modern economy such as ours without an incomes policy, without a policy that gets to the guts of the matter-an incomes accord, or at least an incomes approach of some kind.

What honourable members opposite fail to understand about the tax package is that it is totally consistent with the general strategy of the prices and incomes accord. That is the point. It is not simply an ad hoc set of measures put together in order to please any particular interest group. That is not what has happened. What has happened is that we have put together a set of measures that have been carefully thought out so that they are consistent with the incomes policy. We now have a taxation policy and an incomes policy working in harmony with one another. When has that ever happened in the history of Australia? When has it ever been the case that any government has produced such a coherent and comprehensive approach? What the tories on the other side totally fail to recognise is that they have to come up with some coherent alternative.

What are honourable members opposite doing? They are talking about dropping the accord. Okay, if they want to drop the accord, that is fine. But what do they want to do? Do they want to totally deregulate the labour market and create a war in the jungle situation in industrial relations in a modern economy? It has been proved by history that that sort of approach does not work. It creates social disharmony and, in fact, creates circumstances which can destroy an economy rather than build on it. When will the Opposition recognise that Sir Robert Menzies was not wrong to change the previous laissez-faire policies and get down to the nitty gritty of working out a coherent alternative which involves an incomes approach and some regulation of the economy? Are they going to recognise that? Of course not. They have gone back to the crazy days of mouthing a few slogans about deregulation and talking about a model of the economy that is totally non-existent. The honourable member for Charlton, as a former teacher of economics, could tell us that such a model has never existed in the world. Rather than living in the modern Australia, honourable members opposite try to put forward models of industrial relations and of the economy which are totally ridiculous and incoherent.

Let us look at the tax changes themselves. I mentioned the imputation issue. The fact is that imputation, far from being an attack on business interests, as was implied by the shadow Treasurer, is one of the greatest concessions ever made to business by any government. It will cost some $250m, and that amount probably will increase in future years. Yet we have the shadow Treasurer saying: `That is no good because, after all, you will be introducing a capital gains tax'. Let us look at what the capital gains tax will do. I put it to the House that this capital gains tax is the most moderate ever conceived by the mind of man. Who has ever heard of a capital gains tax that totally exempts all existing holdings? Can anyone point to another nation in the world that has a capital gains tax like that?

Furthermore, the proposals in the White Paper to provide for a deeming of realised capital gains when inheritance takes place have been dropped as well. In addition, the capital gains tax will not be imposed on nominal gains but on real gains which means that inflation will be taken into account. How much more generous than that can we get? What else could the Opposition want in the form of a capital gains tax? It is extraordinary that the Opposition should oppose this proposal. They want to abolish it. All the Opposition wants to do is to put money into property and forget about productive enterprise. Is that the Opposition's idea of economic management? That is why manufacturing in this country went down during the regime of honourable members opposite. Capital gains tax has an important role to play in balancing resources in the economy and the Opposition knows that.

Let us get away from this humbug and to the concrete reality of the matter. The concrete reality of the matter is that these proposals have been put together in order to achieve economic growth. That is what they have been put together to do. These proposals are not based on some outrageously socialist concept. They are based on the notion that if one does strengthen capital investment and capital accumulation in the way in which we are trying to do it-through the imputation system-that will be reinvested in productive enterprises to create employment.

It is unfortunate that honourable members on this side of the House have to get up here and give basic economic lessons to the Opposition but the fact of the matter is that it is trying to put to the Australian people that there is something grossly anti-business about these proposals and that they are somehow grossly unfair to the richer sector of the economy. If that is what honourable members opposite think, they should look at the opinion of Kenneth Davidson in today's Age under the heading `Tax reforms favour the rich'. I do not entirely agree with the sentiment expressed there but I certainly agree that the bulk of the benefits of these taxation changes will go to that sector in the form of personal income tax cuts. The Government gave personal income tax cuts to the other sector last year. That is the point. We intend to give more tax cuts next year to that sector. We are trying to treat the different sectors of the economy fairly.

What are honourable members opposite talking about when they get up here and say that the tax changes are contrary to entrepreneurship, to investment and to growth? The fact of the matter is that honourable members opposite do not understand how a capitalist economy operates. All they have is a myth in their minds about some laissez-faire system which has never existed in history and which certainly does not exist today. That is why all they do when they talk about the public sector, which has an important role to play in any modern mixed economy, is to attack the public sector, to try to dismantle it and to try to tear it apart. That is the idea honourable members opposite have in relation to economic management.

We have heard grumbles about restaurants and the entertainment industry. It is unfortunate that there will be some reduction in expenditure and employment in this area in the short term. However, is the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar, suggesting that because someone somewhere is being employed as a consequence of a tax rort, one should continue with the tax rort? Is that the sort of logic he is putting forward? The fact of the matter is, as everyone in this country knows and understands, especially the ordinary working people who cannot claim entertainment expenses, there has been a rorting of the system. People have been going to lunches, dinners and all kinds of functions purely or almost entirely for social purposes and they have been claiming them as legitimate expenses. The Opposition is telling us that, because of the unfortunate situation in relation to the entertainment industry in the short term, we should agree to the continuation of the tax rort.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Dr D.J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of 19 September 1985. Unlike the previous speaker, the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), I would like to introduce some serious economic analysis into this debate. Whilst I would like to address many issues, I have decided to concentrate in the time available on just three aspects of that statement. Those aspects are the capital gains tax, the imputation of company tax and the implications of these proposals for superannuation. I will address these aspects in sequence.

SPEECH.PARA: On 19 September the Treasurer announced the introduction of a capital gains tax. He introduced it with these words:

The Government has decided to introduce a capital gains tax but, in the light of the public debate, to incorporate several major modifications to the proposal outlined in the White Paper in June. These changes address the concerns which have been expressed and will substantially reduce the impact of the tax and allow the community a lengthy period in which to adjust to its application. In particular, it has been decided that the tax will be in every sense prospective.

That means it will only apply to gains on assets purchased or acquired after today. All assets already owned by taxpayers will be exempt from the tax when sold by them both in respect of gains accrued until now and all future gains.
Later, in Attachment B on page 43 of his statement, the Treasurer said:
The restriction of the tax to assets acquired after today . . . means that for most taxpayers the capital gains tax will have little or no impact.

This is absolute nonsense. The Treasurer is either an economic illiterate, which his performance certainly indicates, or someone who is prone to bending the truth to suit his own purposes. The facts are that the imposition of a capital gains tax has impacted on everyone who owns an asset which is potentially subject to this tax. The price of an asset is determined by the current demand and supply and, just as importantly, the future expectations regarding the after tax return on the asset.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that called speculation?

—No, it is called expectations. As an economist, the honourable member would know. The imposition of a capital gains tax on future purchases and the subsequent selling of these assets will drive down the after tax return and thus it must logically drive down the current value of the asset. Ask anyone whether he would pay the same price for a business purchased on 20 September as he would have been willing to pay on 18 September. The answer is no. People understand that to obtain the same after tax profit after 20 September means that they must pay less for the business.

SPEECH.PARA: If people will not pay as much for a business after 20 September, who has felt the greatest impact of this capital gains tax? Obviously it is the current owners of the assets. They are the people who have suffered the losses. The Treasurer is trying to fool the average Australian that it is only future generations that will be affected. The truth is that the present owners of capital assets-the small business people and the farmers-are the people who are already the losers. Contrary to the incorrect assertion by the Treasurer, the majority of Australians owning assets not exempted from the capital gains tax have already been impacted upon by the imposition of it.

While the points noted previously are important for the current holders of capital assets, it is perhaps the future negative implications which are even more critical to Australia's development. This tax will act to inhibit capital accumulation in Australia. This tax has been introduced at a time when net apparent capital inflow into Australia is falling. In 1984-85 the net capital inflow was some $700m less than it was in 1983-84. In July and August of this financial year there was a drop of some $500m compared with the same months in 1984.

The imposition of a capital gains tax will inhibit entrepreneurs going into high risk businesses. This will particularly apply in instances where there is a low capital money base and where the predominant asset or the predominant future asset of the venture is goodwill. Goodwill will now be taxed in its entirety at the high marginal rates. This will affect a vast range of small manufacturing businesses, professional firms and, of course, firms in some of the new high technology areas. The discouragement of entrepreneurship or risk taking in these areas is diametrically opposed to Australia's long term interests. Eventually it will lead to lower rates of growth and thus lower relative standards of living, higher unemployment and the decline of Australia's international competitive position.

I return to the second point, which seemed to concern the honourable member for Calwell-the imputation of company tax. One persistent criticism of the current tax system is that while it allows a service cost, namely, interest payments on debt capital, to be deducted for tax purposes, it does not allow the service cost of equity capital to be deducted.

The implication of this criticism has always been that dividend payments and retained earnings should be treated in the same way as interest payments. The Treasurer has partly recognised this argument as valid and has allowed the full imputation of company income distributed as dividends to resident individual shareholders. However, the Treasurer has not been totally forthcoming with respect to the taxation changes. As usual, he has understated the taxation revenue implications. Previously, company profits were taxed and then dividends were taxed in the hands of shareholders. Any profits retained by the company and reinvested attracted no personal taxation-that is, no taxation when a shareholder sold his proportion of the now higher valued company.

Under the new arrangements, company profits will be taxed. Profits distributed as dividends will be taxed in the hands of the company at the rate of $49 for every $51 distributed to shareholders. With a company this will be set against calculated company income tax by reference to company profits. But when shareholders receive the dividends, they will receive a tax credit for the tax paid by the company on the dividends. Noticeably, the same treatment will not be accorded to profits which are retained by the company. When shareholders sell the shares at a higher value because of the retained earnings which have already been taxed at the company tax rate, the shareholders will be caught by a capital gains tax at the full marginal tax rate. Instead of a double tax on dividends as in the past, we now have a double tax on retained earnings. The Treasurer's statement implicitly assumed that all profits would be distributed as dividends. This is neither likely nor in many cases prudent financial management. This is particularly the case for public companies. Under the new taxation proposals, the shareholders of those companies which retain earnings in the company will be at a taxation disadvantage.

I now turn to the subject of superannuation, which is affected by the proposed changes to company taxation and a capital gains tax. Since the current Government assumed office in March 1983, it has made substantial changes to the taxation of superannuation. First, it introduced a 30 per cent tax on superannuation benefits accumulated after 1 July 1983. It did this partly because employee contributions to superannuation policies received taxation benefits in terms of deductibility of contributions up to $1,200 per annum, partly in order to stop double dipping and partly because of the preferred taxation status of superannuation companies. Secondly, earlier this year the Government removed the tax deductibility of employee superannuation payments. These contributions are now effectively after-tax contributions for all employees. We now see the third blow. It appears from a reading of the Treasurer's statement of 19 September that company dividends are to be taxed in the hands of companies and tax credits obtained by the shareholders. However, no mention is made of how a beneficiary of a mutual fund is to obtain such credits. Are the taxes paid by the original production company to be offset against the 30 per cent lump sum tax, or in the case of annuities against income tax payable on the annual annuity received? If so, how is this to work?

At present it appears that an employee contributing to a superannuation fund will be making contributions having already paid personal tax. He will also be denied any tax credits on dividends received on his behalf by the mutual fund, which means that he will effectively be paying tax at the rate of 49c for every 51c of dividends received by the mutual fund on his behalf. Finally, when he receives his lump sum payment or when he receives any of his superannuation annuity he will pay further income tax. This is not a trivial point. Because of the size of the life assurance industry in Australia and the prevalence of superannuation schemes where employers and employees make contributions, this will affect millions of Australians and billions of dollars worth of dividends. I should perhaps say as an aside that a similar problem, although not exactly the same, arises with respect to dividends received by mutual funds in their non-superannuation fund areas. In those areas the effect will be to raise the average taxation being paid by these companies in effect from about 30c in the dollar, which roughly equates to the average tax paid by the taxpayer, and will move it closer to the 49c in the dollar which is the company rate of dividend. The world's greatest Treasurer is either purposely misleading the Australian community or is totally incompetent or totally incapable of understanding the implications of the measures that I have just outlined. This Treasurer has moved to eliminate double dipping on the part of taxpayers, but he has replaced it with double dipping by the Taxation Commissioner. For this latter action he deserves the condemnation not only of this Parliament but also of the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the limited time allowed each speaker in this debate, I do not intend to go over in detail the merits of the specific proposals in the tax reform package announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 19 September; rather, I will make a number of comments on the broad thrust of the package considered in conjunction with earlier changes to the tax system made by the present Government. I will then discuss a number of ongoing concerns and perspectives for further change.

SPEECH.PARA: As we all know, the Government's initial preferred option as set out in the tax White Paper was built around a broad based consumption tax. This was decisively rejected by a majority of the participants at the National Tax Summit held in July. The final proposal includes a rationalisation of the wholesale sales tax in such a way as to produce a small revenue gain. The centrepiece of the reform package announced on 19 September is a comprehensive attempt to repair and broaden the personal income tax base. For some time the notional progression shown in the personal income tax rate scale has been a fiction, with most of those on high incomes having access to a variety of tax minimisation avenues. There can be no doubt that the steps taken to close off these avenues are highly progressive in their incidence. I will not discuss specific measures as they have been covered ad nauseam in the debate leading up to the Tax Summit and after.

Part of the burden of this assault on tax minimisation will be borne, in the first instance at least, by the corporate sector. This has served to justify the inclusion of a major concession to the corporate sector in the form of a full imputation system of company tax, only partly offset by an increase in the company tax rate.

It will be some time before the measures achieve their full revenue potential. Nonetheless, we are to see marginal rate cuts introduced in two stages-on 1 September 1986 and 1 July 1987. The first stage is integrally linked to the Government's strategy to preserve the accord in the face of the recent dollar depreciation. These cuts will be of a considerably greater magnitude than would be provided by revenue from the income tax base broadening alone. The rest will come from returning to taxpayers the extra tax that would otherwise have been raised as a result of the effect of inflation on the income tax rate scales.

What overall assessment are we to make of this package, so tortuously arrived at? There is little doubt that under the present system funds have been diverted from productive, employment-providing investment as a result of a system that made tax minimisation concerns paramount in many cases. I would add that that point is generally conceded by anybody who adheres to a rational economic analysis, and it is astonishing to hear speakers like the honourable member for Forde (Dr Watson) continuing to bemoan a capital gains tax which in its fifth year of operation will raise revenue of the order of $25m. To remove a major structural defect in the tax system over time is entirely justified, and one could not imagine a more phased, gradual achievement of that goal than has been done in this package.

Some industries undoubtedly grew to greater proportions than would have been warranted were it not for the existence of tax rorts. The elimination of these distortions should yield significant efficiency gains to the economy in due course. As to the equity of the tax system, the base broadening measures in isolation are undoubtedly progressive in their effect. However, this picture changes somewhat when the new income tax rate structure is brought into the picture. An analysis of the distributional impact of the changes appears on the final two pages of the attachments to the Treasurer's statement. When the base broadening and rates scale changes are combined, the greatest gains, measured by increase in disposable income, will go to those with incomes around $30,000 per annum. Above this income level, the percentage gain in disposable income falls until a taxpayer at $100,000 suffers an actual loss of 1.6 per cent of disposable income. In other words, the changes are progressive in their impact from an income of $30,000 upwards. Taxpayers on lower incomes gain, but to a considerably lesser extent than taxpayers in the $30,000 per annum range.
