TALK.START.PARA: —This picture improves somewhat when account is taken of measures that will impact on companies rather than directly on individuals. The table which I have incorporated does not take account of those measures which in the first instance will raise revenue from companies. That picture varies depending on the assumptions one makes about a company's ability to shift a tax burden either forward on to consumers or backwards on to labour and the way in which share holdings are distributed in the community as between individuals and large institutions. Nonetheless, if we take the impact on the corporate sector into account, the impact on progression starts to look a bit better than what is shown in the table.

SPEECH.PARA: It is appropriate to consider these changes in conjunction with other rate scale adjustments since the change of government. In particular, the cutting of the bottom marginal rate from 30 per cent to 25 per cent in last year's Budget considerably enhanced the progression of the tax system. So the argument is that one has to consider the Government's changes to the tax and social security systems as a totality rather than focusing on the current package of tax changes in isolation. I have requested the Parliamentary Library to attempt an analysis that will take into account the effect on the progression of the tax system of all the changes since the present Government took office. Such an analysis might tell us some interesting things.

An overall assessment should also look at the distributive impact of increases in various types of social security outlays over and above indexation since the change of government, including the anti-poverty trap measures announced in conjunction with the tax reform package. While I would have liked to see more done in this area-and I think if one takes a somewhat longer view over the past decade one can see that there has been a significant deterioration in real value of some of those payments and certainly a deterioration when compared with the updated Henderson poverty line-nonetheless, there is no doubt that these measures are very well targeted to the groups most in need. The Government has undoubtedly reversed an adverse trend since it took office.

I have to say that I would have preferred to see a greater proportion of the benefits of tax reform distributed to low and middle income earners. This could have been achieved by structuring the marginal rate cuts differently and enlarging the outlays package targeted at poverty alleviation. I think there was plenty of scope to do more in those areas. A well designed anti-poverty package could have been somewhat larger than the $200m or so that is envisaged in the package as announced. As things stand, relief in the below $20,000 income range really only offsets the effect of inflation on the tax system for the next couple of years. I am referring there primarily to the increase in the threshold-from $4,595 to $5,100. The benefits accruing from tax reform itself are overwhelmingly delivered to those in the higher marginal rate brackets in a form not susceptible to rapid erosion by inflation. Slashing the top marginal rate from 60 per cent to 49 per cent is a concession that, by its very nature, is not subject to erosion by the effect of inflation whereas moving the tax-free threshold, which is the main form of assistance to low income earners, will, of course, very rapidly be wiped out by the action of inflation.

There is no doubt that more could have been done to help low to middle income earners and that this would have been consistent with substantial marginal rate relief in the middle income range and a moving out of the 60 per cent marginal rate threshold. If one looks at the numbers, one will see that there is no question that what I have just said is accurate. If one projects forward to 1987-88, one can see that the abolition of the 60 per cent marginal rate is a very substantial concession. I believe that that in itself will have a revenue cost well in excess of $1 billion when one updates and takes account of inflation, fiscal drag, growth in the labour force and so on. Rather than doing that, I am suggesting that that threshold could have been moved out so as to stop people with comparatively modest incomes from getting into it.

Notwithstanding these concerns, the tax reform package is a great step forward. Adjustment to the rate scale is politically a relatively simple matter by comparison with the measures needed to rid the income tax system of the major structural deficiencies that have made it susceptible to tax avoidance and evasion. In other words, I guess I am flagging here that I hope to see some further adjustment in the marginal rate scale that will restore a greater degree of progression.

It needs to be stressed that continuous monitoring and review of the tax system will be needed to guard against the possibility of new avoidance and evasion avenues being developed. Already the tax avoidance industry has run advertisements in major newspapers boasting of its capacity to get around the new changes. There undoubtedly remain significant avenues for avoidance and evasion. One such area, partly tackled by the foreign tax credit scheme announced in the package, that will require a highly sophisticated approach is that of overseas avoidance and evasion.

I quote from the paper delivered to the Tax Summit by Yuri Grbich, Professor of Law at the University of New South Wales and acknowledged as one of the leading experts in tax avoidance and evasion in this country, particularly the legal aspects:

Good task force auditing strategies, the development of better intelligence and, more controversially, new legislative techniques against tax havens and transfer pricing promise handsome returns for resources. This involves a long term commitment to build up the quality and depth of advice and to revise the Act. The amounts involved are-and I emphasise- very large indeed but the problems are equally daunting.

In another part of his interesting paper, Grbich argues that the existing institutions in the field-that is, the Taxation Office and the Treasury-may well be unsuited to the sort of task set out in the above quote. Grbich favours a new, more legally oriented, institution with the following characteristics. He states in his speech:

It would tend to concentrate on long term initiatives, with some emphasis on large scale management initiatives, and leave most of the day to day administration of the tax system to the Tax Office. Its expertise would go considerably beyond the economic expertise of the economists who have traditionally dominated Treasury.
I think those remarks are extremely significant and ought to be the subject of on-going consideration within the Parliament.

The nature of the marginal rate changes also warrants placing the direct taxation of wealth back on the agenda for the medium term. The treatment of this issue in the recent debate was unfortunate. The White Paper discussion was perfunctory, presumably because there was seen to be little point in wasting too much effort on an option that had been virtually ruled out by the political leadership at the outset. It was also unfortunate that the perception developed that integrated inheritance and gift duties were a more viable form of direct taxation on wealth than a net wealth tax. I believe, for reasons that I could set out in more detail given time, that this perception was misguided. However, I just make the observation that, according to opinion polls, there is a far greater acceptance of a net wealth tax than of integrated death gift duties. The reasons for that probably stem from the unfavourable experience of the dual Commonwealth-State death tax regime that formerly applied. However, for a variety of reasons I think if we are going to look at the direct taxation of wealth, a net wealth tax is the right way to go. However, time does not permit me to go into that further.

I conclude by observing that one of the main impediments to a rational consideration of such a tax is a lack of reliable data on wealth distribution in this country. Efforts are currently being made to remedy this matter. I welcome that and I hope that in the medium term we will be looking a lot more seriously at that question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate today is totally misnamed. According to the Government, this is a debate on reform of the Australian taxation system. It really should be titled a debate on the reduction, for part of the time, of marginal tax rates for individuals and the introduction of a series of new anti-business taxes. Let me address the matter of marginal tax rates. Some people believe the Government's publicity and are of the opinion that the burden on individual taxpayers through income tax has been reduced. It has been for some time, but not for any great length of time. Unfortunately, our Treasurer (Mr Keating), who has the mantle of the world's greatest Treasurer, has forgotten to index these marginal tax rates. According to his Budget Papers, we expect an increase in average weekly earnings and inflation of about 8 per cent per annum.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it hard to believe that our Treasurer does not know of something called bracket creep. My calculations indicate that within two years, with 8 per cent inflation and taking account of bracket creep, the average Australian taxpayer will not be better off under these new tax scales but worse off. If one also considers the impact of the new taxes this Treasurer has introduced, the average Australian taxpayer will be a lot worse off. When one considers not only the direct impact of these new taxes but also the indirect effect-that is, the impact on inflation, because all these taxes will increase the cost of goods and services-the average Australian taxpayer will be a lot worse off. The Australian economy will be in for a new round of inflation. That vicious cycle, which so often accompanies Labor governments, that is, high inflation, high unemployment, low rates of growth and, these days, a declining value of the Australian dollar--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!
—The Minister laughs. I refer him to the Whitlam period.
—Can I just refer you to the Fraser period? What about taking the last year of the Fraser Government? Double digit inflation, double digit unemployment.

—Let us not digress too far from the debate. The greatest example in Australia's history of how not to manage an economy was Gough Whitlam's period in office. Let me address some of the more important issues contained in this package of new taxes. Let us look at the impact of the fringe benefits tax, which is a tax on employers. As I said, it will increase the cost of goods and services. I think our Treasurer has really been snowed by the equivalent of Sir Humphrey in his Department. This is totally unnecessary legislation. I quote from the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, section 26(e), which states:

SPEECH.PARA: the value to the taxpayer of all allowances, gratuities, compensations, benefits, bonuses and premiums allowed, given or granted to him in respect of, or for or in relation directly or indirectly to, any employment of or services rendered by him, whether so allowed, given or granted in money, goods, land, meals, sustenance, the use of premises or quarters or otherwise . . .

These things are subject to tax because under section 26(e) they are defined as income. The reality is that if the Australian Taxation Office was doing its job and using the provisions that already exist in the tax Act we would not need further amendments imposing new taxes on the employer. The reality is that the Treasurer cannot stand up to his Department and say to Sir Humphrey, or whoever it is in that Department: `I want you to enforce the law as it stands'. No, he has been snowed, like Jim Hacker. He has been told to go into the Parliament and argue for more law, more bureaucracy, more public servants, more cost, so that it is easier for the tax department. He has not even realised the consequences for Australian business of forcing employers to pay taxes in this way. I find it absolutely amazing that some honourable members on the other side talk about their concern for unemployment but are busy imposing a further tax, in the nature of a tax on employment, in this so-called reform of taxation.

The reality is that employers have only a given amount of income. They have suddenly been confronted with an additional charge which they have to pay to the Government through this proposed tax on fringe benefits. What are their choices? Will they put up their prices? Of course they will do that. But their capacity to do that is limited by the shape of the demand curve for their product. What is their other option? They will start cutting costs. Where does an employer start cutting costs when he has an increased cost of employment? He starts looking at his employees. What will happen? The average employer will say: `I will have to keep my senior executive people, the management of my firm, the people who make this operation go, so I will have to wear the tax for them'. He will look at who else he employs. Perhaps he has some unskilled people, some less experienced people, some young people. He will say: `Let's cut the payroll bill there'. So more people, the people least able to compete in the labour force and get other jobs, will be put on the unemployment heap. This Government claims that it is concerned about unemployment and creating jobs. In this move the Treasurer has eliminated I do not know how many jobs, but probably thousands, because he has not thought through the reactions to this proposal.

As another example of the Treasurer's thoughtlessness we look at this total ban on entertainment expenses. Even members of his own Government recognise the importance of entertainment expenses. In the next few weeks we will be treated to the spectacle of the $22,000 lunch at Ayers Rock.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—A $22,000 lunch at Ayers Rock. I do not know why it is having a lunch of that magnitude if it does not feel that that is an integral part of the business that will take place there-that is, the giving away of Ayers Rock to a certain section of the Australian community. The reality is that entertainment expenses are a legitimate part of business transactions. On the Sunday program the Treasurer was asked whether his Department had done any calculations or studies on the likely employment consequences of banning entertainment expenses. Do you know what his answer was, Madam Deputy Speaker? He said: `No, we haven't done any studies on it'. I can tell him that this measure is already beginning to bite. Entertainment expenses are no longer deductible. Restaurants are beginning to lay off people. A thousand people were laid off in Melbourne the other day, and that will continue. The Treasurer trots out this spurious argument that the restaurant industry has been existing behind a tax shelter. Let me tell honourable members that entertainment expenses are deductible under section 51(1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act, as is every other legitimate business expense. The next thing the Treasurer will tell us is that we cannot deduct the cost of paper clips, paper, fuel for machines and such things because they are deductible under section 51(1), under a tax shelter. What a lot of arrant nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer seems committed to building a bigger and better bureaucracy. The substantiation provisions contained in the so-called reform package are absolutely horrific. They will create work. The Government will have to expand the storage provisions in the taxation offices just so they can file everybody's tax returns. What about the wholesale taxes? The Treasurer has introduced a reclassification of wholesale taxes, an extension of wholesale taxes. He made the statement on Thursday night, and in some of the regional offices of the Taxation Office on Friday morning officers who had to advise people responsible for collecting this tax on behalf of the Government were rushing out and buying newspapers, trying to work out what the obligations were. The Treasurer had not even managed to get the detailed advice through to the officers of the Taxation Office. I wonder what sort of administrative competence that is.

TALK.START.PARA: —It sounds like a cosmetic operation to me, following that advertisement yesterday.

—My friend reminds me of the cosmetic operation. The Treasurer has a reputation for being suave and urbane, but I notice that he is looking after his toiletries. They are all to be taxed at the 20 per cent rate while the tax rate on cosmetics and toiletry requirements for females is 30 per cent. I would love to be a fly on the wall in the Cabinet room when Senator Susan Ryan makes some comments about that.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter that is really important is the proposal of the Treasurer to quarantine farm losses. On the one hand he is limiting the ability of people involved in primary industry to offset losses incurred in that activity against income from other sources. On the other hand, he is busy encouraging group tax positions for the corporate sector of the economy. The reality is that this Treasurer is anti-farmer. He does not realise that a lot of agricultural pursuits, particularly in the orchard industry, require a long term investment. It is up to seven or eight years before one gets any sort of return out of many orchard investments. There is a need to seek some sort of tax relief and amelioration or that sort of investment will not go on. Earlier in this debate the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) talked about the veritable flood of macadamia nuts and avocadoes. I am amazed that the honourable member does not even recognise that avacadoes are in short supply. They are an export crop. We have tremendous potential for exporting them to Asia and America. The honourable member is obviously unaware of the parlous state of our balance of payments and the level of the Australian dollar. If he was concerned about Australia's position in the world economy he would be in favour of any proposal which encouraged the development of export industries. Agriculture, particularly the orchard section, is one of our few industries which have any potential to increase exports.

In the limited time available to me I would like to draw the House's attention to an absolute anomaly that this Government has introduced into property investment. From 17 July this Government has banned negative gearing on property investment. That means that one cannot pay more interest than the rent one receives on a property, notwithstanding that over a period it is possible to reduce the mortgage, and therefore the interest payment, and reverse the situation. As a so-called sop, the Government has introduced from 17 July a depreciation provision of 4 per cent on property the construction of which commenced after 17 July. What about the vast stock of property in Australia which was built prior to 17 July? It is not eligible for negative gearing; it is not eligible for depreciation. That means the only buyer for that sort of property is an owner-occupier. No investor seeking to rent the property would purchase it unless its value was substantially discounted. Consequently rents are likely to rise and the values of certain classes of property are likely to drop like a rock.

A colleague of the Treasurer in the Australian Labor Party, the Minister for Youth and Community Services in the New South Wales Government, is absolutely terrified of the consequences of what his colleagues in Canberra are doing to rental values in Sydney. Already there is something like a one per cent vacancy rate in the Sydney rental market and rents are rising rapidly every week. Coupled with this Treasurer's capital gains tax, his prohibition on negative gearing and the limitation of the depreciation provision to property commenced after 17 July 1985, he will put more and more pressure on rental values. We will see an increase in rents, we will see a simultaneous drop in the value of certain classes of property and, because of the structure of this capital gains tax, we will see excessive investment in housing in Australia.

The final point I would like to make concerns the proposed identity card. Opinion polls in Australia indicate that most Australians support the proposal for an ID card, but the reality is that they support the proposal for an ID card on the basis that it will do something about social security fraud. A decision has been taken not to have a photograph on the ID card, which is known as the Australia Card. There was a very conspicuous omission from the Treasurer's statement-that is, an estimate of the social security overpayment and fraud savings that would accrue from the introduction of this card. But there was a very conspicuous estimate of the extra tax that would be collected. The reality is that the Australia Card is a fraud; it is nothing more than a tax card.

I was told in discussions with officers of the Department of Social Security-I find this amazing-that the Department will not rely on the Australia Card as a source of identification for clients. The reason it will not rely on the card is that it does not have any confidence in the integrity of this proposal. I find it absolutely amazing that this Government will spend millions of dollars on introducing an ID card without a photograph, that the Department of Social Security will not rely upon it, that it will not be used by the Australian Electoral Office for compiling electoral rolls and that it will not have any direct link with the Australian Taxation Office. Yet the Government will spend an immense amount of money on it. I think it is one of the worst ideas I have ever heard.

A much simpler way of collecting tax would be to introduce a national taxation file system. Instead of the State by State system of tax files that we have at present, this Government and the Treasurer would be much better off directing the Taxation Office's attention to coming up with a national tax file number which could be used by employers and employees alike in recording payments in the nature of wages and salaries to people for casual work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has elapsed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the subject of the reform of the Australian taxation system. The Government's tax reform package is a major achievement indeed, despite the protestations of the Opposition. It is the outcome of an unprecedented process of consultation, not the least of which was the National Taxation Summit. Admittedly the tax summit was a difficult exercise for the Government to undertake because it involved consultation with so many varied groups of people. Nevertheless I believe that it was a valuable exercise and I am sure the Government believes that, too. This tax reform package is, to a large extent, the result of that consultation with the Australian people and their representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: Simply put, the Government's plan to reform the tax system in Australia is to broaden the direct tax base by cracking down on tax shelters, taxing fringe benefits and very gently-I emphasise the words `very gently'-taxing capital gains to help fund tax cuts for those taxpayers who, for so long, have suffered high marginal tax rates. These measures have brought forward some opposition from select vested interest groups. I will not name any honourable members opposite. However, the majority of the ordinary working people, who comprise the bulk of taxpayers in this country, have heralded these reforms as being fair and long overdue. I can speak from my experience of having consulted with constituents in my area. They certainly herald these changes. Very few of them have benefited from the free lunch or any of the other little perks and lurks that were available to some people under the previous tax system.

The money collected from those not previously paying the appropriate amount of tax will help fund reductions in marginal tax rates and benefit all income earners who to date have been conscientiously paying full tax on their weekly earnings. The demise of the free lunch, which I have just mentioned, and entertainment expenses as a taxable deduction may cause, and probably has caused, some concern to some people and some industries, as is obvious from recent newspaper articles. However, this measure was necessary because of the difficulty in determining what was a genuine business entertainment expense and what was not. Like many other aspects of the taxation system, it was the abuse of this deduction that necessitated its removal. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) recently pointed out, meals associated with legitimate conferences and conventions will still be deductible. But people will no longer be able to claim meals and entertainment expenses for reciprocal lunches with colleagues, friends and family and those sorts of occasions when business people choose to discuss aspects of their work over a meal in a restaurant. However, many will still follow this practice because of time constraints and the need to eat somewhere at some time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like here.

—Exactly. People will now simply reorganise their arrangements for paying the restaurant bill; that is, they will decide to pay for themselves only-they will go dutch as it is called-or reciprocate where regular dining is a feature of their relationship with the person they are meeting. Few amongst the majority of taxpayers in Australia have had access to either business lunches or entertainment deductions. Nevertheless, they have been footing the bill, at least in part. This situation could not be permitted to continue unchecked.

SPEECH.PARA: Some fringe benefits are undoubtedly necessary to a person's job and pursuit of income. Many have been fought for as part of industry awards. However, many more have been granted as non-cash benefits purely for the purpose of avoiding taxation. Therefore, the Government has decided, quite rightly, that employers should pay the tax on most fringe benefits which are extended to employees. Under these circumstances, employers and employees will be able to discuss the relative merits of specific fringe benefit arrangements and the consequences of their possible renegotiation.

The Government's tax package also includes the provision of quarterly provisional tax, to commerce from 1987-88. This ought to reduce the stress on the money market-as is well known to honourable members on both sides of the House-at particular times of the year. When fully implemented, four instalments will be payable. This is an important reform and one which many people in the community have accepted. The simplification of the wholesale rate structure from four scales to three is another important reform.

In passing, I would like to reject the method and nature of the approach by the cosmetics lobby to Federal members of parliament. It is a particularly tasteless attempt to create artificial divisions in the Parliament and the community-not to mention between men and women.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you sending yours back?

—Of course I will send mine back. Many women-I include myself-do not view the items selected by that cosmetics lobby as necessities. However, that is not the reason I reject the approach. Most members of parliament would be offended to think that a $30 package of cosmetics could change their views on an issue of principle. I hasten to add that there probably are areas within the wholesale tax allocation that need further review. I am sure that the Treasurer would agree. However, those items chosen by the cosmetics lobby in its endeavour are not necessarily essential items. Therefore they ought not, just for the sake of it, be put into the lower tax bracket.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government in this package has undertaken far-reaching and substantial tax reforms. It has addressed the recognised need to reduce marginal tax rates, to curtail tax avoidance and evasion and to restore fairness to the taxation system. It has also recognised the need to gear our tax system to encourage economic growth and to provide greater reward for initiative by removing distorting tax shelters. It is important to note in this context the removal of previously allowed negative gearing and the introduction of a capital gains tax. These were necessary and reasonable reforms. They should assist in removing capital from relatively non-productive areas, such as the purchase of real estate and second properties, and placing it in areas which are more productive, and which have greater implications for employment. These reforms have also been received well and understood by most Australian taxpayers. Emphasis will continue to be given to stamping out avoidance and evasion in the Australian tax system. I congratulate the Government on its genuine and courageous attempts to reform the tax system in the way that it has.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Cowan (Ms Jakobsen), along with other Government speakers in this debate, talked as if she really believed the claim of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that this tax reform package before the House is the largest, most comprehensive and far-reaching reform package to be put down by a government in living memory. That might be true in terms of the number of changes to the system that are assembled in the one package. There is indeed a whole air about this package of the Treasurer casting around to achieve substance and face by the range and number of reform measures in order to make up for the humiliating defeat that he suffered at the July National Taxation Summit. There the famous option C which he favoured and which would have enabled real and fundamental reform was thrown out under pressure from the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the left wing of the Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: So the present package is distinguished by the number of changes it would make, but it fails the test of fundamental reform in terms of the shape of change to which the Treasurer was passionately attached a few months ago, namely to reduce substantially the excessive reliance in the Australian tax system on personal income tax, with a particular focus on changing the present exploitative 46 per cent, 48 per cent and 60 per cent marginal tax rates and the low thresholds at which they become operative-reducing the tax rates and increasing thresholds. I stress the matter of the thresholds as did the Treasurer in his latest statement in which he stated:
. . . at the beginning of the 1970s the top rate came in at the current equivalent of $110,000, today it comes in at $35,000.
He refers to the threshold but, of course, he is not doing anything about it. He is not in a position to do anything about it.

In the welter of discussion about the detail of the array of measures in the present package, it is salutary to pause and review the case for this central thrust of reform, reducing the excessive reliance on personal income tax, as it was put in the June White Paper and, indeed, so eloquently argued up and down the nation by the Treasurer. This case basically looks at the situation in Australia over the years and is not necessarily based on comparisons with overseas countries. In the mid-1950s about 35 per cent of all taxation was personal income tax. In the late 1960s and 1970s that amount was up to 40 per cent and currently personal income tax is about 52 per cent of total receipts for the Government. In fact, that is a higher incidence of personal income tax than in most other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. In addition, taxpayers on quite moderate income levels are exposed to very high marginal rates of tax. In 1954-55 only one per cent of taxpayers faced a marginal rate equal to or greater than 46 per cent. Currently, nearly 40 per cent of taxpayers do, that is, nearly half of any additional income that they earn, or any increase in income, goes in tax. Again, in 1954-55 the top marginal rate, then 66 per cent, began at an income level approximately 18 times average weekly earnings which would be equivalent to an income of about $400,000 today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Staggering.

—As my colleague says, the comparison is staggering. Currently, the top marginal rate comes in at $35,000 which is 1.6 times average weekly earnings. These marginal rates adversely affect incentives and hence efficiency and growth; they also, of course, encourage people to take steps to avoid or evade paying tax. As the Treasurer put it in his statement, `taxpayers just will not pay ridiculously high marginal rates'. The extent of avoidance and evasion is reflected in the comparison between the situation in 1954-55 and now. In 1954-55, something like 54 per cent of all income tax came from people with incomes up to 1.6 times average weekly earnings. Today, the quantum of income tax coming from that group is barely 21 per cent. All this adds up to an imperative to do something dramatic about the personal tax system; in particular, lowering marginal rates but also increasing thresholds.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps people could live with a marginal rate of 46c in the dollar if it was imposed at a higher level of income than average earnings, or $19,500. Perhaps they could live with a 60 per cent rate if it came in at an income of something like $100,000 which, as the Treasurer said, was the case only as recently as 1972. But when the 60 per cent rate comes in at an income of $35,000, barely one and a half times average earnings, it is totally unacceptable.

There are two ways of achieving the desired change. One is to cut substantially the aggregate of government expenditure. We know that this Government will not look at that proposition. It has specifically ruled it out in the discussions of tax reform. The other is to move to a greater reliance on a broad-based indirect tax, which has the added advantage of taxing at the point of spending money in the so-called black or cash economy. That is a very important and significant aspect of this matter. In fact, the White Paper, subsequently embraced by the Treasurer, proposed just such a move. The Treasurer embraced with a sort of bold vision the introduction of a broad-based consumption tax at the very high-indeed, too high-rate of 12 1/2 per cent. That, even allowing for compensating persons disadvantaged by such a tax, would have enabled a substantial change to be made to the income tax system. Indeed, the Treasurer, growing bolder as he went along, suggested that he could go further and even index the personal income tax structure he should finally implement so that that structure would continue. That has always been a highly desirable practice, not least to the union movement. It has always been anomalous that without tax indexation the full indexation of wages-adjusting wages fully to the price index-will still leave employees with a decline in their real incomes. I believe that there is a commitment in the much-vaunted accord to an annual review of tax rates with that purpose in mind.

As we know, the broad-based consumption tax was not on, largely owing to the opposition from the Australian Council of Trade Unions and from the left wing of the Australian Labor Party. I give notice that the present policy of the Opposition is to move to less reliance on personal income tax via some form of a broad-based indirect tax. For my own part, that would be a value-added tax-a VAT-but I am not suggesting that that is the policy of the Opposition.

What in the end do we get? We get a set of measures-some, like the capital gains tax, operative right now as my colleague the honourable member for Forde (Dr Watson) so adequately expounded this morning-which, notwithstanding some good factors such as the imputation system for company tax having the effect of ending the double taxation of dividends, adds up to a total package which lacks any coherent sense of purpose or direction, is depressing to business and is inimical to growth and employment.
In respect of the capital gains tax, let me again quote the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). On 16 February 1983, the Prime Minister said:
. . . let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it; and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentation and distortion. There will be no new capital gains tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who could believe him after that?

—Who could indeed? We now have the capital gains tax in place and, in addition, we have an increase in the company tax rate; we have the tax on fringe benefits. I am not necessarily against a tax on fringe benefits, but this tax is to be paid by the employer. These measures, combined with the total disallowance of entertainment expenditure, may be seen-I believe that this is its most disturbing aspect-as potentially the first step in a general attack on the deductibility of business expenses, which would be a very serious matter. We have that package of measures on the one side. What will we get on the other, so far as personal income tax is concerned, which, as I have stressed, is the prime focus of the whole tax reform exercise? The personal tax changes are not to be implemented immediately and are contingent on a variety of macro-economic conditions such as the rate of economic growth, inflation, the Government's containment of spending and the deficit-I do not have too many great expectations in that area-and will not be in the final form until 1 July 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: What is in prospect in respect of the personal income tax is a change in the marginal rate scale as follows. Apart from a raising of the tax free threshold there are to be no changes at all to thresholds. The 46c rate will be reduced to 43c and then to 40c. That is commendable enough, but it is still to come in at $19,500. The 60 per cent rate is to be reduced by 1 July 1987 to 49 per cent. That is a welcome reduction but the rate is still too high when it comes in at a level of income only 1.6 times average earnings, namely, $35,000. So we have a proposed reduction-we have not yet got the reduction-from 60 per cent to 49 per cent but no change in the thresholds. In this overall package we are looking at a number of measures which, as I said, do not add up to any coherent purpose or direction, are depressing to business and are inimical to growth and employment. The final outcome, after all the trauma and all the potential disruption, is that the proposed changes in marginal tax rates are something of a wimp.

I believe that no one who has any understanding of the complexity of the Australian tax system or of the myths and misinformation that surround it would pretend for a moment that the task of tax reform in Australia, or anywhere else, for that matter, is an easy one. There are no easy, quick or simple solutions. But, recognising that fact and seeing how this Government has laboured so hard and long and, in respect of the central objective, brought forth a mouse, it will fall to the next coalition government to accept the challenge of fundamental reform towards a tax system with much less reliance on personal income tax, a system which is conducive to entrepreneurship and growth and which addresses the needs of Australian families.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address my remarks in the first instance to the amendment moved by the Opposition spokesman on Treasury affairs. The Opposition says in the amendment that it welcomes some of the measures outlined by the Government for the relief of the double taxation of dividends and the promised reduction in marginal tax rates. However, it has then gone on its usual way to try to make some sort of criticism based on five or six items. I shall go through them one by one.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, the Opposition specifically condemns the Government for the proposed introduction of a new capital gains tax. We know now, following a question answered by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in this House yesterday, that the Opposition spokesman has stated quite categorically that the Opposition is now in favour of the introduction of a capital gains tax.

In fact, the Opposition is in favour of the extension of section 26AAA. This relates to a capital gains tax on speculation which is imposed at the full marginal rate on the full nominal gain. However, honourable members opposite have the audacity to support their Treasury spokesman's amendment condemning the proposed introduction of a very mild capital gains tax announced by the Treasurer in September in order to reform the Australian taxation system.

It seems to me that on one hand we have a government prepared to work to reform the taxation system and, on the other hand, we have an opposition prepared to move amendments to the motion to take note of the paper-thus condemning the Government-at the same time as its spokesman for Treasury matters in the Senate has stated that the Opposition proposes to introduce a more severe capital gains tax than the one proposed to be introduced by the Government. We can see that honourable members opposite are very much at sea in relation to their policies in this regard. In paragraph (2) of the amendment the Opposition:
notes that under the Government's proposals the share of revenue carried by personal income tax will continue to rise;

That would be acceptable because over the last three years-including 1985-86-we have seen growth at a level not achieved in Australia since the 1960s. We have growth in employment and the economy. Therefore, it is quite understandable that there will be a further rise in the share of personal income tax revenues. That is a matter for congratulation, not condemnation. Therefore, any one who understands economics at all will never condemn the fact that there will be a growth in employment and revenue and, henceforth, a growth in the personal share of income tax which will continue to rise. The Opposition in paragraph (3) of the amendment then:
condemns the arbitrary nature of the attack on fringe benefits and entertainment expenses;

My heart bleeds for all those in the political arena who feel that the taxpayer should pay for free lunches which are legitimately part of business. I do not have any qualms about any person who wants to go to a restaurant for dinner. However, there is no reason in the world why the taxpayer should be asked to pay for those lunches if they are a business expense. If a business takes a decision to run its operations along that line, by all means let it do so. However, if such a business wants to put on a lunch there is no reason why the taxpayer should foot the bill. I quite agree with the position the Government has taken on that matter. That policy will affect politicians and business. It is right across the board and thus could not be said to be arbitrary. In paragraph (4) of the amendment the Opposition states that it:
expresses grave concern on enterprise, investment and employment due to the additional cost burdens on business arising from the capital gains tax--

I cannot see where there will be any enormous cost burden on either enterprise or investment in this regard. Certainly, it will have an effect on how people invest in the future. As a result of a tax reform of this nature for the first time investors will be able to sit down and make a legitimate decision as to where they will invest their money for the best return they can get and, also, the best return for the good of the economy. In the future we will not see as much investment in properties on the outskirts of towns around Australia where, as we all know, the price of land far exceeds its value for legitimate returns on investment. Everybody knows that that is being done only for capital gains purposes in the long term.

I think as a result of these measures we will see real reforms in this area. The proposed capital gains tax will not have a major effect on people's incomes, nor will it have a major effect on enterprise, investment and employment, as has been stated by the shadow Treasurer. It will have a proper effect on people making correct economic decisions. In paragraph (4) the Opposition further expresses grave concern over the:
. . . fringe benefits tax and the loss of deductions for legitimate entertaining expenses;

The Opposition says that this also will have the same effect on private enterprise. I think honourable members opposite have a very low opinion of the board rooms of Australian companies. They think that these measures will have a dramatic and detrimental effect on business as to where it will make investments in the future. I firmly believe-I am sure it will be proven, long before the next election-that the measures introduced by this Government will result in proper investments. There will be plenty of enterprise, plenty of investment and plenty of employment in Australia. The figures will continue to show that. In paragraph (5) and (6) of the amendment the Opposition states that it:
regrets the package will have an adverse and discriminatory impact on rural Australia;
notes the particular discriminatory nature of the attack on the deductibility of farm losses against non-farm income . . .

Once again, the intention is quite clear. The taxation package is designed to operate right across the board. The capital gains tax is as important as the element concerning the deductibility of farm losses. That has been put in place in such a way that genuine farmers-those who are working the land; those who are producing a major export industry for this nation-will be protected. The proposed change will affect only the Pitt Street and Collins Street farmers who write off big losses from other industries into the capital speculative areas around our country towns and who push up land prices. This will be the greatest measure for our economy. It will really turn around our investment decisions. It will push people into genuine production investments which, I hope, will push land prices back to a realistic level.

A lot of concern has been expressed to the effect that land prices will come down and that this will have a detrimental effect. I do not know how this can be so. The thing that keeps young people and others out of farming in our nation is the ridiculous price of land. The price of land in country areas right around the nation is so ridiculous simply because of the speculative nature of the people who are not genuine farmers who go into that industry. They are pushing land prices up. No doubt, the measures taken in the taxation reform package will have an effect in that area. They will have a positive effect. They will bring land prices down to a realistic level. Some while ago an honourable member interjected to mention the assets test. The only problem that people discovered with the assets test is that their land values were far in excess of their earning capacity. The asset they alleged they had was valued far in excess of what it was worth. That is one of the real problems in our economy. We are not as wealthy as we believe we are. The simple reason for this is that land values are far in excess of what they should be.

I will spend the few minutes I have left detailing the quarantining of farm losses and the improved averaging provisions announced by the Government because I believe, as Chairman of the Caucus Primary Industry Committee, that there has been some confusion in country areas in relation to this. I will detail those. In the paper `Reform of the Australian Taxation System' the Treasurer stated:

Deductions for losses for the 1986-87 and subsequent income years from a taxpayer's primary production activities are to be limited to the amount of non-farm income deemed to be `notional' annual farm income and specified as the greater of:
$15,000 shading out dollar for dollar for non-farm incomes between $15,000 and $30,000, with these thresholds subject to indexation in subsequent years; and
the aggregate of the previous 5 years of net farm income.

Any excess primary production loss is to be carried forward indefinitely for deduction in later years against the taxpayer's farm income, the annual notional farm income specified above and any taxable gain on disposal of primary production property. Quarantined primary production losses carried forward will be deducted in later years ahead of any losses carried forward under the existing loss provisions of the income tax law.

The measure will apply to all individuals, companies, partnerships and trusts carrying on a business of primary production. Many farms are operated as husband and wife partnerships and the notional farm income provisions could benefit both partners if they each earned non-farm income.

The specified `national' farm income limit of $15,000 and associated shade-out provisions, together with the indexing of these, will also extend to the current income tax averaging arrangements under which a maximum of $5,000 of `notional' farm income is allowed for averaging purposes. This will provide a significant tax benefit to many genuine primary producers, unrelated to the proposed quarantining measure.

The increase in the specified monetary limit from the $10,000 in the draft White Paper to an indexed $15,000 significantly increases the amount of non-farm income able to be earned by farmers without being affected by the quarantining measure. In increasing this monetary limit and indexing it the Government was particularly mindful of the fact that many genuine farmers can earn significant amounts of non-farm income, especially during hard times.

Taxpayers will also be able to attract higher notional farm income for quarantining purposes in particular years by demonstrating a proven record of farm profitability, regardless of the level of their non-farm income in those years. This profitability test will address more completely those cases where farm losses are caused by downturns or disasters, rather than by tax sheltering activity. Losses of up to the aggregate of the previous five years' net farm income may be offset against other income.

The quarantining of taxpayers' primary production losses to, broadly, their income from primary production is aimed at taxpayers who undertake farm activities to exploit weaknesses in our tax system: particularly, the up-front deductions for full nominal interest payments and rapid write-off provisions, coupled with the later realisation of capital gains which are either not taxed or, as proposed, taxed on a preferential basis. Sheltering non-farm income from tax in loss-making years is an essential part of this exploitation.

For similar reasons the Government announced on 17 July 1985 the quarantining of excess interest from `negatively geared' rental property investments to the income and taxable gains from those investments. Similar quarantining measures will be applied to other areas should that prove necessary to protect the revenue from tax sheltering activities.

The notional farm income concept to be applied with the quarantining of farm losses is designed to minimise adverse effects of the measure on genuine farmers or other taxpayers undertaking primary production purely for commercial reasons. Such a concept avoids the disadvantages of qualitative and quantitative tests that would otherwise be required and which invariably would be complex, would involve very heavy administrative workloads and could introduce uncertainties as to the outcome in particular cases.

The measure will inevitably have some effect on some existing investments, particularly those with longer lead times. Nevertheless, the measure does not apply to losses until the 1986-87 income year and losses incurred before then will remain deductible against either farm or non-farm income of future years. Both the delay in the start-up of the measure and the more generous treatment in relation to non-farm income will ameliorate the effects of the measure on existing investments.

Offsetting the revenue gains from the quarantining measure will be the effect of the significant improvement in the primary production averaging provisions. An additional $20 million per annum benefit to farmers will arise from the complementary increase in the notional farm income limit for primary production averaging purposes, from the current level of $5,000 to the new level of $15,000. This represents a significant increase in the amount of non-farm income which may benefit from the averaging provisions.

It is estimated that revenue gains from these measures will be $105m in 1987-88 and $75m per annum thereafter. I contend that the major input in this area is that this total package works as a unit. It will have a major effect on investment in Australia in the future. The measures that have been announced in many cases are revenue neutral. They are not designed as tax collecting measures. They have been put together in such a way as to put the economy of this country into a position where it can go into the next century with proper investment.

Nobody who understands the Australian economy and who has looked at it over the last 10 years could express anything but alarm at the sort of approach that has been taken. We have had many measures put forward by way of discussion so far as tax reforms are concerned. We have had inquiry after inquiry. A conservative government took over the Australian economy in 1975 and for the next seven years dallied with talk about tax reform but achieved absolutely nothing. That government worked its way through the system at that time with the greatest income bonanza any government could have had from the oil fields in Bass Strait, in my area of Victoria. It did not use that money for the good of Australia. It did not use it to develop this country. It used the money to overcome its inability to tackle tax reform. Massive amounts-$4,000m and $5,000m-came into the coffers of the Government. It was a great short term opportunity-that oil is going to run out in a short time-which this country should not have missed. The conservative forces threw away what was probably the greatest opportunity Australia has ever had. In the last three years this Government has put its mind to work and has put into place tax reforms which will put investment in Australia into the right mode and create more employment and more jobs. There will be more enterprise in Australia. There will be more confidence. Amendments such as that put forward today by the shadow Treasurer will do nothing for the Australian economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I address some of the specific parts of the Government's so-called reform package, let me say that I think it is important to understand that today we are talking very much about shifting the chairs on the Titanic. The one thing that this Government has not been prepared to do is to sit down and talk about the level of government expenditure. The reason it does not want to talk about government expenditure is that it is a government that believes in continually increasing government expenditure, the size of government and the size of bureaucracy. The Australian people want to hear about less government and less taxation. Is it any wonder that the Government's standing in the Australian community is deteriorating day by day and hour by hour? For those of us on this side of the House that is no surprise, particularly in view of the Government's decision to introduce capital gains taxes to king hit the restaurant industry in this country, and at the same time, by way of nice contrast, to pay out to a bloke whom it instructed to be sacked hundreds of thousands of dollars when its own legal opinion has told it that $10 would have been enough.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I wish to refer particularly to the Government's proposal for identification cards and for the introduction of a capital gains tax. I think the nub of the argument in relation to ID cards is that they will not work, they will not be effective, and they will be a massive intrusion into the privacy of ordinary Australians. They will also be a licence to the criminal element in this country to print money at the expense of ordinary honest Australians. The proposal can be said to be a Canberra bureaucrat's classic which has been frantically pounced upon by a government anxious to pad out its latest tax reform package. The Government's decision to proceed with the scheme has all the hallmarks of a government which has completely lost direction and which has abandoned its principles at virtually every turn.

It is no wonder the Government was pretty worried recently, with the ascension to the leadership of the Liberal Party of the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), when a popularity poll showed that many Australians had a perception of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as one who was very quick to abandon party principle. This failure to abide by policy, by party principle, is fertile ground for the development of a government propensity to go native. Many of my constituents ask me whether what they see on that television program Yes Minister is true. Unfortunately, in this case I would have to say that it is absolutely true. The term `go native' is brilliantly defined in that television series as the tendency of Ministers to forgo their status as advocates of the interests of their constituents, their party and their principles and to become instead representatives of their departments. This is very apparent in the proposal for ID cards. It has been so enthusiastically supported by some of Canberra's bureaucrats that we recently had the spectacle of the Australian Government Publishing Service and the Health Insurance Commission squabbling over who would get the spoils.

I say to Australians listening today that when we see bureaucrats fighting over who is going to administer a program, watch out, because what it means is greater expense on them, greater burdens on them, and more and more bureaucracy. As was so appropriately said by Sir Robert Menzies, one thing about bureaucrats is that they never swallow their young. Leave them alone and we will find them increasing every year. Once the cue was given, the bureaucratic machine was very quick to prepare a glossy brochure, at massive public expense, which was paraded at the taxation summit. This is the bureaucrats' idea of producing charisma. In their frenzy, they glossed over the social and economic costs of the proposal and, as we have already seen, there have since been some massive revisions to the original costings. Just for good measure, in a demonstration of complete contempt for the common sense of the ordinary Australian, some bureaucratic boffin dreamt up the idea that the ID card would be more palatable if called the Australia Card, as if people would somehow be fooled by this prostitution of the name `Australia'.
Originally the savings were going to be $800m, the establishment cost was going to be a mere $38m, and the running costs were going to be $40m-odd.

Now we hear that the start-up of the scheme will cost $127m and the annual running costs will be between $86m and $100m. There will be no real savings until 1991 and the saving of $540m, which will not be reached until 1993, remains totally unsubstantiated.

By way of contrast to these meaningless estimates plucked from thin air, the fine print notes that there will be extra costs on business. The Government was quick to tell us the savings, but very reluctant to tell us the costs on business and to make some estimates of those costs. This proposal for ID cards has all the hallmarks of an episode from Yes Minister, with a dose of George Orwell's Big Brother. It gives us more government and, like all schemes said to save money, will take more and more from the average taxpayer. It suits the bureaucratic mind that finds numbers easier than names, and it is all couched in the context of another scheme for the public good. Instead of providing benefits to the average taxpayer, it will open yet another opportunity for the fraudulent and will give thousands of bureaucrats access to the bank accounts of every man, woman and child in this country. From the cradle to the central registry in Canberra to the grave ID cards will keep track of every Australian and will lead to ever greater government control over the private lives of the ordinary, honest citizen. To those who say that the ordinary, honest Australian has nothing to fear, the fact is that it is the ordinary, honest Australian who will cop the abuses of Labor's ID card proposal. Mr Justice Kirby recently described the significance of ID cards when he said:
What is at stake is nothing less than the nature of our society, and the power and authority of the State in relation to the individual.

This proposal is of such significance that I believe the Government before proceeding with it should conduct a plebiscite so that all Australians can fully participate in this decision. I know that the Government will not take up that proposition and for those who are proponents of the cards the reason is quite clear. There is no doubt that public opinion is moving against this proposal as the outrageous aspects of it become clearer as time proceeds. The proposal in my view will in due course obtain the sort of opposition that is clearly building in the community in regard to the capital gains tax.

I now take the opportunity of referring to the capital gains tax. The recent opinion poll that was taken, which confirmed the Opposition's views, showed that 73 per cent of Australian voters expressed their opposition to Labor's plans to introduce a capital gains tax. And if that figure were not high enough for the Government, it is interesting to note that of the 20 per cent said to be in favour, 8 per cent had no idea what level of tax would be appropriate, 8 per cent favoured a rate up to 29 per cent, and only 4 per cent favoured a rate above 30 per cent, which would equate with the taxation of capital gains at the top marginal rate, which is essentially this proposal. The relevance of these figures relates to the principles laid down by the Government when it went to the tax summit. Let me quote one of those principles:
Any reform package must have widespread community support . . .

Clearly there is not widespread community support for the capital gains tax proposals. And well might there not be public support for it, because the proposal attacks the incentives in this community to build up assets and the standard of living of all Australians. It is a classic piece of Labor legislation aimed at denigrating the tall poppies, attacking the achievers in the society and bringing them all down to the lowest common denominator.

This country has a few economic problems. What we want is a government and some legislation which address those problems and which give people some encouragement to get out there and take a risk; to forgo some income and build up some goodwill, build up some good businesses and start to make proper provision for their families. I believe that it is about time this Government started to realise that, instead of relying on rhetoric based on allegations or claims of concern about economic growth, it should face up to realities in the small business community, the farming sector and other sectors in this community which are trying to make a go of things. I state quite clearly that the Liberal Party and the National Party are totally opposed to a capital gains tax proposal. We will vote against it in this House and in the Senate, and we will repeal it on our return to government.
