PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Shack, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act 1985 was introduced into this House in 1977 by the then coalition Government's Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, the Honourable Tony Street. It was introduced at a time of great crisis in public sector industrial relations. Mr Deputy Speaker, you, amongst many, will remember it well. Air traffic controllers across Australia had implemented work to rule bans which had crippled air travel at enormous cost and inconvenience to the community. At that time the then Minister said:

. . . it would be the Government's hope that it will not be necessary to use this legislation and it is the Government's intention that this Bill will not be proclaimed to operate unless circumstances so dictate. Certainly it recognises that the very great majority of government employees and their union have acted, and do act, responsibly. Indeed, the legislation would not have been necessary but for the actions of a minority.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the Bill was passed in 1977 but it was not proclaimed until 1979, and only then in response to disruption in the operations of Telecom Australia because of bans applied by members of the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association. Legislation introduced as a deterrent and as a measure of last resort in the event of union delinquency in the Commonwealth Public Service was proclaimed only after great patience on the then coalition Government's part in the face of excessive and unreasonably defined industrial action by some public sector unions. It was the coalition's view then and it is still our view that public servants have a special responsibility to the community and a particular duty to take into account the public good when pursuing their legitimate collective interests. The Honourable Ian Viner, when Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs in the previous coalition Government, summed up our view nicely when he said:
The Australian public has a right to expect of its public servants a fair day's work for a fair day's pay.

That was not too much to ask then and it is not too much to ask now. Most public servants would agree that this is a reasonable expectation. Indeed, I believe that their special responsibilities are acknowledged by them and are a source of pride to the overwhelming majority of Australian Commonwealth public servants. In return for a commitment and a standard of behaviour commensurate with those special responsibilities they receive benefits not received by employees generally in the private sector, including permanency of employment and exceptionally generous superannuation arrangements.

Until very recently Commonwealth public servants, more than any other group of Australian workers, could be relied upon to pursue the negotiation of their wages and conditions in the most reasonable manner possible. They provided a laudable model of industrial responsibility. However, over the last decade certain sections of the Australian Public Service have shown a regrettable willingness to breach the bounds of reasonable industrial behaviour.

This is regrettable not only from the Commonwealth's point of view, as an employer, but also from the community's point of view because it is the community which suffers most from any disruption to the Commonwealth's provision of services. It is also regrettable from the point of view of the majority of public servants who have seen their own reputation decline in the eyes of the community to a point where they were bracketed earlier this year with outrageously militant unions such as the Builders Labourers Federation as a result of the industrial guerilla action campaign they pursued in their quest for an 8.3 per cent wage rise.

Public Service union officials must answer to their members for this decline in their reputation, which is a major embarrassment to the many dedicated and serious-minded employees of the Commonwealth Public Service. Let me state unequivocally that public servants are workers; they have an undeniable right to negotiate with their employer over wages and conditions. The coalition recognises this freedom and has no argument with it. However, we do expect public servants to behave always with the public interest foremost in mind. The interruption of vital government services, services which are absolutely central to the Commonwealth Government's fulfilment of its duty to this nation, does not constitute reasonable industrial action. The CE(EP) Act was drafted as a contingency measure to be used in instances where Public Service unionists lost sight of their duty-our joint duty-to the Australian community.

The Public Service dispute which occurred in the first quarter of 1985 was certainly such an instance. In place of decisive action on the part of the Government to bring unlawfully militant Public Service unionists into line, we witnessed weakness and compliance. Even if the Government had wished to take the firm and proper stand which the situation and the community called for, the task would have been that much more difficult because of action it took in 1983 to repeal the CE(EP) Act. The Government threw away an effective deterrent without having anything to replace it. The consequences earlier this year were only too apparent. As the Public Service unions campaign for 8.3 per cent rise steamed ahead-a claim which was, incidentally, well outside the ambit of the Government's much vaunted accord-the Government looked decidedly acquiescent. A Full Bench of the institution normally so much loved by the Labor movement and this Government, the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, ruled against the claim. In fact, it awarded no pay rise whatsoever. But the Public Service unions would not take no for an answer. They would not abide by the umpire's ruling.

What followed may be faint in the minds of many people, Mr Deputy Speaker, but it should be remembered that this memory should not be allowed to fade any further. Commonwealth public servants refused to process government revenues; cheques and receipts of all sorts gathered dust as they refused to handle the banking of Commonwealth moneys. In at least one case physical intimidation was used by some Public Service unionists against other public servants who were fulfilling their normal duties. Goods of all types sat idly on the wharves because Customs officials refused to clear import duties. The money market went into a spin as a result of the Government's lack of control and authority in the situation. This contributed to the nose dive of the Australian dollar, which depreciated rapidly against other world currencies and has not recovered much since.

Instead of acting rapidly and decisively to end this outrageous industrial blackmail, the Government acquiesced. Instead of reminding public servants of the responsibilities that accompany their substantial rights, the Government caved in. Instead of doing what was right and just, the Government followed the line of least resistance. Even if the Government had decided to live up to its responsibilities to sort out the Public Service unions, the job would have been extremely difficult because of its foolish repeal in 1983 of the previous coalition Government's CE(EP) Act.

Mr Deputy Speaker, we do not wish to witness ever again the dithering weakness and compliance of a government held hostage by its own employees. I commend this private member's Bill to the House so that this Government and no other future government are incapable of responding in the appropriate manner to public servants who refuse to work as directed-that is, by standing them down without pay. This Bill will give the Commonwealth a power which should be the right of all employers-the power to stand down without pay employees who refuse to work as directed. The coalition supports this Bill. It is being introduced in a non-confrontationist manner at a time when all is quiet on the Public Service industrial relations front. This Bill is not in response to any particular crisis or emergency; rather, it is designed to return to the range of industrial relations measures available to the Commonwealth one very necessary and legitimate power. While workers have a right to strike, no one has the right to expect to be paid while they refuse to perform the duties required of them. I am confident that the community supports the no work as directed, no pay principle. Apart from anything else, taxpayers have an understandably violent objection to paying the wages of public servants who are denying them the services to which they are justifiably entitled. Further, I am sure that the vast bulk of hard working and dedicated Commonwealth public servants supported the original CE(EP) Act and would support its reintroduction. Without it they know that they and their Public Service are made vulnerable to the destructive excesses of militant trade unionism. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Connolly

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and I reserve my right to speak.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted for the debate to proceed forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Bill is an extraordinary example of doctrinaire posturing by the previous shadow Minister for Industrial Relations and the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack). It is a clear example of the way in which the Opposition is allowing ideology to direct its policy rather than common sense. It is also a clear example of how little the honourable member for Tangney knows about the Public Service. I wonder whether he has ever met a Public Service union leader and whether he has any sense at all of the intensity of opposition to this Bill which exists throughout the public sector and therefore the extent of the provocation to industrial conflict which he is attempting to cause.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, there are 10 sound strong reasons why this Bill is inept, any one of which is, by itself, sufficient reason for opposing the Bill. As I have 10 minutes, that is one reason a minute so I will have to be quick. First, the Bill is a provocation of industrial conflict. It is like a red rag to a bull; the honourable member is like a bull in a china shop. All the cliches apply. He appears to be trying to cause conflict rather than to resolve it. If the Bill were passed there would be a wave of protest, of strikes and bans over nothing more than an unnecessary statute, for-this is the second reason-the Government as employer already has the right to apply to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to suspend or stand down employees involved in, or affected by, industrial action. That right exists under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Therefore, why provoke a dispute when it is entirely unnecessary. Also, this legislation would give the Commonwealth Government powers not available to other employers.

The honourable member for Tangney demonstrated his ignorance by saying that the Government had no alternative to the CE(EP) Act when it was abolished. This is simply untrue. The Government has the same clear right as any employer to go to the Commission and ask for a stand-down clause in the award. That is the third reason for opposing the Bill. It is inappropriate for the Commonwealth to be able to suppress conflict just as it would be a rejection of the rights of employees in the private sector to give business that opportunity. Neither public nor private employers should have the unilateral right to withdraw oppressively the right to strike.

The more constructive and consultative approach is to take a conflict to the Commission for conciliation and, if necessary, arbitration. Public sector employers can be rigid and unreasonable, just like those in the private sector. They should not be protected from having to argue their case before a tribunal. So, fourthly, there are alternative approaches to dispute settlement which are likely to be more permanently effective. Suppression of conflict does not resolve a dispute; rather the grievance festers, spreads and breaks out more violently later. The positive alternative is to take the dispute to the Commission and, if all other approaches to settlement have failed and there is clear intransigence, apply for stand-down powers. Such an application ensures that the views of all parties are considered rather than just those of the employer. Fifthly, the Bill does not include any right of appeal or avenue of redress other than under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act which effectively allows a review only on matters of law and not on the merits of a decision. So the Bill is designed not only to prevent unions from presenting their case to a tribunal but also to prevent them from appealing against any unilateral decision by an employer.

Sixthly, the CE(EP) Act, which the Fraser Government introduced, the present Government repealed and the Opposition is now trying to reintroduce, was carefully examined by the International Labour Organisation's Committee on Freedom of Association and was strongly criticised. The ILO committee was highly critical of the virtually unlimited capacity of the Commonwealth to apply the Act to employees involved in industrial action at any time. It was also critical of the lack of any role for an independent adjudicator, and also of the danger that the Act might be used before other conciliation and arbitration procedures were exhausted. The Committee considered that such punitive sanctions would impede harmonious industrial relations. To go ahead with the Bill in the face of such strong and of course well-based international criticism would be a deliberate invitation to Australian public sector unions to start another protest, to cause conflict rather than to resolve it.

Seventhly, the Fraser Government used the previous CE(EP) Act nine times yet there is no evidence in any of those cases that the Act had any effect in reducing industrial action or in ending a dispute. Rather, several times use of the Act had the effect of extending a dispute and causing greater disruption to the public. Disputes end only when they are resolved, not when strikes are supressed. In fact-I go to the eighth reason-use of the Act generated yet another costly and time wasting cause of litigiousness. When the present Government repealed the Act in 1983, a large number of actions was still before the Federal Court under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. Those actions were brought by Commonwealth employees challenging the validity of their suspensions under the CE(EP) Act during the social security staffing dispute in 1981 and were based on claims of denial of natural justice.

Ninthly, both unions and private employers agreed with the repeal of the Act in 1983. The tripartite National Labour Consultative Council was consulted about the proposal to repeal the Act and agreed to that action. So yet again the Opposition is advocating policies which have no significant support anywhere, from either employers or unions. The honourable member for Tangney is clearly demonstrating more of an authoritarian reflex than any genuine concern about resolving industrial disputes. Tenthly and finally, this Bill is contrary to the whole structure and strategy for industrial relations which is being so successfully applied at present. The Government is encouraging resolution of all conflicts through consultation. The accord between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions sets a fair framework for the maintenance and improvement of real wages. Industrial confrontation and conflict has fallen; in fact, strikes are at their lowest level for 16 years. Claims outside the wage guidelines are prevented but anomalies can be addressed through the system. Other disputes are handled through the normal conciliation and arbitration procedures.

So I return to the beginning, Mr Deputy Speaker. There are 10 sound strong reasons why this Bill is inept, any one of which is by itself sufficient reason for opposing it. Together they make a conclusive case against the Bill. That is why it was repealed and why it is simply inept to propose its reintroduction. It is not only inept but also unnecessary, provocative and authoritarian. It has been condemned by the ILO and opposed by both employers' representatives and unions in Australia. The honourable member who introduced the Bill is demonstrating his own ignorance and short-sightedness. The real reasons for moving his actions are difficult to discern. I hope that he will not waste the time of the House on such a misguided proposal again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the seconder of the motion that the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Bill be read a second time, it is my great pleasure to speak in support of the proposition which we have put before this House. That proposition is not, as the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) would have us believe, based on ideology directing our policy, not common sense, but rather on the simple principle put to this House some years ago by the then Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Viner, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian public has a right to expect of its public servants a fair day's work for a fair day's pay.

The honourable member for Fraser went on to suggest-this clearly is a figment of his own imagination-that this legislation was withdrawing the right to strike. I make it absolutely clear that, whatever the personal views of Opposition members may be on the substantial economic and social disruption caused by strikes, the Opposition does not have within its policy-nor has it been suggested in this House on this occasion by my colleague the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) that this legislation in any sense implies it-a withdrawal of the right to strike.

Clearly the essence of our proposal is to replace into legislation the provisions which were removed in 1983 by this Labor Government in an attempt, which has proved manifestly to be a failure, to pay off the Australian Council of Trade Unions and win over the support of the Public Service unions. But the question which has to be asked-certainly this is where the element of common sense comes in-is: What has the Government gained by removing the no work as directed no pay provisions from the Act and what benefit have the people of Australia, who pay for their Public Service and for the other services of government, achieved as a result? The strike action which plagued this nation early this year, soon after the last Federal election, remains as living testimony of the fact that the Australian electorate and the Australian economy suffered grievously because of the weak-kneed and pusillanimous attitude of this Government in supporting a proposition put to it when in Opposition that in order to gain the political support of the trade union movement, especially the trade unions relating to the Public Service, it should support the removal of no work as directed no pay provisions.

Members of the Government would do well to recall that in the midst of the last Federal election campaign unions associated with the Department of Social Security put to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) a simple proposition: You will either agree to what we want or, in the midst of an election, we are going to go on strike and the pensioners of Australia, including 1.6-odd million age pensioners, will find themselves without access to their pensions. If that is not blackmail I would like to know what it is. That is the reality-it is on the record-of the pressure unions can apply to a government from either side of the political spectrum in an election situation. It is precisely because of situations like this that any government needs to have sufficient weapons within its industrial relations arsenal so it can at least be in a position to say to irresponsible unionists that if they take strike action, which it is their right to do, they cannot expect the Australian taxpayer to pay their way while that strike action is in place.

I think it is appropriate to point out that the concept of the no work as directed no pay provision was regarded as effective by the Public Service Board and this was emphasised in its report of 1982-83 which stated:
The Board considers that the `no work as directed no pay' provision should remain available to management and has expressed that view to the government.

Yet the Government, because of the deal that it entered into with certain public sector trade unions, ignored the advice of the statutory body which has been created and supported by both sides of this Parliament to ensure that the Public Service remains as apolitical as possible, that it is an efficient Public Service and that it gives to the Australian taxpayer a level of service and competence which it is entitled to expect. But it was this Government, the Hawke Labor Government, which for purely political reasons did away with this provision and therefore left itself effectively naked in the face of continuing militant action which reached a peak early this year.

In the context of the Government's policy of manpower budgeting there surely needs to be some security built into the system because what we saw happen last January, February and March could well occur again in future years. The present campaign of some Public Service unions is not for higher wages, because they know they are locked in by the current accord but rather for better terms and conditions of employment which will ultimately result in less working hours. These are issues which the Government must have the courage to face and, while such issues must of course be approached on the basis of negotiation, if negotiation breaks down and if unions decide to take into their own hands the ultimate control of the situation clearly it is up to the Government to protect the interests of the Australian people and ensure that those strikers are not paid for the time during which they are not performing the functions for which they are employed.

Let us go back a few months and examine the situation as it was in early February this year. The Public Service bans which commenced in January were in protest against the Arbitration Commission's rejection on 10 January of an 8.3 per cent anomalies wage claim. All members of the Government are well aware of the fact that that 8.3 per cent claim was completely outside the terms of the wages accord which we have had put to us on so many occasions by members of the Government as the very centre of their industrial relations package. That arrangement went to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and it was rejected. It was rejected by the same Commission which the Government claims is meant to act as the arbitrator in matters of dispute such as this.

When the Government should have supported the decision of the Arbitration Commission it failed to do so. It started softening up the situation. It started making suggestions that maybe the unions could be met half way despite the fact that the terms of that settlement were absolutely contrary to the very principles which had been espoused by the Government as the basis for its accord. The ultimate result was inevitable. The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, finding itself alone, with no allies-not even a Minister, not even the government of the day-ultimately had no choice but to seek middle ground and a settlement was reached. It is worth noting that at that particular time, January, the then Deputy Leader and present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) made the observation that the Public Service unions had made it manifestly clear that their strategy `is designed to incapacitate the Government by cutting off its revenue while maintaining its outgoings'. Of course that is exactly what happened.

Twenty days after the Public Service bans were introduced this Hawke Labor Government was still continuing to pay the very same public servants who refused to do their duty, who refused to carry out the activities for which they had been employed. But they did not have the courage to go on strike, which as I said earlier was their legal right. No; they took a much more damaging approach and that was to stay at their desks but not do their job and therefore they claimed the right to be paid for doing nothing.

The Public Service bans at that stage led to an unsettled money market, which came at the same time as the massive devaluation of the Australian dollar from which, while current policies remain in place, we are not likely to recover. But let no member of the Government be under any illusion that it was the actions of that Public Service dispute early this year which set in place the international perception of a government which is not in control of its own machinery of public administration much less the economy and the development of this nation. The bans disrupted the Reserve Bank of Australia's attempts to stabilise the money market during the crucial tax run-down period which takes place in the early months of every year.

As I said earlier, the events of last January are not unique. It is absurd for any government to suggest that they will not occur again, and it is equally foolhardy for any government not to be prepared, through this Parliament and with the support of the Opposition by way of this legislation, to go to the Australian people with the knowledge that it does have the capability, even if it lacks the intestinal fortitude, to at least be able to protect the interests of the Australian people. Because of these disputes we lost in January 8.9 thousand days of work. As I have said, the vast majority of those public servants involved were paid by the Australian people for not doing their duty. In February the dispute was still in place but the number of days lost had been reduced to 2.7 thousand. By March the situation had stabilised and the level of disputation had fallen to 1.3 thousand days. Over that first quarter we lost 12.9 thousand days because of industrial disputation and the failure of this Government to support that basic principle of no work as directed no pay, or, putting it in a more simplistic but equally adequate manner, that public servants have a responsibility to do their duty to the Australian people who, in turn, have a right to expect that their public servants will do a fair day's work for a fair day's pay.

The Commonwealth Public Service dispute cost the taxpayer some $18m. The Government stood by and virtually did nothing although its revenue collections were being seriously disrupted by the actions of these militants. Large sections of the business community faced mounting losses due to the dispute which held up hundreds of millions of dollars of imports at ports and airports throughout the nation. In Sydney alone an estimated 9,000 sea freight shipments were held up at container terminals, which were bulging, as were the bonded warehouses. An estimated 340 million cheques, including one for $50m as payment of an Australian oil company's oil levy, were withheld from the Government's bank accounts. These examples represent only a tenth of the goods involved. The sources of revenue dried up, and with that the interest bills which are being carried by this nation obviously rose. For all that, we have never heard from this Government the slightest acceptance of responsibility because, as in so many other areas, it has abrogated its duty to defend the rights of the Australian people.

The main bans at that time included refusing to bank cheques of more than $2,000; refusing to send out debit assessments for more than $5,000; data processors did only half their daily work on overtime; and bans were placed on compiling work reports, which made it difficult to assess the effects of the union campaign. In addition to that we had the Customs officers dispute and, as I have said, the effects on business, especially the import and export industries, were clear. The dispute threatened to close down the vehicle production industry in Victoria; General-Motors Holden's Ltd came within minutes of closing its Dandenong works because electronic fuel injectors from West Germany were being held up by Customs officials.

Despite this, we are told that the proposals we have put forward today will in some way cut across the natural rights of the Australian who happens to be working in the Public Service. We tend to make the error time and again in this country of forgetting about the natural rights of the vast majority of the 16-odd million people who live in this land and whom we in this place are supposed to represent. They have no other voice. They do not necessarily belong to strong unions; they are not necessarily public servants; they do not have the capacity to find the ears of Ministers or even of members of Parliament. That is why our duty to them is so much more fundamental, and it is equally so much more important that we carry out that duty in a fit and proper way. For all of these reasons this Government has failed the Australian people. It has not even been prepared to leave in place legislation which the Minister of the day said was there to be used only in times of action by extremists. It has been suggested to us today that its very presence on the statutes of the land presents a challenge to natural justice. Natural justice to whom, I ask, and when and where? Where is the natural justice in a situation when during that dispute earlier this year the Victorian Branch of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association put out a bulletin entitled `Pay Dispute Bulletin No. 2'? This is what it said, and I hope these words will never be forgotten:
The nature of the industrial struggle we are fighting is to take control of the work place away from the employer . . .

Away from the employer, who in this case happens to be the elected government. Faced by that clear challenge, which has never been denied and which is specified in this document, the Government talks about natural justice. As I said, for whom? And where is duty which must be equally responsive to the concept of authority on the one hand and responsibility on the other. We have a nation where so many people talk about their rights but so few, apparently, are prepared to look to their duties.

The Australian Public Service is one of the best in the world and for many years it has had an absolutely outstanding record of minimal industrial disruption because it is made up of professional people who are committed to the future of this land. Yet we have seen in recent years a clear trend of militancy coming into some of the unions related to the Public Service. This Government's response to that trend has been supine weakness-to lie back and let the nation carry the load, to mislead people about what really will happen if we allow the public services of this nation to collapse as they did during the first quarter of this year. As I said, the whole objective of that strike as far as the ACOA Victorian Branch was concerned was to take control of the work place away from the employer.

Honourable members opposite make up the Government. They have been elected to make sure that public servants stay at their posts and do their duty; this they have failed to do. We will continue to remind the Australian people, through this Parliament, of what they have not done. If that dispute had taken place before the last Federal election they would be sitting on the other side of the House, of that there is not the slightest doubt. If it had become public during the election campaign that the Prime Minister was forced to give in to unions in the Social Security Department over the issue of cheques for pensioners, do honourable members opposite seriously suggest that those pensioners would have voted for them? Of course not. They depend on that money and it is no good coming into this place and talking about natural justice, because where was the natural justice for them during those months? Where was the natural justice for every Australian taxpayer, whose taxes inevitably have gone up? One reason for that is the fall of the Australian dollar and another is the massive increase in our overall payments on interest bills overseas. Devaluation alone has cost us over a billion dollars in payments every quarter.

All of that had its inception in the industrial disputation which took place in the Australian Public Service in the first three months of this year. We want to see no more of that and it is the responsibility of the Government to see that it has in place a sufficient armoury by which we can defend the interests of the Australian people. To do this they should support this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Saunderson Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak against the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Bill introduced by the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack). I suppose I have to start off by saying that I am not quite sure how I should treat this matter because when this Bill was first placed on the Notice Paper the honourable member was the shadow Minister for Industrial Relations. Since the coup that took place on the other side of the House and the rise of new policies within the Liberal Party, the honourable member found himself being shadow Minister for Education rather than Industrial Relations. So I am not sure whether this Bill is in fact the industrial relations policy of the current Opposition, whether it is the previous industrial relations policy of the honourable member or whether it is really another option that has been cast so that the Opposition can wander away somewhere and have another summit. It obviously cannot be up in the snowfields because it is too late in the season, but perhaps their brains might work a bit better somewhere else. They might be able to come up with a cohesive policy. It is very difficult to mount an argument against an Opposition which seems to have half a dozen different ideas about how it might do something if ever its slim hope comes to fruition and it gets back to the government benches.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill simply reflects the Opposition's single-minded, ideological fascination with destroying trade unions. The Opposition-it is probably on the other side of this House because it does have this view-cannot see that any useful activities are carried out by the trade union movement, so its solution to these problems is to go out and crush them. The Opposition would implement any form of legislation which would destroy the trade union movement. Of course all of the legislation that the coalition has ever implemented-and this legislation in particular-has proved to be absolutely ineffectual. We heard the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) say how important it was for a government to have an effective arsenal. If we look at the record of the CE(EP) legislation we find, if we study each of the case histories where the previous Government applied it, that the Act in almost every case did not resolve the dispute. It exacerbated the dispute, extended it, and made it much more difficult to find a resolution.

At the time I was a union official in a Public Service organisation, the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association, to which the honourable member for Tangney referred. I suppose the ATEA can take some credit for the previous Government having implemented the CE(EP) Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you proud of it?

—I think the honourable member asked whether I am proud of it. Obviously I am not necessarily proud that the Government had to stoop to some draconian legislation to resolve industrial disputation. It showed that the previous Government, like the current Opposition, was incapable of handling industrial disputes in a manner which would lead to a resolution. Its only response to disputation was to try to crush the opposition extended rather than resolve the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The CE(EP) legislation did nothing to resolve disputation. I can say, as an official, that we went through the farcical situation of finding that statutory bodies and Public Service departments were forbidden to negotiate, which is part of the process of resolving disputation. The previous Liberal Government directed that they extend disputes by immediately implementing the CE(EP) legislation and causing stand-downs. We went through the farcical situation of seeing people queued up by management so that the Government could see the dispute extended to such an extent that it was widespread.

That the public was inconvenienced in many of those disputes was the fault of the Government because it deliberately set about creating that situation. Prior to the CE(EP) legislation many of the Public Service organisations were fairly inactive in industrial disputation. Most of them had been through situations in which they had negotiated some form of compromise with the government of the day. Any disputation they embarked on was of a minor nature. One of the previous speakers said that most public servants supported the CE(EP) Act. When that legislation was first introduced it resulted in the greatest attendances seen at public meetings organised by the Public Service unions. Public servants were outraged by the fact that many of them could be roped into a dispute when they actually had no bans in place at all. In fact, in many instances it politicised the Public Service unions. Much of the industrial action taking place now probably would never have occurred if the CE(EP) legislation had not politicised those unions. The extent of disputation can be directly related to the application of the CE(EP) Act.

This Government is about proper industrial relations; it is about resolving issues and doing so in a way that causes the least amount of inconvenience to the community and reduces the amount of industrial disputation. The provisions have always existed for governments to resolve disputes by the use of the arbitration system itself. Almost inevitably any dispute between two parties is resolved not by some punitive action but by consultative process which leads to some mutual agreement. Where that cannot be achieved one goes through the arbitration system and obtains an arbitrated result. But the CE(EP) Act tried to get away from the initial process of consultancy. It did not allow for that consultative process to be carried out properly and the previous Government used it as a bludgeoning weapon to try to crush the unions of the day. All it did was exacerbate disputes, as I said before. We now have a situation where, following the removal of the Act, we can enter into normal discussions and negotiations with the unions, and they do not feel that they are under constant threat. That allows for the proper resolution of disputes and we believe it is a much more effective way of achieving such resolution.

The previous Government, the current Opposition, obviously has learnt nothing during the time that it has been in opposition or from the personal experiences of honourable members opposite. They would have had a look at the CE(EP) Act itself, at what happened when the bans were introduced and they were applying the CE(EP) Act. One would have thought that they would have gone away with that experience and thought about it. It is obvious that they have not, and it all comes back to this blinkered ideological view that they have. It is obvious that they do not understand industrial relations, and they do not understand human relations. It is highly unlikely that, if ever they had the opportunity to sit again on the benches on this side, which I very much doubt, they would be in the position of really being able to contain industrial relations problems in Australia.

The fact that many disputes took place towards the latter part of the previous Government's term was due directly to its policies. Its wages and economic policies were such that it forced many of the trade unions-not just the Public Service unions but those out in private enterprise-into a disputation situation. When private sector people were obtaining benefits in the market place and the Government of the day was saying that the market place should prevail, it is no wonder that public servants were saying that they also had to participate in that activity. But the then Government did not see that as a fit way for public servants to go. The honourable member for Tangney said that we needed the CE(EP) legislation because we want to stop industrial action. He then went on to talk about illegal industrial action. We know that the Opposition's view is that any industrial action is illegal. That is the way it perceives it, and it perceives that you can stop something like that by taking legal action. The realities are that legal action has not resolved any dispute, and I say again that it has to be resolved by consultation between the parties.

I remember very vividly one of the very large disputes that I was involved in. When we were before the arbitrator the employer, Telecom Australia, attempted to show that a dispute existed. We were able to point out to the arbitrator that there was no dispute because we had not even been able to discuss the matter with Telecom because it was under the direction of the Government not to discuss, negotiate or talk in any way on the issue. Telecom was forced to apply the CE(EP) provisions and so the issue, the disputation and the disagreement, was extended. So we were not just arguing any longer about an industrial matter, which could have been resolved by negotiation; we were faced with having to extend our claim to ensure that those who had been stood down under the CE(EP) provisions were taken care of, were reinstated with all of their entitlements given back to them. That is exactly what happened at the end, but it became a much more diffcult task for us to resolve those things because of the heavy-handedness of a government which had no comprehension at all of industrial disputation and how to resolve it. It had made a mess of the economy, it had made a mess of wages policy and it had made a mess of industrial relations in Australia, and in order to try to contain its problems it thought it could apply the heavy hand of the law.

This Government has shown in its period of office that the alternative way achieves results. By direct negotiations with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and by achieving a social package in the accord we have minimised to a great degree the disputation which exists in Australia today. We can look proudly at that record and see how much industrial disputation in Australia has been reduced. The economy is running along well, and we have the confidence of the business people because we have shown, in terms of being able to get agreements with the trade union movement and being able to restrain wage demand and other such things, that we can achieve our goals. The Opposition has not shown that. Not only has it shown that in the area of economics it cannot make up its mind what it wants to do, that it does not know which way it is are going to go, but it cannot make up its mind in the area of industrial relations, either. On the one hand, Opposition members argue that they want a free market and say that they are going to do away with the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission but, on the other hand, they change their minds as soon as they change their shadow Minister.

Now they are not going to have an arbitration court or too much of a free market, because maybe it does not work and there are lots of problems with it. The proposed Bill would be a disaster because it would set us back. It is a draconian Bill which takes away the freedom of unionists to take action to protect their rights. It does not do anything to enhance the industrial relations situation in Australia. We certainly would not entertain any support for legislation of this nature.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If there should perchance have been anybody in Australia who still had some lingering doubts as to this Government's total enslavement to the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson), in his own small way, would have dispelled those doubts. For not once, in a lengthy expose of this Government's attempts to deal with the trade union movement to minimise industrial relations problems, did he mention employers. We have had some 15 minutes of how his Government engages in negotiation and consultation directly with the ACTU and the trade unions. Not once was any employer body mentioned. I urge the Government to consider, at least, the fact that good industrial relations involve a tripartite relationship between government, unions and employers. Not one of those bodies can be excluded, and yet we have had a history of this Government excluding employer representatives in its sweetheart deals with the ACTU.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack), in introducing his excellent private member's Bill, the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Bill, on behalf of the Opposition, seeks to give effect to the wishes of the overwhelming majority of Australians. The Bill is drafted so as to restore accountability to those public servants engaged in wrongful and unlawful industrial action. In doing so the Bill protects the public interest. The public have rights, and some of those rights are constantly ignored by some sections of the Public Service.

This legislation was first introduced by the previous coalition Government in August 1977, and it was repealed by this ACTU-dominated Labor Government in November 1983. It is worth while to consider the events leading up to its introduction in August 1977. At that time, Australia had suffered under a prolonged and disastrous air traffic controller strike, which not only inconvenienced in a personal sense tens of thousands of Australians, but cost this country dearly in economic terms. This legislation was introduced as the notorious postal dispute entered its third week-a postal dispute in which the honourable member for Aston proudly declared his part. That-at the risk of stating the obvious-was a cruel and ineffective dispute which did not achieve its objectives and served only to again inconvenience, often irreconcilably, many members of the public, to the extent that there was a back-up of some four million letters and articles. Where is the public right and the public interest in those circumstances?

I believe, as do members of the Opposition, that this Bill with its far reaching powers of suspension, standdown and dismissal of public servants, is necessary to enable the Government to react quickly and responsibly to disputes which affect the public interest. The public interest needs to be protected in the fields of health, transport, communications and social security.

This Bill, essentially, empowers the Public Service Board to suspend or ultimately dismiss Commonwealth employees engaged in industrial action. It also empowers the Public Service Board to stand down those Commonwealth employees not directly involved in the dispute but who cannot fulfil their responsibilities or cannot be employed. The Bill allows the Government to bypass the traditional avenues of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and does not leave redress to an employee-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is now 1.45 p.m. In accordance with standing order 109 as amended for this session, the debate on the motion for the second reading of the Bill is interrupted.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the time for the discussion of Notice No. 1, General Business, be extended until 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for extending my time in such a fashion. As I was saying, the Bill permits the Government to bypass to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and to suspend, stand down or dismiss employees who fail to adhere to work directives. Interestingly, there were a number of instances of public support for this piece of legislation-none less to the interests of the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) than Australia Post. Australia Post made a submission to the Prices Surveillance Authority late last year for an increase in postal rates, but it was rejected by the Authority. In handing down its report, the Prices Surveillance Authority made some scathing criticism of the poor performance of Australia Post, but that is another story, Minister. More importantly, Australia Post blamed the repeal of the `no work as directed, no pay' legislation, as incorporated in this Bill, for making mail services more vulnerable to union work bans and hence more costly to the consumer. So Australia Post is very clear on its commitment to this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the problems for Australia Post is, of course, that it is empowered to dismiss workers who strike under the Postal Services Act. However, those members of the unions of which the honourable member for Aston so proudly declares his leadership get around that by engaging in selective bans and disruptions of that nature. For instance, the famous five-minute ban was engaged in as a common practice before the coalition Government's introduction of the Act on many occasions. When the van arrives to unload the mail, there is a five-minute ban which prevents postal workers from unloading that van. They go back to work, of course, soon after; but the mail mounts up. So unless we have legislation in this form, public servants can get around existing legislation and engage in selective bans.

It is obvious to members of the Opposition, as it would be to all fair minded Australians, that legislation like this would be invoked only on the most serious occasions when the public interest is indisputably being harmed. The present Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), who was shadow Minister when this legislation was introduced initially in August 1977, said this:
What this legislation enables is for the employing authority to arbitrarily decide that it will impose this penalty forthwith.

The penalty being, of course, standing down, dismissal or suspension. That is it in a nutshell. I agree. That is exactly the power conferred on government. But governments are elected and public servants are not. When public servants have the provision of services within their sphere of responsibility and obviously engage in industrial action which abrogates that responsibility, a duly elected government is compelled to act.

This legislation would be invoked only as a final step, and not a step taken lightly. As the honourable member for Tangney has stressed, there is not only a need for more effective powers, as contained in this Bill, but there is also recognition of the very fine service given by a great majority of public servants.

It goes without saying that there are many public servants who would support the introduction and invoking of the powers contained in this Bill so as to protect them from the more militant industrial actions that are undertaken by a number of unrepresentative union leaders or union cells. This Bill is introduced at a time when there is a significant change in the mood of industrial relations in this country. That mood is clearly against the unrestricted powers that have been gained by trade unions over the years and accelerated under this Government.

Two significant events have convinced me and convinced the Opposition that the Australian public want tough, strong and decisive action by governments when the public interest is so threatened as has occurred on a number of occasions in recent times. The first example is the Electrical Trades Union dispute in Queensland, where the Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, showed that a duly elected State government will not bow to a small strident minority; and the second example is the Mudginberri dispute in the Northern Territory. This is a mood which has even been recognised by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. On 31 July, he addressed a forum in Sydney in regard to the recently issued report of the Hancock Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems, which concluded, as if we did not already know, that existing sanctions in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act were virtually a dead letter. The Minister said:
The union movement has to decide whether it is prepared to argue for a system where there are absolutely no effective sanctions against industrial activity no matter how outrageous.
In short, would the trade union movement propose supporting a system where anything goes?

The Minister himself, following on from the actions taken by Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, by the National Farmers Federation, and by the Opposition in both the ETU and the Mudginberri disputes, recognised that no union has an unfettered, an unbridled right to withdraw its labour or engage in selective industrial disputes which will harm the competitiveness of this country and bring injury to innocent third parties. Any government which does not, firstly, acknowledge the mood of the Australian people in relation to unbridled union power and, secondly, does not adhere to its responsibilites to ensure the smooth running of Public Service functions, will not enjoy the people's confidence. For that reason, I have no doubt whatsoever that, as this Government goes further down the drain of its subservience to the ACTU, the Australian people will turn to the Opposition for the decisive and consistent strength needed, as shown in this Bill, to quash unreasonable and excessive union power.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch Mr G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is no wonder Opposition members got the Budget deficit wrong almost by double; they get their speaking time wrong almost by double as well. I thank the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) for his contribution. The Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Bill, the Shack shackling of public servants, is a return to the darkest years of the Howard-Fraserism ideology. It is confused in its own ideology and it is hypocritical in the context of any policy consistency of the Opposition. This legislation seeks to shackle public servants like convicts in 1788. At the very bottom line, like the Opposition's use of the Mudginberri dispute and the Queensland power dispute, this legislation is a cover, a cloak, at the very least an admission, that after two and a half years in opposition and three Opposition spokesmen later, and before that seven years in government and countless numbers of Ministers, the Liberal and National parties still do not have a wages policy. That is a fact. It is a return to the past of the Fraser-Howard years. Confrontation is an end in itself. Confrontation is a political tool deliberately contrived and acknowledged as such-and confrontation at the expense of every Australian. This legislation seeks to make every public servant in Australia a second-class citizen. It is always the view of the Liberal and National parties that public servants are second-class workers, and second-class citizens. It is a handy resource to have around their branch meetings and Federal councils-to push the line of a large, lazy bureaucracy, overpaid and hungry for power, and capable of being blamed for every mistake ever made.

SPEECH.PARA: But what of the rule of law that the Liberal and National parties always tout yet always seem to be breaking? Here, again, they are breaking their own belief, it would seem, in the rule of law, because this is a duplicitous policy. They are seeking two rules of law, one law for every employee in the private sector and one law for every employee in the public sector. That is, of course, if we put aside for one moment the present Opposition spokesman on employment and industrial relations and his position, as announced last week, where some people will be in the arbitration system and some people will be out-`We will decide about that later'. But there are two rules of law. Where do they stand? What about their so-called striving for freedom in the work-place and the right to choose? How many times have we heard them talk about the right to choose for employees in the private sector?

This Bill, if passed, would amount to the greatest legislated control over individuals in the work-place ever put through this place. How about providing an example? This flies in the face of the whole basis of the Opposition's dry policies. If this Government were to follow the example of this legislation in the private sector, there would be screams of `Socialism' and `Government control' and the rest of the contrived contortions through which Opposition members go every week. What about the call for less government? This legislation would impose the greatest control by any government over any employee in Australia. Notwithstanding that, the hypocrisy of it is still touted by every member on the other side.

The Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act was introduced in haste in 1977 but was not brought into operation until 1979. The Act was first invoked in 1979 and then eight times in 1981-82, when the present Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown), was the Minister. This Bill is not only a return to the same failed policies; it is the same failed Minister. The CE(EP) Act was used on each occasion under ministerial direction. During CE(EP) applications in 1981-82 there was no evidence shown that the Act had been effective in minimising industrial action or in bringing that action to an end swiftly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite the opposite.

—Quite the contrary, as the honourable member for Port Adelaide has stressed. On a number of occasions the use of the Act had the effect of extending a dispute and causing greater disruption to the public. Let there be no doubt that this legislation gives too much arbitrary power to the executive government to deal with Commonwealth employees. That is in sharp contrast to what happened in the private sector. The Opposition is contradictory in the extreme in its policies on employment and industrial relations. On the one hand, Opposition members want deregulation of the labour market in the sense that they want to openly confront themselves with the unions by diminishing the role of the conciliation and arbitration system; and, on the other hand, they want to further regulate the labour market by giving more power to the executive government to dictate employment conditions. We do not need another CE(EP) Act. We never needed it in 1980, 1981 and 1982, and we certainly do not need it now.

SPEECH.PARA: It might interest the House to note that the original Act of 1977 was examined by the International Labour Organisation's governing body Committee on Freedom of Association in 1978, following a complaint by the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association. After noting several points about it, the committee of the ILO was highly critical of the Act on a number of important grounds, including the virtually unlimited capacity to apply the Act to any Commonwealth employee, the lack of any opportunity for an employee, to have recourse to an independent adjudicator, the serious risk that the Act would be used before existing procedures for settlement were exhausted, and that punitive sanctions would impede harmonious industrial relations.

In the short time available, let me conclude by saying this: Like Opposition members' economic policies, like the rest of their industrial policies, like their foreign policies, like so much that has been brought out by the new dry Right, the new Rajneesh Right opposite us, this Bill is hypocritical. It is hypocritical in the extreme and it is dangerous. A return to those years would endanger this nation to the industrial chaos that we went through for too long. We should throw this Bill out of the House and have no more of this confrontation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m, in accordance with standing order 104, as amended for this session, the time allotted for precedence for General Business has expired.
