—Mr Speaker, I wish to advise the House that the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley)-I know that he will be missed by his shadow-will be absent until later this afternoon viewing the naval exercise Coral Sea. The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown), as Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, will answer questions for Mr Beazley.

—I ask the Prime Minister: Now that it has been revealed that his Department had a copy of Mr Reid's letter to Dr Armstrong of 12 October 1979, setting out the latter's terms of employment, from the time the Prime Minister assumed ministerial responsibility for the Australian Bicentennial Authority, how does the Prime Minister justify his failure to examine the contents of this letter before the Authority's $500,000 payout to Dr Armstrong? Would the Prime Minister not agree that the most basic of inquiries which he should have made would have revealed the existence of that letter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition seems destined to never learn. But that is to our advantage and not to his. Let me read to the House the note that I have received from the Acting Secretary of my Department this day on the matter raised by the Leader of the Opposition. It is to me, Prime Minister. The heading of the note is `Letter of appointment of Dr Armstrong as Chief Executive of the Australian Bicentennial Authority'. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: I deeply regret that the Department has been responsible for your being-
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest that the Prime Minister resume his seat. It is useless trying to carry on in view of these sorts of organised interjections. I now call the Prime Minister.

—Mr Speaker, it will be recalled that yesterday the Leader of the Opposition in his totally pathetic attempt to censure me included amongst those weak arguments the pro- position that here was a Prime Minister who did not consult his Department-this Prime Minister was too proud, too arrogant to consult. When I say that I consulted and I get advice from the Department, all we can get from this feeble minded, temporary Leader of the Opposition is a hee haw. I will read to the House the advice that I have received from the Department, something that yesterday he condemned me for not doing. This is the advice I received and I repeat the advice:

ANSWER.PARA: I deeply regret that the Department has been responsible for your being incorrectly and incompletely advised on the availability on departmental files of documentation on Dr Armstrong's appointment as Chief Executive of the Australian Bicentennial Authority.

We consistently advised you that we had been unable to obtain from the ABA, prior to Mr Reid's resignation, a copy of the contract under which Dr Armstrong was employed by the Australian Bicentennial Authority. In the period following the transfer of responsibility for the Bicentennial Authority to your portfolio, a number of requests, including some at the request of your staff, were made to the Authority for details of terms and conditions of employment of senior ABA staff and information was provided by the Authority on levels of salary and allowances and other elements in the remuneration packages of senior staff.
It goes on:

We did not, however, pursue requests from your office for copies of the specific contracts under which Dr Armstrong and other senior staff were employed, because we had been given to understand by the Authority that these contracts were regarded as being of a private nature between the Authority and its individual senior staff.

Following oral advice on 27 September, after Mr Reid's resignation, from an officer of the ABA that a copy of the Letter of Appointment of Dr Armstrong had been sent to the Department of Administrative Services with Board agenda papers in 1980, a search of the 800-odd files inherited from the Department of Home Affairs was initiated. Copies of this document were located on files in the Department on 1 October and the officer in charge of the Bicentennial Branch became aware of this on 8 October. Neither you nor your office were informed that these papers had been located on the Department's files until this morning.

That is signed by Mr Visbord, the Acting Secretary of the Department, and it confirms completely the total accuracy of the position that I have put to this Parliament. As distinct from those on the other side of the House, we tell the truth in these matters and do not seek to dissemble and deliberately to misrepresent as has characterised the whole of the Opposition's miserable performance in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the Prime Minister's answer I had occasion to refer to `organised interjections'. On reflection I think that was improper because it does involve the suggestion of improper conduct. Perhaps I should have used the term `concerted'.
—Spontaneous.
—`Concerted' I think is the proper word.
—I ask the Prime Minister a question. Are the Government's economic policies producing jobs at the rate promised when the Government was elected to office?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly, all those on this side of the House and the overwhelming majority of Australians will be thoroughly pleased with the further evidence contained in this morning's statistics as to the continuing strong growth in employment in this country. The Statistician's preliminary labour force statistics for September that were released this morning are, of course, very encouraging. They show a very sharp rise in employment and falls in both the level and the rate of unemployment despite a quite significant increase in the participation rate. The latest employment figures bring now to 487,200 the increase in employment since April 1983.

ANSWER.PARA: It is quite clear that we are now on the verge of achieving a half a million new jobs that I promised the people of Australia would be achieved in three years from the time of the summit. The unemployment rate decreased to 8.1 per cent from 8.3 per cent and from 10.2 per cent in April 1983, and this was the lowest level since September 1982. It is particularly notable that, among those seeking full time work, the level of unemployment fell in September below 500,000 to 494,000. This is the first time since October 1982 that we have seen that category fall below half a million. In summary, the labour market in this country is continuing to improve very solidly. It is interesting to note that the figures indicate that employment has grown by around 1.5 per cent in three months or, in fact, more than half the Budget forecast growth for the whole of 1985-86.

If we are to have a proper appreciation of the alternatives facing this country in terms of economic management and employment growth, it is informing to look at the observations of the Leader of the Opposition. Not being satisfied when he was Treasurer with inflicting upon this economy and upon the people of Australia the greatest damage in the history of this country, he then became the professional doomsayer of the Opposition when he was cast properly into that lot by the decision of the people in March 1983. I ask that the people of Australia should listen to and understand the observations, the predictions and the economic analysis of this Leader of the Opposition.
What did he have to say on 3 May 1983? He said:
The outcome must unavoidably be that more tens of thousands of Australians will be thrown out of work.

That was his prediction at the beginning of 1983. Then we had the indication that he had learned nothing from his disastrous time in office. What was his prescription for what should happen? I will quote what he had to say on 20 September 1983. These are his words:
A policy of fighting inflation first. It remains, in my view, the only effective method of tackling unemployment on a permanent basis.

Having pursued that miserably unsatisfactory and disastrous policy for five years, he could not learn. As he saw the emergence of the success of the policies of this Government, he said: `No, you are wrong. What you must do is fight inflation first'. He brought the magnificent success of that policy to the country of Australia by bringing about double digit inflation. That is how successful the former Government was at fighting inflation first. But it managed to accompany that with double digit unemployment simultaneously for the first time ever. This is what the Leader of the Opposition had to say on 20 September. This is relevant now to what we have achieved-487,000 new jobs. I quote his words of 20 September, when he said:
The election promise of 500,000 new jobs over three years is now joining the rest of Mr Hawke's empty promises on the scrapheap.

That was his observation. He thought that we would not get half a million new jobs and that that policy would go on to the scrapheap. Finally, in analysing the Leader of the Opposition on this subject, I refer once again to what he had to say in this place on 7 December 1983. The honourable member for Kooyong should take out a writ against the Leader of the Opposition because, as the former Leader of the Opposition will see, the current Leader of the Opposition has been grossly guilty of plagiarism. What the current Leader of the Opposition had to say is very instructive. This was his analysis:
I regard a prices and incomes accord as an absolute fraud on the Australian community. I think that all we have to do is give the prices and incomes accord time to fail.
These are the current Leader of the Opposition's words, which I recommend to the former Leader of the Opposition as to whether he should think about taking out a writ against him for plagiarism:
As surely as day follows night, the prices and incomes accord in this community will fail.

That shows that the current Leader of the Opposition, not being satisfied with inflicting the most savage disaster on the people of this country-160,000 jobs disappeared in the 12 months before we came to office-then set about, in his role as economic spokesman for the Opposition, trying to undermine the very process by which this Government has turned around the employment situation in this country. I say to the Leader of the Opposition that he was a miserable failure in government: He is chaotically incompetent in opposition. All I can say is that the honourable member for Kooyong is looking good and, surprisingly, even the honourable member for Denison, the covetous pretender, is starting to look good by comparison.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister a question which is supplementary to the previous question I asked him. I refer the Prime Minister to the answer he gave to my first question. I specifically ask the Prime Minister: Did he request his Department to give advice on the contract between the Australian Bicentennial Authority and Dr Armstrong between 15 August and 30 August, the latter being the date of the payout to Dr Armstrong? Secondly, did he, between those two dates, inform his Department of the arrangements he made with Mr Reid regarding the resignation of Dr Armstrong?
—I have indicated in the replies I have given that queries were made of the ABA. My Department formed the impression, on the basis of the replies it had been given-
—But did you ask it?

—If the Leader of the Opposition will contain himself, he will get his answer. My Department formed the impression, on the basis of the replies it had been given that the position, which had been put and which it understood, was that, because these documents were in the nature of personal documents between the Authority and those involved, the Department would not be given them. Therefore, by the time I came to consider this matter from 15 August, I was proceeding on the basis particularly of the conversation I had with Mr Reid on 19 August. I remind this House again that that conversation was confirmed by Mr Reid on these occasions: 10 September; 24 September, to the Authority when Mr Reid confirmed that the account which I had given in this House was an accurate statement; and again talking with me on 26 September. I acted, therefore, on the basis of all the information given to me which I will repeat again. It gives me no pleasure to have to repeat it again. I repeat that when I was acting on this matter I acted on the basis that what was being conveyed to me by Mr Reid put the position accurately, and I responded accordingly.
—I ask the Minister for Housing and Construction: What effect will the Government's tax reform measures have on the availability of private rental accommodation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I take the opportunity to refute some claims made publicly by a minority section of the real estate market that the Government's action in quarantining negative gearing and in the introduction of a prospective capital gains tax could have adverse effects on rents and current investments in the private rental market or perhaps on the level of future investment in the private residential rental market. I do not believe that those claims are correct. I believe that those claims have no validity. They certainly should not have any validity if the Government's changes are properly understood.

ANSWER.PARA: Firstly, the quarantining of negative gearing and a capital gains tax are completely prospective from 17 July and 20 September respectively. So, there should not be any effect whatsoever on rents for property which was held before those dates. As for the future, if this Government perceives that it needs increased investment in residential rental property, we will do that through justifiable incentives and not through encouraging tax shelters, as, of course, occurred under the former Government. I stress that in the encouragement of those tax shelters by the former Government it was the ordinary taxpayer, the ordinary worker, who, in fact, paid for those tax shelters.

Yes, we have quarantined negative gearing for investment in residential rental property, but we have also introduced a 4 per cent straight line depreciation allowance on new buildings for residential rental purposes. I make it clear that the current Opposition, as a government, supported tax shelters, and this Government supports legitimate investment allowances in the rental investment industry.

The figures I would now like to table for the benefit of honourable members are important because they show the effect of computer modelling of the Government's changes regarding the quarantining of negative gearing, the introduction of the straight line investment allowance and the effect of a prospective capitals gains tax. That all boils down to the fact that an investor who wants to invest a legitimate level of investor equity in a property and who can receive a moderate level of appreciation over time will still do very well from investment in the private rental market, after property realisation. The figures stack up thus: If there is a rate of real property appreciation of 2 per cent over a period and the investor has a 50 per cent equity level, he can still get over time an after tax return of 13.4 per cent from his investment.

That is the result of these tax changes. I think that compares well with the after tax returns from investment in other areas, particularly from some financial institutions. Secondly, there is no reason whatsoever for the unjustified attacks by certain sections of the real estate industry on the Government's tax changes. For the benefit of the House I will table the figures with respect to the changes that have been provided by extensive computer modelling, undertaken by the Department of Housing and Construction.

TALK.START.PARA: —I again ask the Prime Minister: On what date did he first consult his Department, or any other section of the Government, regarding the proposed retirement of Dr Armstrong?
—I have covered this question extensively in answers given in this place. I have nothing to add to what I have said.

—Will the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce indicate whether the Government is concerned with the accumulation of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd shares by Robert Holmes a'Court's Bell Group? In particular, is this likely to have any effect on the steel plan agreement established between the Government, BHP and the unions regarding the reinvestment of funds into the steel industry?
—The Government is monitoring the BHP situation closely. I understand from the honourable member for Grey that concern has been expressed by steel workers-
—Are you going to start buying some shares?
—Order! The honourable member for Ryan persists. If he keeps on persisting the Minister might even produce some out of his pockets. I call the Minister.

—Concern has been expressed by steel workers in the honourable member for Grey's electorate that a change in BHP's ownership might change their employment prospects. The Government has no reason to believe at this stage that if control of BHP changes the agreement made by BHP, the Government and the unions under the steel industry plan will not be adhered to or that BHP's plans for continuing investment in the steel industry will not go ahead.

—I direct my question to the Prime Minister and I hope that his selective amnesia will not prevent him from answering this question. Is it a fact that the Solicitor-General's opinion fails to support one of the reasons the Prime Minister has given for sacking Mr Reid, namely, that the settlement of the Australian Bicentennial Authority with Dr Armstrong was-to quote the Prime Minister-`at least a tax minimisation'? In light of the Solicitor-General's finding in paragraph 46 of his opinion, does the Prime Minister still maintain, as he did in the House this week, that the only motive for the composition of the settlement was tax minimisation?

—The reasons which moved me to ask for, and receive, the resignation of Mr Reid stand as I gave them to the House. As this question of the impact of the arrangements that were made in regard to Dr Armstrong is a matter for the Bicentennial Authority to handle-it is taking advice as to whether action needs to be taken-it would be quite inappropriate for me to make any comment.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industry and relates to the meat industry. I preface my question by saying that 400 people in my electorate work in a very efficient abattoir. Is the Minister aware of a strike which is taking place today in South Australia and the Northern Territory by members of the Meat Inspectors Association? What is the reason for this strike? What are its effects, including animal welfare aspects, and what is the Government's attitude to it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I am aware that members of the Meat Inspectors Association are today on strike in South Australia and the Northern Territory. I have also now been informed that meat inspectors are planning to strike tomorrow in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland and in Western Australia on Monday. I understand that the strike has been called as a protest against the non-payment by my Department of Primary Industry of three inspectors in relation to their failure to attend for duty during a dispute between the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union and the management of Mudginberri abattoir, an abattoir in the Northern Territory.
—We have heard of it.

—That is good. The inspectors had been directed to report for duty. They refused to do so and thus were deemed to be on strike. The irresponsible action taken by the MIA clearly puts to rest the baseless claims by livestock producers that I have acquiesced to union demands in respect of the Mudginberri dispute. Mr McLachlan of the National Farmers Federation sent a letter to the Prime Minister stating:

ANSWER.PARA: We reject the view that provision of inspection services would lead to a national meat industry strike.

We now have a national meat industry strike. It is this sort of industrial action that the Government has persistently attempted to avoid for it has the potential to damage the Australian meat industry substantially. The Government took that attitude throughout the Mudginberri dispute. The Government supports the right of any employee to strike. But let me make it very clear that the Government does not support the payment of such persons while they are on strike. Further, the Government does not support irresponsible use by any employee organisation of the right to strike. The Government firmly believes that the organisation should negotiate and use the due processes of conciliation and arbitration.

I urge the MIA to cease its strike action which not only will adversely affect the domestic and export meat industries-of course it will affect employment-but also may cause undue cruelty to animals scheduled for slaughter. The honourable member asked about the animal welfare aspects. In South Australia there are milk lambs in pens which are ready to be slaughtered and, of course, their condition will deteriorate rapidly in today's forecast high temperatures. So there is a real animal welfare concern.

This morning I spoke to Mr Simon Crean, the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, in an attempt to effect a speedy resolution to this totally inadequate situation. I am fully sympathetic with the representations I have received in respect of this matter from the Minister of Agriculture in South Australia, Mr Frank Blevins, the Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia, the Australian Meat Exporters Federal Council and the Country Meatworks Association of New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Treasurer aware that quarantining farm losses discriminates against agriculture when compared with negative gearing on rental properties which will apply only to investments from 18 July 1985? Does he agree that the quarantining provisions in respect of rural farm losses applies to existing investments and thus has a retrospective effect in respect of farm property investments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has covered that position in the arrangements because it is possible that the quarantining which will now exist in respect of agriculture can be set against the previous five years income and that losses which have applied before the 1986-87 income year can be brought to book. In other words, any existing or deferred loss which is taken after these measures are introduced will be brought to account. I noticed a remark by the Leader of the Opposition during the week. I think he probably failed to understand that point. Existing losses, that is, losses pre-1986-87 and any losses which have been stored up, can be offset in the future. Any losses which are incurred after the introduction of this measure can be written off against farm income for the previous five years.

ANSWER.PARA: The other thing I should say is that there is also a very great benefit in the farm sector in respect of averaging. At the moment under the averaging provisions only $5,000 of non-farm income is included, whereas under this arrangement $15,000 of non-farm income will be included, which will make a great difference to the great majority of farmers. Of course, all farmers will benefit from the reduction in marginal tax rates. All farmers will benefit from the fact that the 60 per cent rate will go down to 49 per cent, and the 46 per cent rate to 40 per cent. A lot of farmers do not have any off-farm income, in which case they are not affected. People who are farming without additional income will not be affected. Of course, there is the other offsets test. Up to full loss offsets are available on non-farm incomes of up to $15,000 and partial loss offsets on incomes up to $30,000. So we have treated the farm community very fairly.

Over time, Pitt Street farming has been a loophole in the tax system. It has been a tax shelter. With the eradication of all other shelters in the system, or as many as the Government can find, this type of shelter would have been worked to death by people with substantial non-farm incomes. The effect of this over the period has been to drive up the value of rural land in some places, which has substantially disadvantaged the farm community. Farmers have had to purchase properties with big mortgages occasioned by the rise in rural values brought about because so much has been able to be negatively geared and offset against another non-farm income. So the balance of measures protect the farm community. The Deputy Leader of the National Party should understand that existing losses can be stored. Losses can be stored indefinitely against the earnings of the farm.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs been drawn to full page advertisements by the Northern Territory Government regarding Ayers Rock? Can he inform the House whether the advertisement is a fair representation of the issues involved in the recognition of the title to Uluru?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the advertisements sponsored by the Northern Territory Government. They are grossly misleading. They are grave distortions of the facts and I believe they are calculated to arouse racial tensions throughout the Australian community. Let us look at a couple of the propositions in these advertisements that are factually incorrect. It is asserted that Uluru National Park will be handed over to fewer than 100 Australians. The advertisement says that all Australians visiting the rock will have to pay a fee to see it. Let us take both those propositions as representing the truth as the Northern Territory Government sees it. The fact is that the rock is not being handed over to any one Australian. It is being handed over to a lands trust which will handle the title for and on behalf of all the indigenous traditional owners of Uluru. That is the first gross distortion of fact. The second is the implication that as a result of this decision Australians will now have to pay to see Uluru. How is it that the Northern Territory Government does not seem to know that a fee has been paid by visitors to the rock for the last 25 years?

ANSWER.PARA: I will not dwell on the morality of these mischievous and misleading advertisements. It is all very well for Mr Tuxworth to act like a mischievous prophet, hawking himself around Australia and making all sorts of false assertions. I want to direct this House to the reactions of the people of the Territory to this campaign. I can do no better than to go to newspapers which could not be described in any way by anybody in this House as traditional supporters of this Government. The mid-week Territorian of 9 October 1855-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, 1985. I was thinking of the attitudes and responses of the gentlemen opposite. What is interesting is the uniform approach that has been taken by all newspapers in the Territory. The Territorian editorial states:

ANSWER.PARA: In boycotting the handover of Uluru National Park the Territory Government has again unhesitantly pitted one racial group against another . . . The Territory Government has selfishly decided to boycott the handing over of Ayers Rock to Aborigines.
I invite the Leader of the Opposition to ponder this next sentence:

The handing over is nothing more than a show of respect to a race that has lived in Central Australia thousands of years before the arrival of the first European. The CLP may have won an election on the Ayers Rock issue. But that is no justification for the Territory boycotting an event that is an immense symbolic gesture to a people who only 20 years ago were given the right to vote.

In a mid-week poll conducted on the streets one cannot say that any poll of that kind is necessarily conclusive, but it is interesting 30 people were questioned in Alice Springs, the majority of whom identified themselves as Country Liberal Party voters. Eleven agreed with the boycott decision, and the rest supported the handover. The Northern Territory News is not a newspaper which has ever been sympathetic to the Prime Minsiter or this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You couldn't lie straight in bed.
—It is important that the honourable member for the Northern Territory should identify himself because he has not been here for most of the week. We are pleased to see him back.
—Come back up to the Territory. You are worth 500 votes to me every time you go up there.

—I have been told that he is spending most of his time in Queensland looking for a seat. Perhaps he has just been in Queensland handing back the $20,000 legal fee he should never have received. The editorial headline in the Northern Territory News-it is not my headline-describes Mr Tuxworth's cavorting around the capital cities of Australia as a `pointless crusade'. The editorial states:

ANSWER.PARA: Rhetoric by Mr Tuxworth and former Chief Minister, Mr Paul Everingham, about traditional ownership of Ayers Rock and the need to keep the Rock for all Australians, is a smokescreen designed for electoral gain.

A letter from Mr Everingham to Mr Hawke less than a month after winning the 1983 election, which was based on `winning back' the Rock, shows Mr Everingham proposed acknowledging Aboriginal title on the understanding the park subsequently would be leased to the Conservation Commission.
As late as August this year, Mr Tuxworth's Government was perfectly happy for Aborigines to hold Territory title to the rock.

Opposition Leader, Mr Bob Collins, could well be correct when he says Mr Tuxworth's crusade could deter tourists, who could be forgiven for believing they will find no more than a yawning hole in the ground after the handover.

I am quoting to the House the views and editorials of every newspaper in the Territory, and newspapers which, as I pointed out, traditionally do not support this Government. The Advocate's editorial comment was as follows:

. . . if Mr Tuxworth is trying to be politically damaging to Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, he would do better to restore the credibility of the Territory in the business fiascos among the Australian business community.

It is an interesting exercise for honourable members on this side of the House to be continually lectured by the Leader of the Opposition and his shadow Treasurer on the benefits of privatisation. They are so anxious to support their colleagues in the Northern Territory without any thought or regard to the rights of traditional Aboriginal people and the policy of this Government, which follows the very policy and the very philosophy of the former Prime Minister. Let it not be forgotten that during the whole period of the Fraser Government the question of the future of Uluru was constantly under consideration. The previous Prime Minister made it perfectly clear that under no circumstances would he simply hand over title to the Northern Territory Government unless he had firm guarantees about the recognition of the rights of traditional Aboriginal people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame.
—That is right, shame, shame.
—It is interesting to hear the honourable gentlemen opposite saying `Shame' when I refer to the Opposition's own previous policy and philosophy.
—You will want Tasmania next.

—There are no traditional owners in Tasmania. I ask the House to consider this: The previous Government made its policy perfectly clear and, more than that, indicated to the Northern Territory Government that it would be prepared to hand title to the Northern Territory Government on the basis of that title then going to the Aboriginal people of Uluru. That is the reality. There is a real question here which I ask the Leader of the Opposition to consider quite seriously. The action of the Governor-General in proceeding on behalf of the Commonwealth to hand over title to the Aboriginal people is of immense relevance not only to the beneficiaries but also to Aboriginal people right around Australia.
—What does Sugar Ray Robinson say? He wants you to give it back to the whites.
—Order! The honourable member for Maranoa will cease interjecting.

—Mr Speaker, my only regret is that some of the comments from the Opposition benches cannot be recorded. This exercise is of tremendous relevance to all Aboriginal people, for the following reason. It is the first occasion upon which the head of the Commonwealth is saying on behalf of the people and the Government of Australia that we recognise the traditions of Aboriginal people and their spiritual relationship to this area of land. No one Australian citizen will be disadvantaged in any way at all. There will be screams and yells from honourable gentlemen opposite as we approach our bicentennial year if any group of Aboriginal people decide not to participate in this ceremony. That will be a matter of concern to this House. I find it extraordinary, therefore, that the Leader of the Opposition and his supporters, who I do not think have thought their way through this seriously, now are prepared to support a white ban on a very serious and important event. They believe that the Northern Territory Government is entitled to say to every public servant in the Territory in respect of an event that is to take place on a weekend in their own time: `You shall not go'. I ask the Leader of the Opposition to think about the implications of that.

ANSWER.PARA: I finish on a simple note. No one Australian citizen is having any of his rights diminished under the arrangements that have been made. Those arrangements follow very much the policy adopted by the Fraser Government. Finally, the average Australian is not losing Ayers Rock; he is gaining Uluru.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. In view of the understandable and regular involvement of staff on both sides of politics in State election and by-election campaigns, can the Prime Minister assure us that no member of his Ministers' staff has been connected in any way with the matters presently under investigation relating to the Nunawading by-election?
—Certainly, to the best of my knowledge, that is the case.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs. What is the Government's assessment of the impact of recent developments in the Middle East, particularly the Israeli air strike against Palestine Liberation Organisation headquarters in Tunisia and the subsequent hijacking of an Italian cruise ship by people purporting to act on behalf of the Palestinian cause, on the prospects of achieving long term peace in the region?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As everybody will know, the Foreign Minister and the Government deplored the Israeli Air Force raid on Tunisia on 1 October and was concerned to learn that there has been a seizure, by those who were later called Palestinian terrorists, of the Achille Lauro on 7 October. It clearly shows that terrorist activity will only harden the attitude of the respective parties in the Middle East, where there has been a conflict for some lengthy period in endeavouring to obtain a peaceful settlement. Let me make it very clear that Australia supported the United Nations Security Council resolution condemning the Israeli raid. That resolution was passed on 4 October. The Government also strongly deplored the taking of the hostages aboard the Achille Lauro.
—Do we know whether anyone on the vessel was killed?
—I understand that there is a report to that effect, but I am not able to confirm it.

ANSWER.PARA: It is disturbing that action, although apparently unrelated, should be taking place when there have been very heartening signs of movement towards a comprehensive settlement in the Middle East. On 11 February, Yasser Arafat and King Hussein of Jordan agreed on what they called a framework for common action on the basis that there would be a peaceful settlement of the Palestinian problem. That in turn was based on the principle that there would be an exchanging of land for peace. The accord and the subsequent developments, particularly King Hussein's address to the United Nations on 27 September, represent encouraging developments in the search for peace, but considerable difficulties remain. The Australian Government, as always, is committed to a negotiated political settlement of the Arab-Israeli dispute. According to Security Council resolutions 242 and 338, we firmly believe that terrorism and violence are unacceptable and that in no way would they be able to achieve politcal objectives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to section 30 of the Human Rights Commission Act 1981, I present the Commission's report No. 15 entitled `The Human Rights of Australian-born Children: A Report on the Complaint of Mr and Mrs Yilmaz', together with the text of a statement relating to the report.
—Pursuant to section 35 of the Criminal Injuries Compensation Ordinance 1983, I present the annual report on the operation of the Criminal Injuries Compensation Ordinance for the year 1984-85.
—Pursuant to section 8 of the Independent Schools Loan Guarantee Act 1969, I present the independent schools loan guarantee report for 1983-84.
—For the information of honourable members, I present a fisheries agreement between the Commonwealth of Australia and the Koah Siung Fishing Boat Commercial Guild.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: ANDREW; BEALE; CHYNOWETH; HALVERSON; HAND; HAWKER; HOLDING; LLOYD; MCARTHUR; MACPHEE; O'KEEFE
PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation.
3. They know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will give speedy passage to the Flags Act Amendment Bill which provides that the Australian National Flag can only be changed by a referendum.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew,Mr Beale,Mr Chynoweth,Mr Halverson,Mr Hand,Mr Hawker,Mr Holding,Mr Lloyd,Mr McArthur,Mr Macphee and Mr O'Keefe.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. That the overwhelming majority of Australians are completely satisified with the existing Australian National Flag.

2. That we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, unless such proposed change is first voted on by the people of Australia and passed by a majority of voters in a majority of States.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and the future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of out inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum. And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Small Businesses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
they adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
the Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

any capital gains that might result when owners of small businesses finally sell the business are not ``windfall gains'' but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business to create growth and jobs;
the owners of small businesses often depend on a capital gain-which are simply deferred salaries-when they eventually sell their business to sustain them in retirement;

Your Petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman,Mr Fife,Mr McArthur and Mr Miles.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. That we are completely dissatisfied with the frequent and substantial increase in the price of petrol and diesel fuel.
2. That we are aware that these price increases have an adverse affect on the living standards of the average Australian wage earner.
3. That increases in fuel prices adds to farm costs and further reduces the average income per farmer which has already fallen to one-third of national earnings.

Your Petitioners therefore pray that the Government will immediately reduce the price of petrol by three (3) cents per litre in line with the commitment given by the now Prime Minister of Australia during the 1983 election campaign and take all possible action to prevent further increases occurring.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
1. That we are completely dissatisfied with the pricing of petrol in this country;
2. That under a Labour Government petrol prices have continued to rise excessively, with recent Government decisions adding over 8c. per litre to the price of petrol in some country areas;
3. The proposed consumption tax could lead to a further rise of 6c. per litre; and
4. The high cost of petrol discriminates against country residents who rely on their cars for essential communication and transport.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government honour the commitment given by the Prime Minister during the 1983 election campaign to reduce petrol prices by 3c. per litre.
Further we strongly urge the Government to adopt a petrol pricing policy which does not cause unnecessary rises in the cost of petrol.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Fife and Mr Hawker.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To The Honourable Speaker and Members of The House of Representatives, the Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the recent cuts announced in the Mini-Budget to Pre-schools and Day Care Services are a reversal of A.L.P. policy to make child care services available to all at an affordable cost.
Further, that the fee rises arising from the cuts will cause great hardship to the majority of families using these services.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House fully restores all Federal funding to children's services in Australia, and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Carlton,Mr Hollis and Mr Nehl.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Private Health Insurance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sayeth:
That we the undersigned are totally opposed to any taxation change which involves a tax on Health Fund contributions or benefits.

That we are already required to pay a 1 percent levy to partly finance the Medicare scheme and that we would regard any further taxation of our health insurance arrangements as unfair and unreasonable.
That therefore we urge the Government to ensure that there is no taxation on illness and no special taxation on those who seek to insure themselves against the cost of private health care.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Darling,Mr Fife and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government.

1. Unhold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognize that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection, storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognize that any system giving `property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognize that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hollis and Mr Milton.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initiative needs to be established which will work toward mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all, fulfilling employment, a sustainable society conserving natural resources and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover. By achieving these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world to follow.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
1. Create an Australian Ministry for Peace specifically devoted to peace-building and the non-violent resolution of conflict;
2. Convene a national Summit for Survival to discuss the issues of world disarmament, security and national and international co-operation;
3. Support the United Nations World disarmament Campaign by allocating the equivalent of at least 10% of our military expenditure to fund peace activities;
4. Actively assist the International Year of Peace in 1986 by initiating programs for peace education, self help development and environmental repair;
5. Develop National Employment Programs to give priority to the planting and growing of forests, food-producing trees and other crops to assist the greening of Australia.

6. Implement National Recycling Programs to reuse water and to compost all presently wasted domestic sewage-sludge and organic garbage with mineral-rich gravel dust, a by-product from rock quarries and mines, into hygienic humus, a natural fertiliser, for use in revitalising impoverished soils.
7. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hollis and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourble the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initiative needs to be established to work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all and full employment. This Initiative will help to ensure a sustainable society conserving natural resources, and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover for the needs of present and future generations. By working for these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
1. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
2. Implement action programs leading up to 1989 which will include:
a. Actively supporting the International Year of Peace in 1986 by reallocating at least 10% of our military expenditure to fund environmental repair programs.

b. Implementing National Recycling Programs to reuse water, and to compost into hygienic humus all presently wasted organic garbage and sewage-sludge mixed with fine ground powder from mineral-rich gravels and rocks, to use as a natural fertiliser in revitaliser impovrished soils;

c. Developing National Employment Programs giving priority to the planting and growing of healthy forests, food-producing trees and other crops and vegetation including environmentally sound use and reuse of water to assist the greening of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the humbled Petition of the South Australian Country Women's Association Incorporated and the Undersigned shall showeth:
The necessity to restore the concessional price of fuel in rural areas-without which there will be increased freight and production costs.
Your Petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will restore the concessional price of fuel in rural areas for the benefit of all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sugar Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

As residents of the towns of Ayr and Home Hill and surrounding districts, your petitioners do humbly pray that the Australian Government, in recognition of the present plight of the sugar industry in our region and other parts of Australia, and in recognition of the importance of the industry to the economic and social well-being of our community, provide urgent financial assistance to that industry to ensure the survival and future viability of our local economy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Compensation for Use of Private Property
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth.
That all steps be taken to prevent the continuous erosion of the rights of the holders of freehold land.

Your petitioners draw to the attention of Parliament the denigration of freehold rights as practised in N.S.W. and calls on the Parliament to enact overriding legislation to allow full and proper compensation to all Australians where Government requires the use of private property and traditional rights attached thereto.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Wild Horses
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament Assembled.
The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to have the wild horses of Queensland and the Northern Territory declared a protected species.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House set aside National Park for these horses and ensure that killing of feral animals is undertaken in a humane manner with proper legislation and enforcement.
And your petitioners in duty bound ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of State Arts Councils
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the current policies of the Community Arts Board of the Australia Council are disadvantaging rural residents with regard to access to the Arts.

Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Federal Government will allocate sufficient funds to the Australia Council specifically to ensure ongoing funding to State Arts Councils to enable those organisations to maintain access to performing and other arts activities in country areas, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that:

1. We affirm our belief that, in Jesus Christ, human sexuality is placed in the context of mutual loving relationships and therefore Christians reject any form of pornography which depicts violence against adults and/or children and the economic, physical and spiritual exploitation which is basic to hard-core pornography.
2. We urge the Parliament to prohibit the importation or production of this kind of pornography.

3. We request the Parliament to continue a public enquiry during 1985 to report on the operation of Regulation 4A of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations and the A.C.T. Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 in relation to video tapes and video discs which have been refused classification or classified ``X'' by the Film Censorship Board.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fitzory South Post Office, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
That the Fitzroy South Post Office offers an important service to the residents of South Fitzroy which cannot adequately be provided by any other post office in the surrounding area.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Fitzroy South Post Office not be closed.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the many anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions brought to its notice, the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitious and unfair Assets Test. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Military Bases in Australia and Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
As a part of the world wide campaign by women in the final year of the United Nations' Decade for Women for `equality, development and peace' (1976-1985)
and
In view of the grave possibility of nuclear catastrophe, the Union of Australian Women calls on the Australian Government to:
intensify its efforts for nuclear disarmament.
remove U.S. bases from Australian soil.
keep the Pacific and Indian Oceans nuclear free.

PETITION.TITLE: Compulsory Unionism
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of certain concerned citizens of Australia.

Respectfully showeth: that the actions of trade unions have gone beyond their traditional goals of protecting workers conditions and rates of pay and have reached the point where they are seriously affecting the economic health of the nation and the people.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray:
1. That all Governments throughout Australia acknowledge and protect the Right to Work on behalf of all Australians.
2. That the total sovereignty of individual governments be recognised as a fundamental requirement of a workable, balanced Federal system of government.
3. That all necessary steps be taken to protect the citizens of Australia from any compulsion, threat or intimidation to join any trade union.
4. That the supremacy of elected governments over the sectional interests of trade unions be recognised, and
5. That the provision of essential services be maintained, free from industrial disruption.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of we, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That the government reverse its decision to cut pre-school funding in the mini-budget.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows that there is a need to end the current discriminatory application of sales tax on confectionery and the other anomalies existing in sales tax law.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that this tax should be replaced by a broad-based consumption tax with a uniform ad valorem rate, without any exemptions whatsoever.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:
1. the Hawke Government's retirement incomes policies are piecemeal, inequitable, and discriminate against people who save towards achieving reasonable self-reliance in their retirement and
2. the Government's assets test legislation is particularly inequitable and its effects are especially discriminatory against farmers.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, will call upon the Government to:
1. repeal the assets test legislation;
2. institute a broad inquiry into Australia's retirement income and taxation systems; and

3. following the receipt of the report of such an inquiry implement a retirement incomes policy which is fair and equitable, encourages self-provision and will be non-discriminatory in its operation and impact.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that they are opposed to the proposals contained in the Government's White Paper for the reform of the Australian Tax System in so far as they relate to the imposition of further Capital Gains and Wealth Taxes.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call upon the Government to reject any proposal to increase the burden of Capital Gains and Wealth Taxes on the Australian people.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Baltic States: Human Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That on 28 February 1985 the Senate passed a resolution that read:

(i) that Australia, as a member of the United Nations should fulfil its obligation to promote and encourage respect of human rights and fundamental freedom, and should support the European Parliament's Resolution in respect of the Baltic States.

(ii) that in order to do so the Australian Government should, on its own initiative, and by seeking the support of like-minded governments, bring the question of human rights and self-determination for the Baltic States before all apropriate forums of the United Nations, and especially before the United Nations Human Rights Commission, and,
(iii) that the Department of Foreign Affairs should be directed to take all necessary steps in order to implement this Resolution.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Members and the House of Representatives will concur with that resolution.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Changes to Veterans' Entitlements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, we the undersigned call upon all Members to pay due respect to all returned service personnel.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that all changes to benefits for veterans, and conditions of service for military personnel, as announced in the May Economic Statement, be withdrawn as to allow sufficient time for sensible community debate before any veteran or service person can be unfairly disadvantaged.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Home Patients
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia showeth that:

Without any warning and at the worst possible moment, the Federal Government has abandoned the pensioner patients in South Australia's Nursing Homes. These people are suffering undeserving hardship and trauma as a result of the Federal Government's decision to freeze the nursing home benefit levels in South Australia.

The pensioner patients and those on fixed incomes now cannot expect any relief from recent significant fee increases approved by the Department of Community Services and which have coincided with the decision to freeze benefits.

80-85% of nursing home patients are pensioners and the majority are now required to pay in excess of their pension for their nursing care for the very first time. Some are paying over $5 per day on top of their pension. Many are looking for cheaper nursing care that doesn't exist.
We request that the Federal Government:

1. alleviate the distress of South Australia's nursing home patients and their families by effective restoration of the principle that pensioner patients should not have to pay more than their pension for nursing home care
2. restore the review of the benefit rates in November 1985
3. resolve its concerns over health care costs with the South Australian Government rather than inflicting unnecessary suffering on nursing home patients.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew and Mr Bilney.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of certain citizens of Queensland, Australia, respectfully showeth that we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act 1953.
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change the Australian national flag.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Airport at Badgery's Creek
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth:
1. Badgery's Creek and surrounding district are unsuitable sites for any major airport due to environmental, conservation and weather factors.
2. Many hundreds of people will be dislocated and many thousands more will be disturbed by the siting of an airport at Badgery's Creek and surrounding districts.

3. NSW taxpayers cannot afford the cost of a second airport when at a minimum of cost upgrading and expansion of Kingsford-Smith will satisfy the needs of NSW air travellers in the foreseeable future.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will not approve an airport at Badgery's Creek and surrounding districts.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
