DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's wasteful abuse of scarce taxpayers' funds by expenditure on politically motivated projects.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —A perusal of our daily newspapers, television channels and government publications will show massive government expenditure aimed purely at emphasising, enhancing and supporting the Australian Labor Party. A full page advertisement without any penalty for positioning in the Sydney Morning Herald, for example, costs $13,000-plus. A double page spread, as recently used in the Priority One: Young Australia advertising campaign on more than one occasion, costs $26,000. In fact, the Priority One campaign, with advertisements such as the one in the Sydney Morning Herald of 13 September containing whacking great photographs, cost $500,000. I ask honourable members to tell me what use they are to the Australian community. Did that campaign tell the kids how to get a job? It did not tell them how to get a job. It told them what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) thought of himself. We are starting to discover a bit about that.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for O'Connor is entitled to be heard in silence. There are far too many interjections from both sides of the House.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. This type of advertising is a disgrace. The very people who were making the most noise are the ones who will be interested in the words we have used in the matter of public importance. It refers to the `abuse of scarce taxpayers' funds'. Honourable members opposite know where those funds should be going. That money should be spent on the kids shown in the photograph in the advertisement, not on blown up photographs of the Prime Minister because he thinks he is something. In fact, Opposition advice indicates that expenditure on politically motivated media advertising and party political polls and surveys recently exceeded $6.5m.
—How much?

—It exceeded $6.5m. That information was provided in answer to a question on notice. What are these people doing? What have we got? We have publications such as the one on the prices and incomes accord. That beautiful publication cost only $750,000. We will talk more about that in a minute. That publication, consisting of 28 pages of cartoons, cost $750,000 and tells people what is good for them. That money is not being spent by the Government on youth training. The Government is not trying to help the kids of Australia. No, that money is being spent on boosting up the Government. It needs boosting up because polls in certain magazines are telling the Government how life is going.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had full page advertisements in national newspapers supposedly explaining the Government's reasons for tax reform. Those advertisements might tell people what the reasons are but they do not allay any of the fears which exist among people in the real world. The full page advertisement gives a hot line number. However, when one rings that number and asks, for example, how the capital gains tax will affect one's shareholdings if one is interested in putting out a new share issue or anything such as that one cannot find out. What is more, one cannot find out until March of next year. Why? Because the Government does not yet know what it is going to do. The Government is putting ads such as that in the newspapers at great cost to widows and all sorts of people. That is what the Government is doing. The Government knows it; it cannot deny it. There is probably a $1m cost involved in that advertisement in the newspapers. The people are getting hurt; the people who need assistance are being ignored by the Government. Is there anything in the publication on the accord that teaches people anything? It is full of bloody cartoons.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—I apologise for that, Mr Deputy Speaker, but I feel very strongly about this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to another area, the Australian Nationwide Opinion Poll surveys. That organisation happens to be the Australian Labor Party's own survey organisation. I guess it is no coincidence that consequently it gets 91 per cent of all government work. One wonders what discount that means for the Australian Labor Party. One wonders how many freebies the Australian Labor Party gets from ANOP. What sorts of surveys has the Government been getting done? I mention the survey concerning community attitudes towards school funding. It is not a survey into what the community wants from school funding. ANOP is going out there to find out whether the community is happy with the way the Labor Party is doing the funding. The Labor Party wants to know how it might buy itself a few more votes. There was a survey entitled: `Tasmania's reaction to Commonwealth policies and programs, 1984'.

Why does the Government want to know about Tasmania? It does not hold one seat in Tasmania. That is the point. The ANOP ought to be doing these surveys at the cost of the Labor Party. The Labor Party is the only beneficiary of that sort of information; the Government does not need to know it. The Government should be conducting a survey to find out what the people of Tasmania need.

We now have Federal Budget community reaction phase 1 and phase 2 as well as Budgets phases 1 to 25. Of course we also have something which the Minister seems to have to keep secret-the Aboriginal Development Commission inquiry into community attitudes to Aboriginals. That might not have been too bad except that the Minister was trying to ambush the community and get some information that he could have got for nothing from every other poll. He did not need to spend that money. The Government was trying to build up some propaganda.

The Government has an obligation to use the media to provide information to the public; that is the role of government advertising. It is expensive enough at between $25m and $40m a year. The Opposition does not protest when this occurs. Our protest has been that the scarce financial resources of the Australian community are redirected to promoting party political advantage and provide no helpful information whatsoever. All these documents are about selling the Government because it is in dire and terrible trouble. It is prepared to spend taxpayers' money but more importantly to take that money away from those people who need it. That is where it is all wrong.

When blatant attempts are made to sway community opinion purely to advance the prospects of a political party which has the control of these scarce community funds, the present Opposition has every reason in the world to complain as it is at the moment. I can see that the two honourable gentlemen who will follow me will want to jump up and down and give me some sort of history lesson. I will give them a history lesson. The people of Australia judged the Government on how it would deal with their money in this situation. The honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) and the Leader of the House, the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young), tell us that it is not the purpose of this Government to spend money in this way. We do not need a history lesson. If there were faults in the past it told the people about them, as did the Prime Minister in February 1983 when he said about a previous government:
The Government's decision to spend almost $1 million to advertise its wages freeze is a disgrace and a shocking misuse of taxpayers' money.

Why does the Government not stand on that? If the Prime Minister could find the bloke who wrote that, he would sack him. The Prime Minister would say: `You should never have done that. I will kill you'. If anybody does anything that turns out to be a mistake, it is never the Prime Minister's fault. He says: `It is not my fault. You have to be sacked'. The Prime Minister would chop the person's head off. One day he will try walking on water and he will blame someone when he drowns. The Prime Minister also said in 1983:
There ought to be now an end once and for all-
once and for all-not `when I get into power', but once and for all-
to this appalling misuse of taxpayers' funds for political purposes.
The Prime Minister used words like `disgrace' and `shocking'. It is amazing that he did not get a couple of others in that he uses so frequently.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are running out of steam.

—No, I am not, I am doing very well. I ask Mr Hawke: What of your Government's decision to spend $750,000 to advertise in this way? People are concerned about the application of their taxes. They believed those promises when they heard them, and as usual the promises have been broken. This is a Prime Minister of the `use by' date; he puts a use by date on all his promises because he knows they will not last very long. As I have said before, if the consumer authorities had anything to do with his promises as far as a use by date was concerned they would classify them all as the most perishable. People's trust has been misplaced. Let me just say that any quoting of history by the two honourable gentlemen opposite will go along the lines: `Do not do as I do, do as I say'. This is hypocrisy.
—Get excited. We like it.

—That is good. Every member of parliament in this House is able to observe the gaps in the provision of government services. Despite this Government being prepared to raise the tax take to intolerable levels and borrowing $20,000m in the last three years, doubling the accumulated debts of the previous 80-odd years of Federal Government, these matters are still unresolved. The Government is not denying that there are people out there who could do with this sort of money. People still suffer from inadequate government resources. The Opposition stands in defence of these people and in total opposition to the waste of scarce government resources. Wasteful government advertising and promotion of public services in no way advances the welfare of the Australian community but purely the political opportunities of the Government and certain media and survey organisations which give Labor support. It is amazing that we find other community organisations are getting the prime share of this amount of money.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is not crying foul. It will take the political problems associated with this. If it were not for the community cost the Opposition would not even mind the Prime Minister's picture in the paper. I will tell honourable members why the Opposition does not mind his picture there. Today that photograph is associated with a man who callously and incompetently wasted $400,000 of taxpayers' money in the payment to Dr Armstrong. That is what people see when they see the picture of the Prime Minister now. They see a man who wasted all that money. We do not mind that picture going before the people if the Government can do it for nothing, because that is about what it is worth.

It is clear that a large amount of government expenditure is being diverted in this direction. It is not all going out as honourable members may believe. It is going out of government departments. There is $4.943 billion associated with the education vote. People believe that that is going to educate their kids, which is what they want. However, a large proportion of that is funding little brochures which are delivered around schools by school teachers and which make claims about what the Government is doing. I will tell honourable members what people want from the education system. They do not want these sorts of advertisements. They want their kids to be able to read these advertisements. The Government should spend the money it has on ensuring the kids can read.

TALK.START.PARA: —The way you are going you won't be able to read for much longer, you will be blind.

—I will not be blind from anything the Minister can do to me. I do not have to worry about that. People want that money spent on educating their children, not on telling them that a situation that is still inadequate is in fact better than it is. That is all we get out of these sorts of publications. What about giving some more assistance in the education arena to people in remote areas who are unable to send their kids to school because the Government says that it has not got any money for that when it has got money for this form of advertising?

SPEECH.PARA: Where do we find all this money going? Seventy per cent of the Priority One: Young Australia program brochure consists of photographs. There is nothing in it but publicity for the Government. There is no information as to where the kids go to get on this training scheme. The Government does not tell them things like that. When they ring the hotline, they get nothing then either. We know what is in the tax advertisements. The accord booklet and the booklet on youth training are all just publicity. They contain no information for people. On the Ayers Rock handover the Government is going to have a real party. An amount of $350,000 is going to be spent on that. I have travelled in the Northern Territory and other places on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs and I can tell honourable members that there are still heaps of people who just need a house. How many houses could we get for $350,000? I will tell honourable members something else. For children who are battling and who need remedial teaching, the cost of the Priority One program would have paid for the annual services of 200 remedial teachers. The Priority One program did not even tell people where to apply for it. It was just pure publicity. That is the situation we have.

Coincidental or not, the company which handled the recent advertising for the Government on its Priority One campaign was Chandler, Hamilton and Mier, whose controlling interest is held by Monahan, Dayman Adams Pty Ltd. Those companies are just three miles apart. The word is out now that that particular group-headed up really, of course, by Mr Phillip Adams, although his name comes last on the list-is favoured to get a $1m contract for advertising the International Year of Peace. I can tell honourable members that that sort of advertising will bring a lot of peace in Australia when people are going short of things such as education and health. The Opposition asks today how much money was diverted through these particular firms that I have just referred to in relation to that scurrilous situation of those how to vote cards at Nunawading.

What backhander went out there? Was the printing done in that way? It probably was. There is no reason for the Government to spend this money. It said that it would not do so; it promised not to do so. But the Government is producing things of no value to the community, taking away scarce resources from people who need them, people who are in real trouble. Labor members pontificate about the poor and what they would like to do for them-I refer to the very people who are sitting in this chamber at the moment-but they are prepared to tolerate the situation going on like this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism)

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again, we have heard the ubiquitous member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) raving and ranting in his usual disjointed, illogical fashion on something about which he knows very little. Whatever theories he propounds are based on a doubtful premise. As usual, we had from him a fairly decent expose of alleged dishonesty in Government practice, ranging from innuendo about Australian Nationwide Opinion Polls Pty Ltd and what sort of discounts it would be giving the Government because it happens to do its polling. I do not think that does the honourable member for O'Connor or the party he represents much good, but he continually comes into this House questioning people's honesty. He should look in his own cupboard occasionally before he starts to talk about anybody else. It should be made quite clear that all government advertising and government public relations exercises are propounded on a decent tender system so that everything is above board, above suspicion.
—Do you ring up Adams and tell him the lowest tender?

—If the honourable member has any doubts about it and about Phillip Adams, why does he not go outside the House and say it? He is a very courageous man sitting there pouring scorn on a very well-known and favourably received Australian, Phillip Adams. He gets his work, if he gets work from this Government, because he provides the best tender, which is something the honourable member's grubby little mind might be able to comprehend. Our procedures here are above suspicion. If he thinks they are not, he should try to have an inquiry into them and see whether he can find any information to support his grubby little theory.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me give a few figures. In 1982-83 the previous Government spent $24m on advertising, most of it just before the election, propounding the benefits of the Liberal's great pre-election Budget. The then Government had the indecency to spend $2m during the Flinders by-election pushing the family Budget policy. Anything this Government has done in advertising has been dedicated to making Australians acquainted with what government assistance is available in every area. It was quite predictable that we would produce the Priority One: Young Australia program. I would have thought that there would have been bipartisan support in this Parliament for Priority One, which is about getting kids to work and increasing their employment opportunities by improving their educational possibilities. I make no apology for what money we have spent in co-ordinating the activities in education, employment and industrial relations in this Priority One program. It is making employers aware of what is available in traineeships.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no information. The ads are hopeless.

—The ads are not hopeless. They have been very well received by everybody. I do not need the assistance of the Leader of the Opposition. I usually do a single act. Actually he is a doll; I play him with my foot. The information in those ads is dedicated to letting employers know what opportunities are available for the employment of trainees, for parents to realise what opportunities are available in education and to paint the overall picture. That is then backed up by a great deal of leaflets that are available, as is pointed out in the advertisements. Anything the Opposition protests about in our advertising is discountable. Our advertising is not about us winning the next election, as all of the former Government's advertising was. It is about explaining to people what Government policies are all about. I would have thought that, after all those years, given the huge legacy of youth unemployment left to us by the coalition Government when it left office, the Opposition would now at least adopt a bipartisan approach to something that is dedicated towards getting kids to work. The whole speech of the member for O'Connor was peppered with inaccuracies. For instance, he said that the accord booklet cost $250,000. It cost $40,000. That was a slight inaccuracy; just 600 per cent out.
—How many copies are printed for that?

—I do not know how many copies have been printed, but if the Opposition wants to know I will get the answer. The total cost was $40,000. The taxation advertising was primarily used to inform people about the hotline. There have been 6,500 calls as a result of that ad from people wanting information. It is an absolute insult for Opposition members to come into this place to tell us how we waste money on propaganda or advertising. Does the Opposition recall its Government's Information Unit? If ever there was an insult to the Australian public in the use of taxpayers' money, the Government Information Unit was a prime example. Everybody in Australia and everybody in this House knew that the GIU was an extension of Liberal Party headquarters. Eggleton made no excuses, not even an apology for it. It was an indictment on honourable members opposite that they spent public money promoting their own political party. To the eternal credit of the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) when he became the Minister responsible for that area in the first term of the Hawke Government, the GIU was disbanded and replaced with the Media Liaison Service, which has taken an absolutely apolitical stance. I defy anybody to prove that the MLS has been anything but an apolitical body.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition members may laugh, but let them produce a bit of proof. Hollow laughter does not do anything to provide any sort of reasoned argument. Opposition members who come in here talking about improper use of taxpayers' funds must be kidding.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me tell the House about a few of the things they did with taxpayers' funds in order to stay in government, and how unsuccessful they were. Let us look at airports. The coalition Government built international airports in Cairns, Townsville, Brisbane and Adelaide primarily to stay in government. I well remember the late honourable member for Lilley, Kevin Cairns, coming over to me on the day the then Government announced the construction of the new Brisbane Airport to cost $182m. He said: `That will make sure that Lilley remains safe in the hands of democracy'. How right he was, because the Liberal Party lost the seat at the next election. It is now a Labor seat and is safe in the hands of democracy.

TALK.START.PARA: —How about Parramatta Park!

—I am happy to debate that with the Opposition members too, if they like. The then Government decided to build international terminals in Cairns and Townsville. Was there ever a more ridiculous waste of taxpayers' money? We have more international gateways in Australia than there are in the United States of America, and Australia has one-twentieth of its population. The then Government was so unsuccessful that the airport at Adelaide was opened three times. The former Prime Minister opened it once, the former Minister for Aviation opened it once and the local member opened it once and the coalition Government then lost the seat. It could not even spend public money as immorally as it did with any great success. Opposition members are hopeless. They should not start lecturing and hectoring us about how we spend public money.

SPEECH.PARA: Our advertising has been expended in an honourable fashion by means of tender. It has all been dedicated to explaining to the people of Australia, who actually pay for government programs. I know that is news to the Opposition, but it is true. It is paid for by the Australian public and they are entitled to know what the programs are about, and how they can take advantage of them. I defy Opposition members to produce one piece of information in our advertising that has done anything other than try to explain to the Australian public what information is available. Opposition members can rave and rant all they like about advertising. Our advertising has been a-political and aimed at explaining government programs. Opposition members talk about misleading advertising. Does anybody recall Liberal Party advertising, putting forward the idea of the fistful of dollars? It is evident when considering the sort of transparent dishonesty practised by the Opposition in its own political advertisements as well as in its government advertising. We stand here as a government that has done more to improve the lot of the Australian people in three years than the Liberal Party has managed in 31 of the previous 36 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—The honourable member can say `Rubbish', but the figures are there to prove it. Look at the employment figures released today; look at the economy; look at everything that has happened in Australia in the last three years and tell us that we are not a better government than those opposite could ever have aspired to be. Yet we have not wasted money in promoting a political cause. As I explained a little while ago, the amount of money we spent in 1984-85 is exactly comparable with what those opposite spent in 1982-83. But all of our expenditure has been apolitical. All former Government advertising in 1982-83 was absolutely political, all aimed at promoting the Liberal Party. The Flinders by-election was a perfect example and featured the family Budget produced by the coalition Government. The then Government spent $2m on advertising for the Flinders by-election. The Liberals got their candidate in that time, but the man did not get here. We went to another election first.

SPEECH.PARA: The family budget program was an exercise in corporate advertising aimed solely at selling the short term politically expedient decisions taken in that year's Budget. Our programs, by comparison, are target-oriented and designed genuinely to provide useful information to the taxpayers who pay for these programs.

In 1982-83 the previous Government, the present Opposition, engaged in the biggest political propaganda ever seen in this Parliament. Fraser tried to buy the votes of the Australian population with handouts to the tune of billions of dollars, including massive advertising campaigns. It did not work. If the honourable member for O'Connor can produce any shred of evidence to suggest any form of dishonesty in the way in which we run our advertising campaigns, please produce it. It is easy for him to stand here with his usual flourish, but what he says does not prove a thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is in the accord pamphlets.

—Is it? If the honourable member wants to talk about the wasteful use of public money, I have just given him the perfectly good example of airports. It is a pity that more members of the National Party of Australia are not in the House at the moment because we could talk about a few of the handouts that Fraser, Anthony, Street and Sinclair helped themselves to for years-superphosphate subsidies, beef cattle incentive schemes, drought subsidies, anything going. If the honourable member wants to talk about decency in government he should not start lecturing us about our advertising campaigns. Our advertising campaigns are honest, they are clear and they go exactly where they are aimed-to the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member mentioned that the Ayers Rock ceremony will cost $350,000. It will cost $132,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Really? Apparently the honourable member for O'Connor has the figures. They would want to be more accurate than the figures he quoted in his speech, which were all wrong. He said that the accord booklet cost a quarter of a million dollars. In fact, it cost $40,000. All I can suggest to the characters opposite is that it is an absolute sham for them to come in here and start questioning the honesty, the veracity or the decency of this Government's advertising campaigns. The honourable member did not produce one whit of evidence in his quarter-hour speech to prove that we have done any wrong, but we can give honourable members opposite plenty of evidence of what they have done wrong. I have already given them plenty of that. The Flinders by-election is a perfectly good example. The Government Information Unit, that dreadful Goebbels-type propaganda unit that Opposition members employed, was a disgrace to the parliamentary system in Australia. That unit, which was demolished by us and replaced by something decent, was another perfectly good example of how honourable members opposite acted in government. They are a disgrace to this Parliament, and that is why they were removed from office. Honourable members opposite came in here, having won one election, and all they could think about was what they could do to convince the Australian people that they should vote for them next time. What did they do of a constructive nature in all those years in government? I wish they could give me one good living example of any reform they introduced in that period, apart from the few decent things their Prime Minister did in respect of South Africa. The only decent impact they made on the fabric of Australian society was in respect of African affairs. With all those years in government, with all the propaganda they employed about what a great government they were, they were not able to convince the Australian public and they never will again.

SPEECH.PARA: We stand here very proud of our advertising programs. They are honest, they are fair, and they are decent. If honourable members opposite could produce one whit of evidence to suggest otherwise, we would be very happy to see it. On what we have been shown today, I do not think that is going to happen. If those opposite want a little more evidence, we happen to know that during the 1983 campaign the former Prime Minister spent $40,000 on three business luncheons around Australia. How do they equate that with their record on advertising?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have got Newman's files on you.
—I hope the honourable member will produce them here. I would love to see them produce their files on me.
—Order! The Minister will-
—I am very happy to debate my behaviour.
—Order! The Minister will not talk while I am talking. The honourable member for Richmond is going to follow in this debate. He will keep quiet until it is his turn to get the call and speak.
—You nearly saved him. His time is nearly up.
—I am very happy to debate anything that is on file about my behaviour as a Minister.
—Order! The honourable member for Richmond will withdraw that remark. I consider it an aspersion upon the Chair.
—I withdraw the remark.

—The honourable member for Richmond spends his time asking grubby little questions. I had another one from him yesterday-he will get the answer very shortly-about the cost of a reception that was put on for me by the Consul-General in New York in 1983. The year referred to in the honourable member's question was 1984. He could not even get the year right, the silly little man. The answer is: Nothing. The Consul-General put on a function in which I produced for the American travel trade Press the Hogan advertisements. It cost nothing.

—Order! The Minister's time has expired. It appears that I attributed to the honourable member for Richmond a remark which was made by the honourable member for Barker. The honourable member for Barker will withdraw the remark.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I presume that you were referring to my comments about the Minister having difficulty in filling his time. If that is the case, I withdraw. He did have difficulty, but I withdraw.
—Order! The honourable member will not debate the issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased that the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) has taken part in this debate. He seems concerned with accuracy. Let us get down to accuracy. The Minister talked about the accord document. There are four direct references to the Australian Labor Party or the Labor Government on pages 1 and 2 of that document. This is apolitical party advertising? The Minister talked about the Government Information Unit. The Labor Party renamed that body the National Media Liaison Group when it came to government. Let me tell the House what the National Media Liaison Group does. It runs Ministers' itineraries and monitors radio programs and newspapers for Australian Labor Party Ministers and members. Let me tell the House something else. It does not report to Parliament. What we have in the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism is a mechanism for disseminating government information, government propaganda. We have the National Media Liaison Group, the Ministerial Media Group, and something called the ICB-the Information Co-ordination Branch.

SPEECH.PARA: This debate today is about the amount of money this Government spends on advertising which is of direct relevance and direct benefit to itself. We are not talking about a few million dollars. Last year the ICB co-ordinated advertising to a total value of in excess of $27m, and I am not talking about classified advertising. Classified advertising and tender advertising cost $9.6m. What I am talking about is campaign advertising. Of that $27m, some $6.5m is directly party political. Let us look at what it is. First of all, the economic summit advertising was run by Monahan Dayman Adams Pty Ltd. The family income supplement advertisements and the community employment program advertisements were done by Monahan Dayman Adams. The superannuation `The Facts' advertisements were done by Monahan Dayman Adams. I defy any advertising copywriter to get the details of the superannuation tax into the sorts of advertisements this agency ran. The first home owners scheme, the national wage case, and the enrol to vote campaign were handled by Monahan Dayman Adams, which involved an amount of $2.4m.

The Special Minister of State (Mr Young), who is not in the chamber, said at 6.30 on the night of the election: `I am very happy with this campaign. They did a great job'. On Sunday morning he said: `Oh, it did not work. No one understood how to vote'. But Monahan Dayman Adams did that campaign. Because it does such a great job and everything goes to tender, when there is tangible evidence that the campaign fails, on the Minister's own admission, one would think that agency would not get another job. But what happened? Who did the prices and incomes accord and the sex discrimination Act advertising? It was done by Monahan Dayman Adams. Let us go a little further. How many other campaigns did Monahan Dayman Adams do? It conducted the blood donors campaign. Is it not absolutely astounding? Lo and behold, that agency is probably going to get the International Year of Peace campaign. Apart from the campaigns I have mentioned, we have had the International Year of Youth, participation and equity in education and training, and the sea safety campaign.

One thing that stands out above everything else in this is the Phillip Adams connection. Phillip Adams, in case any members of this House do not know, is a professional supporter of the Australian Labor Party. He is the absolute epitome of the Bollinger Bolshevik. I said that this Government had spent some $27m on advertising. It has appointed three master agencies to place that advertising. There are no prizes for guessing the name of one of those agencies. We have USP Needham Pty Ltd, Gordon and Gotch Ltd and Monahan Dayman Adams Pty Ltd.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not again.
—Yes. We have been talking about advertising. Let us have a look at research for a moment, and of course, there is another connection in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) made some reference to research, but let us go through it in a little more detail. Australian Nationwide Opinion Polls Pty Ltd, which is coincidentally the Australian Labor Party's research company, has had 91.4 per cent of the ICB's expenditure budget on research placed through it. It is very interesting to examine the titles of these campaigns.

In August of 1983 there was research into the awareness and understanding of the 1983-84 Federal Budget. From January to June of 1984 there was research into the attitudes of young Australians to various government policies and programs. From January to June of 1984 there was research into the public understanding of policy on funding for schools. From March to April of 1984 there was initial and follow-up research into the awareness of the Tasmanian public of Commonwealth offers of assistance following the High Court of Australia decision on the Gordon below Franklin dam. The Australian taxpayers paid $74,000 for that. Then we have a classic. In August of 1984 there was research into the community awareness and understanding of the 1984-85 Federal Budget. There are no prizes for guessing what is going on now. There are probably research projects into the May cost cutting exercise, into the August Budget and into what is going on now with the so-called tax reform program. Quite frankly, it is an abuse of position.

All this advertising goes through something called the ministerial advertising committee. Lo and behold, who is chairman of it? It is the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism. I say to the Minister, who is still present in the chamber, on behalf of the Opposition that we accept his offer to have an inquiry into advertising placed by this Government. We look forward to it. I hope that the second speaker on behalf of the Government addresses the issue and offers a direct inquiry. Quite frankly, $27m worth of government spending on advertising-with the sorts of relationships that exist, because the advertising is not all put out to tender and because there is, finally, a decision taken on who gets the benefit from placing that advertising-should be subject to public scrutiny. All I can say is that I hope that the second speaker for the Government, whoever it is, accepts the Minister's offer of an inquiry, because that is what we need. That $27m worth of advertising, which is directly influenced by the Minister, is significant.

By the way, the Minister talked about how easy it is to get information. This file, which, unfortunately, we will not have time to go through in much detail today-so, we will save the juicy bits for other occasions-was as difficult to extract as extracting teeth with one's bare hand. Honourable members should try to request something under the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act and see what sort of response they get from this Government, especially when they ask it about its advertising campaigns, its research campaigns or how it takes decisions on who will do what advertising. What answers does one get? One gets not a thing. One is told that the information is not suitable to be released, or the charges are levied before anything happens. What happens to the questions on notice on this matter which the Government is asked? How come there are questions on the Notice Paper which have not been answered? The answers to the questions which are given are absolutely obscured by what this Government is scared of revealing in terms of its advertising campaigns.

The sensitivity to this issue demonstrated by this Government today is absolutely astounding. Obviously there is concern. Obviously the Government is worried. Obviously there is something that really should be brought out into the open. As the Minister has offered to have an inquiry, I think it is incumbent upon this Government to either put up or shut up. We should have an inquiry into what is going on with government spending. Unlike what the Minister said, this spending is not a-political; every bit of it is political. There is no detail in the Government's campaigns. All we see is the retouched photograph of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in circumstances which are designed to create a favourable impression with the Australian people.

Let us go back to the July Federal council meeting of the ALP. What was the decision of that Federal council meeting? It was that the Government should spend more time and effort in promoting programs and ALP policy. The Government spent $27m in the last financial year. If that was the decision of its Federal council meeting in July, just how much money will it spend this year? We can look at the estimates and appropriations of the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism for its special information campaigns this year. We see a vote of half a million dollars. In answer to questions asked in the Senate Estimates committee we were told by an officer of the Department that that half a million dollars has been expended on Priority One: Young Australia advertising. Does that mean that no more information campaigns will be run this year? Does that mean that no more research will be undertaken by the ICB? If that is the case, what will we do with all those people who are in the ICB? I suggest that the Minister should read the Estimates committee evidence, because his officers said that the half a million dollars has been spent. I do not know what those people will do for the rest of the year, unless the Department is voted more money. The reality is that in the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism we have, sandwiched between sweetness and light, an information production unit which is designed to use taxpayers' funds to promote this Government's programs and policies in the most favourable light. The Government uses research as an extension of party political activity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seem to be making a habit of following the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) in debate in this place. I think the outcome today will not be any different from what it was in the last few debates. It is interesting to note that we have before us today a matter of public importance that has been proposed by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's wasteful abuse of scarce taxpayers' funds by expenditure on politically motivated projects.

This comes as a dynamite matter of public importance when we have the taxation package before us for discussion in the House and Bills have to be debated. They are matters which I consider to be far more important than this nonsense.

I want to turn quickly to some of the points that have been made. The honourable member for O'Connor was talking about the types of programs that the advertising in the media purported to cover. He talked about Priority One: Young Australia, the accord, the advertising of the reasons for taxation reform, and so on. I suggest that it would be perhaps remiss of any government not to advertise that such programs have been put in place and, indeed, to say to the people of Australia: These are the programs that this Government is able to put in place and this is the way one goes about dealing with them. That is exactly what happens.

It is very easy for the honourable member to discuss things such as the cost of a booklet that has been produced, particularly the one on the accord. The honourable member for Richmond also touched on that. He talked about the accord booklet and how it referred to the Australian Labor Party three or four times on the first page. Of course it would. Why would it? The answer is that the accord is the greatest piece of industrial work that has been done between a government, the workers and industry in this country's history. How has it been achieved? It has been achieved because of this Government. What is the political complexion of this Government? It is an ALP government.

Honourable members opposite want confrontation. They do not want to be in this process of working together with industry, the workers and government and coming up with something that will be for the benefit of Australia. That is not their bag. Rightly enough, they would not spend any money advertising what they do because their advertising would be about confrontation, strikes, sacking people and taking people to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, et cetera. If honourable members opposite wanted to get re-elected, they certainly would not want to have that in front of the people's eyes.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would not spend anything--

—I say to the honourable member for O'Connor: Let us be honest. Successive governments have devoted public resources to publicising things such as apprenticeship rebate schemes, home ownership schemes, employment programs, social security benefits, and so on. Of course they have, because utilising the mass media of this country is the only way to go. We are talking about newspapers, magazines, radio and television. One uses the media so that one can get the message across to those people one wants to help. Governments should use the media correctly, and this Government does exactly that. Honourable members opposite should not talk to me about needing to have these massive advertisements with photographs of people and all the rest of it but which say nothing. That is absolute nonsense.
—He is not interested in what the answer is.

—Obviously the honourable member for O'Connor is not interested in the answer because he is choosing to leave. The honourable member for Richmond also has left, which is not surprising either. I will mention a couple of the other points which were raised about advertising campaigns that various governments have embarked upon. One which readily springs to mind and which was quoted by the honourable member for Richmond is the enrol to vote campaign. I would have thought that, regardless of whether one is a member on this side of the House or the other side of the House, it is to everyone's advantage to see that the majority of people eligible to vote in this country are in fact enrolled.

SPEECH.PARA: The business of getting back into this place involves having somebody say: `He is not a bad bloke. I will put a cross or a one beside his name and get him back'. Thus one tries to get the most members of the House elected. That is the difference between people on this side and those on the other side of the House. We know how to get back into government. We know that the people will elect us and we embark upon advertising campaigns, such as the enrol to vote campaign, because we believe in the right of every Australian to exercise his voting rights at every opportunity.

It could well be that those on the other side- indeed, the honourable member for Richmond- want those who are eligible to vote not to be on the electoral roll. He is a member of the National Party of Australia. Perhaps he is taking a leaf out of the book of his colleagues in Queensland, where the sheep votes count probably more than the votes of those who are eligible to vote and who walk on two legs. I will not get too carried away with that line of thought.

Reference was made to the blood donors campaign. Are honourable members opposite trying to tell me that advertising for blood donors in order to save lives is not a useful exercise? If that is the case and if that is the point being raised by the honourable member for Richmond, it is a very poor state of affairs.

Some reference was made by the honourable member for O'Connor to the inclusion of the photograph of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in advertisements. The honourable member said that it was terrific to see it there because it shows the people of Australia what a terrible job he is doing. That is nonsense! I refer the honourable member to two recent visits by the Prime Minister to rural parts of this country. I refer, of course, to Townsville and Warwick. What did we find? Let us look at what happened at Warwick, the heartland of the National Party of Queensland. All the National Party people there live for the day when they will see the socialist Government thrown out of office. These people would say: `Oh no, not a Labor parliamentarian coming to this area'. Interestingly, the local member happens to represent the Australian Labor Party in this place and is a very good member. It was advertised that the Prime Minister was going to Warwick. Can honourable members believe that one had to beat off with a stick people coming to see and hear the Prime Minister? Those people who were being beaten off with a stick were National Party members.

On the very night of the dinner the wife of the President of the local branch of the National Party said: `Excuse me, Prime Minister. Would you mind signing an autograph for me and could you make it to me with love from Bob Hawke?' If we are talking about the popularity of Prime Ministers and leaders of the opposition, let us get the facts straight. The man who has the top job in this country and who represents this side of the House is the top man and he will continue to be so. So let us not get carried away with this ridiculous notion about advertising.

I will compare some of the facts and figures. The honourable member for O'Connor said: `It is no good going back in history'. It is all very well for him to say that but back in the good old days when honourable members opposite governed this country, they frequently referred to historical exercises and talked about maladministration under Prime Minister Whitlam. It is incumbent upon us to look back because only through looking back will we get an idea of what the other side was able to achieve. Let us look at some advertising expenditure figures for the Fraser Government in what just happened to be the election years. In 1980-81, $23.25m was spent on advertising by the Fraser Government; in 1982-83, $24.84m was spent on advertising. Honourable members opposite are trying to tell us that there is evidence to support the idea that this Government spends money only on political advertising. What nonsense! This statement is typical of the dishonesty of the honourable member for Richmond.

I refer also to some points raised by our good friend the honourable member for O'Connor. I am sorry he is no longer in the chamber. He is an expert in the whole area of overexpenditure. We well remember him, as a councillor in Carnarvon Shire, taking his wife on council paid holidays. We certainly will not forget that in February 1980 he was called upon to account for his actions and repay the costs incurred for hotels and air fares. He should not talk to me about overexpenditure and government spending on advertising. I am saddened that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has left this chamber. I well remember that when he took over as Leader he said: `If any of my front benchers do not perform they will have to go'. I put it to the House that both honourable gentlemen on the other side who spoke on this matter failed dismally. They put forward a matter of public importance which was absolute nonsense and they failed to give any evidence whatsoever of a failure by this Government in respect of advertising. I put it to honourable members that they blew it.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Lalor-Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)(3.38)-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Customs Tariff Proposals No. 10 1985.

The Customs tariff proposals which I have just tabled relate to proposed alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1982. The changes, which operate on and from 11 October 1985, arise from the Government's consideration of the Industries Assistance Commission's report on telecommunications and related equipment and parts. Consideration of the IAC report formed part of an overall review by the Government of its approach to developing the information industries in this country. The fact that the information industries have an impact on all facets of industry and the economy, and have good growth prospects, was an important consideration in formulating the Government's strategy for assisting the communications equipment industry.

In this regard the Government was particularly concerned that the domestic communications equipment industry had failed to grow during a period of growth in the world market associated with significant opportunities created by new technology. The Government was also concerned that continuing high levels of protection for this industry would disadvantage users of communications services, and delay necessary changes in the industry.

The relative decline of the industry is attributed to a number of interrelated factors which have encouraged a domestic market orientation, a dependence on overseas technology, and a reliance on relatively high levels of protection. Furthermore, a number of studies have suggested that the problems of the industry are likely to be exacerbated by technological change and that further decline could be expected unless research and development is significantly increased and export markets are developed.

Neither the Government nor the industry saw this decline as irreversible and a significant factor in determining the approach adopted by the Government has been assurances from the industry that it believed that it had the potential to develop into a major export-oriented industry and that it had already begun to make real commitments to research, development and exports. The Government acknowledges that some of the industry's problems were either the result of constraints imposed by the Government and its agencies or were of a type that could not be satisfactorily addressed by the current resources of the industry. Accordingly, there is a need for co-ordinated action by government and industry to create an environment which would enable and encourage the industry to be more internationally competitive, export oriented and innovative.

The starting point in this process is the setting of appropriate levels of protection which are consistent with general and related industry policies. In this context, in examining the Industries Assistance Commission report, the Government was concerned to ensure that its decision was broadly consistent with recent decisions on the consumer electronics and automatic data processing equipment industries. The Government considers that the prevailing high level of protection combined with other factors has contributed to the problems of the industry over the last decade and, unless pressure to change is maintained, there would be a real risk that adjustment will be so slow that the overall decline of the industry would contine.

Although broadly accepting the IAC's recommendation for a reduction in levels of assistance for the major goods under reference from 30 per cent to 20 per cent, the Government has recognised that a period of adjustment will be required to allow industry to change and new programs to be effective. Accordingly, the reductions in the tariff will be introduced over a period of four years for most products covered by the reference. For those goods under reference currently dutiable at rates less than 20 per cent, a 20 per cent duty will be applied from tomorrow. The Government has accepted the IAC's recommendation for a 25 per cent value added production bounty to be paid on modems and multiplexors generally used with computers. Implementation of the bounty will be deferred until 1 July 1986 because of the need to establish the appropriate administrative and legislative arrangements. It is also the Government's intention that preforms used in the manufacture of optical fibre be subject to a duty of 20 per cent from 1 July 1986.

Following implementation of these tariff proposals, the Government and industry will begin the preparation of a comprehensive strategy to address the industry's long term problems. On the Government's side this package would largely entail improved co-ordiantion of existing government activities, particularly in the areas of government purchasing, offsets, technology programs, regulation and trade strategies. A summary of the alterations contained in these proposals has been prepared and is being circulated for the information of honourable members. I commend the proposals to the House.
