DEBATE.TITLE: REFORM OF THE AUSTRALIAN TAXATION SYSTEM

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The sorry saga of Labor's tax reform package started in Perth in the election campaign in December 1984. It started because the Australian Labor Party was beginning to feel vulnerable as it did not have a tax policy and the Australian public was beginning to realise that the Liberal Party of Australia was offering a pretty good policy. Our policy was one of income splitting, child care rebates, an attack on government expenditure and a firm commitment against the introduction of capital gains taxes, death taxes and all the other taxes of Labor's envy and greed.

SPEECH.PARA: In the classic case of a decision made on the run the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in response to a suggestion from a Perth radio announcer said: `Oh, a summit; that is a good idea. I think that we will have a summit'. So off the Government headed towards a summit. It prepared the now famous draft White Paper. The summit was one of the fiascos of all time. The upshot was that on the Thursday night of the summit, the members of the trade union leadership called in the Prime Minister and said: `We do not like what you are offering in your draft White Paper'. They told the Prime Minister what to do: As part of the prices and incomes accord and the general understanding between the Government and the trade union movement, they wanted a capital gains tax. They gave him a free hand to introduce this anti-business and anti-free enterprise tax package. The Government has broken faith on three fundamental issues. The first is that it went into the last election with a principle that was restated in the draft White Paper. It said:
Any reform package must have widespread community support.
It is quite clear that there is no widespread community support for this project. The Government has broken faith on that issue. Secondly, No. 8 of the tax reform principles stated:
Any reform package must provide the best possible climate for investment, growth and employment in Australia.

No one could seriously put up the proposition that this package which is directed at the incentives of people to get on, take risks and to build up their own enterprises for their support and that of their family, could possibly contemplate that this package falls within that principle. The Government has broken faith. The classic of all classics was the 1983 ALP policy statement that was delivered to the nation by the now Prime Minister. It is worth quoting. He said:
Let me make one point so clear that even our opponents can understand it and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentation and distortion. There will be no new capital gains tax.

If ever there was a broken promise beyond misrepresentation and distortion, this is it. The Prime Minister must surely go down in the Guinness Book of Records as Australia's best exponent of the broken promise. In one pull of the trigger, the Prime Minister, the world's greatest Treasurer and the bloodthirsty ideologue troops that support them have fired a broadside at every small business in this country. At a time when businesses and families are reeling under Labor's high interest regime as a result of its disastrous new corporatism economic management, the last thing that we want is more taxes and the last thing that we want specifically is Labor's new capital gains tax.

Despite Labor's claim that its capital gains tax is justified on grounds of horizontal and vertical equity and the shoring up of the income tax system, the fact is that this tax is deeply rooted in Labor's discredited theories of the distribution of wealth. It is the old syndrome of cutting down the tall poppies, denigrating the achievers and reducing all to the lowest common denominator. It is yet another indication of the increasing dominance of the forces of the Left in the Labor Party. I conclude by saying that there is a firm commitment in the coalition parties that upon our return to government we will vote to repeal Labor's capital gains tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In entering into this debate, I wish to pick up a few points I made yesterday when addressing some of the legislation that is encompassed in the new tax package. I wish first of all to make the point that I made yesterday-that the Government has just completed a comprehensive and far reaching tax reform exercise. Enormous Government resources have been allocated to it within the Government, within committees, within advisers and within the Public Service. Enormous resources within the community, within business and within the trade union sector have also been allocated to reaching a fair and equitable tax package that will be accepted and be seen as fair across the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is reasonable to reflect on why it was necessary for the Australian Government to allocate this sort of effort and these sorts of resources to a reform of our tax system. The reason is that just about everybody in Australia, except a few honourable members on the other side of the House, has perceived that our tax system had become unfair. Not only had it become unfair but also many Australians had decided to opt out. We had created in Australia an attitude of non-compliance, and that attitude became a major threat to the social fabric of this country. Let no one misunderstand the extent of that threat and the depths to which the tax system in Australia had sunk because of those who had decided to opt out of paying their fair share. We had developed a tax system which was no longer progressive. People like to look at tax scales and to think that we have a system whereby the more one earns the greater is one's capacity to pay and therefore the more tax one pays. What had developed under tax law under previous governments was a system whereby the more one earned the less one paid, the higher one's income the greater one's capacity to use fancy techniques to minimise one's tax and to opt out. We had developed a regressive tax system.

We have heard so much bleating from the other side of the House in this debate about the steps that have been taken to remove negative gearing. The reason for that, very simply, is that the 60c in the dollar tax deduction that people have been enjoying with their negatively geared investments all these years has resulted not in taxpayers paying 60c in the dollar for their top dollars but, in fact, in their getting 60c in the dollar deductions on loans, business lunches and all sorts of operations. I will return to the question of business lunches in a while, because again we have heard so much bleating about this issue today. It needs to be recognised that very few Australians have been paying tax at the rate of 60c in the dollar. Those who ought to have been doing so have found ways to opt out of the tax system. That is one of the reasons why the Government has proposed the changes that it has to the tax scale.

Much of the publicity that has followed the introduction of the Government's tax reform package has centred on two particular areas-the new tax on fringe benefits, including business lunches, and the capital gains tax. That is not what the package is all about. They are two relatively insignificant components of a major reform package. Perhaps I ought to piece together the major components of the package so that there is a better understanding of it. First of all, this Government has addressed the issue of non-compliance. We are facing up to the fact that people must re-enter the tax system. Those who have been opting out must rejoin the ranks of ordinary taxpayers. We have as a government closed off many loopholes in the legislation. We have dramatically increased the resources and powers available to the Commissioner of Taxation to track down tax minimisers and tax avoiders. We have introduced new penalties for the provision of false information to the Australian Taxation Office and we have increased the penalties for those who have been minimising and avoiding tax. We have made very significant attempts to pursue retrospectively those who ought to have been paying their taxes.

The reform process also includes the introduction of a national identity card, which has been very popularly received in the community. I want to make just one point about that. The introduction of this national identity card is directed at combating tax evasion and fraud, particularly in the social security system and in relation to the non-declaration of interest, dividends and income of that kind. The legislation will incorporate very strict measures to protect the privacy of individuals and the card will be used only in areas related to social security and the tax system.

We have also taken steps to remove two of the major regressive components of our tax system. I think it is worth spelling these out. The new policies as they affect negative gearing will, I think, provide a major stimulus in the right direction for the building industry in Australia. The quarantining of building losses to investments in the building sector, coupled with the capital gains tax, the increased depreciation allowance and the incentive for people investing in the building sector to provide rental accommodation, will lead to a move away from speculation in high-cost, quick turnover profit operations such as the construction of Gold Coast luxury flats to lower-cost ordinary public or private rental accommodation. In other words, this Government is facing up to the fact that thousands of people are looking for rental accommodation at levels they can afford. They are not looking for Gold Coast luxury flats; they are looking for a place in which to live, a roof over their heads at a reasonable price, and each of these decisions will assist investment of that kind.

The capital gains tax and the quarantining of farm losses against off-farm income provides very fairly for the ordinary farmer, the ordinary person who is making a go of farming combined with an ordinary off-farm income. The only people who will be affected detrimentally by this move are those who have been offsetting very high income, income that ought to be subjected to pay as you earn tax, against farm losses. It is interesting to note the bleats of those opposite because it reveals whom they represent. They represent the very high income earners who have been using farming operations as tax shelters. That is why they are so upset about the measure.

The fringe benefit and capital gains taxes are reasonable. They address the fact that the system has come under pressure and they will stimulate productive investment in the right areas. I refer to an article published in the Age news- paper in Melbourne this morning. The owner of one of the restaurants that has been providing the business lunch over the years says that his restaurant will not be providing such lunches any more. Here I come to an interesting quotation. The proprietor says of his restaurant:
Here is where some of the biggest deals in Melbourne were made. Deals that generated productivity and jobs. Deals like the Collins Place project were closed in this room.

Here we are being told that multi-million dollar business deals occurred because people were able to have a tax deductible lunch. I have to say that I regard that as nonsense. In my view the restaurants that have been providing this business trade will continue to provide it. There will be a short lived knee-jerk reaction from those who have just lost a 60c in the dollar tax reduction for a business lunch, but if those lunches have been profitable to business people they will continue to have them because they are not going to give up multi-million dollar deals just because they have lost a bit of cream on the cake in the form of a tax deduction.

TALK.START.PARA: —People are still going to eat.
—They still have to eat and they will continue to eat at the levels at which they have been eating in the past, as my colleague the honourable member for Kingston has just reminded me.

SPEECH.PARA: I make the point also that the introduction of the capital gains tax produced a reaction one day before the tax was announced. That gives an indication of the level at which people in this sophisticated industry move.

Honourable members may have noted that $30m worth of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd shares were purchased the day before the capital gains tax was announced. That was $30m worth of shares in one hit. People bought those shares because they were aware that every asset owned before the introduction of the tax would not come within the scope of the new legislation. That legislation refers only to assets bought and resold at some time in the future. Those people knew that if they moved quickly to buy shares on Thursday those shares would never be affected by the new legislation. That is the sort of sophistication I am talking about. When ordinary workers can put together $30m and make a fly such as that they, too, will realise the way in which big business moves and the way in which big business is affected by some of these changes.

To reiterate the comments of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), not one dollar of these tax reform measures will remain in government coffers. They are all being turned around and repaid to the community in a redistribution that provides for a genuine attack on poverty, increases in benefits for pensioners and other social security beneficiaries and, most importantly, cuts in pay as you earn taxes and improved incentives for the business sector. I refer in particular to the tax deduction for imputed business dividends. It all fits together as a neat package and will lead, I think, to an era of increased business investment in the productive sector which will be to the benefit of this whole community.

I wish now to make a brief point about the National Taxation Summit because I believe that process was a valuable one. The honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) made the point in his speech a moment ago that the National Taxation Summit derived from the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in Perth when he promised that we would have a tax summit. What the honourable member passed over, however, was the other event that occurred in Perth and which, in fact, draws to our attention this whole problem in the tax system. I believe the really significant event in Perth occurred in 1973 when the Commissioner of Taxation discovered the bottom of the harbour scheme as it related to events in the office of the Perth Crown Solicitor.

What did honourable members opposite do when they were in government? They did nothing from 1973 until they lost office in 1983. They did not do one thing about that appalling rip-off of the Australian tax system. Not only did they do nothing; they are also extremely guilty of an even worse offence. They encouraged the attitude of non-compliance. They created the loopholes approach. They did nothing about solicitors and accountants finding loopholes in the system. They did nothing to make the Attorney-General press these claims. They did nothing to introduce legislation in this House until they were put under incredible pressure and they knew they were about to lose the election. They did nothing. They encouraged non-compliance. They encouraged tax cheating in Australia. They are the ones who created the mentality. They are the ones who in time, must look back in shame at their performance. I will wind up my comments by quoting from the speech of the Treasurer on the night he introduced the tax reform package. He said:

. . . the Government has confronted the issue of tax reform. We have been willing to consult with the people of Australia. We have been willing seriously and responsibly to consider the issues involved and we have been willing to take hard decisions . . . The Government is confident that the people of Australia will recognise that these significant measures are taken in the best interests of the nation and for the greater good of every individual Australian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) who has just resumed his seat knows as much about how the taxation package will affect farm industries as he does about what the former Government did to try to overcome the tax rort-the bottom of the harbour tax avoidance devices. Legislation was introduced into this House on the most extensive scale ever to come to grips with the tax fraud in this country. Even the Minister for Trade, the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins), has admitted that both in this Parliament and outside it. The honourable member for Burke therefore should eat his words.

SPEECH.PARA: The taxation statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is the result of months of wheeling and dealing with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. We were all witness to the debacle of the taxation summit of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). While speaker after speaker mounted the rostrum in this place to make his or her voice heard as to whether we should have option A, B, C, D or some other taxation scheme, deals were going on behind their backs with the power brokers of the ACTU. At times not even the Treasurer knew what was going on and where his favoured option C was going to end up. We all know that the Prime Minister and his mates of the ACTU effectively pulled the chain on option C at a clandestine meeting which took place behind the Treasurer's back.

The National Taxation Summit had degenerated into a debacle of major proportions and the Prime Minister was desperate to stitch up the mess, regardless of the Treasurer's passionate support for option C. In the end Australians have ended up with what was acceptable to the ACTU bosses. The Prime Minister bravely said in support of his Treasurer in June that he would be willing to sacrifice government in order to secure meaningful tax reform. He said:

Well, if it costs me government . . . I would do it, because I don't want to take the easy way out . . . If we pay a political price well, okay, but if I believe that in the longer term Australia is going to be better off, that's the course I'll take.

We have ended up with an attack on the capital base of small business and the farmers of Australia. The taxpayers have ended up with a long term promise of reductions in the marginal rates of personal income tax the full benefit of which is not likely to eventuate for two years down the track, even if it eventuates then. It is not the option that the Treasurer sought. It is a stitched up expedient taxation regime to satisfy the ever greedy demands of the ACTU bosses-demands to satisfy the wants of today at the expense of the welfare of people tomorrow. When the Treasurer learned that the deal had been done he commented on his tax cart which the Prime Minister had deserted by saying:
It's a bit like Ben Hur's; we got across the line with one wheel off.

We have a tax regime designed presumably to save the sacred prices and incomes accord with the ACTU. The accord with its full indexation, promises of compulsory employer superannuation contributions and other on-wage goodies will undoubtedly be paid for by future generations. As the union demands are met under the accord, our balance of trade deteriorates, our national and foreign debt climbs, our real interest rates reach record levels and our competitiveness as a nation shrinks.

The accord has assured that we will continue to live beyond our means but the day of reckoning will come to our children. `Live for today and to hell with tomorrow' should be the motto of this Government and its ACTU masters. Let our children and their children pay for our indulgences with lower living standards and mounting interest and debt repayments.

This ragbag of tax proposals will strike at the very foundations of the farming and small business sectors. The promised personal income tax cuts are to be funded by taxing employers on fringe benefits provided to hard working loyal employees, quarantining farm losses, negative gearing taxation on rental properties and capital gains taxation. The tax on fringe benefits to employees will result in removing special relationships between small business and farmer employers and their staff benefits often paid to employees who have given loyal service to their employers. Labor will ultimately remove these provisions, no doubt to be replaced by special arbitrated allowances payable to all employees whether they earned it or not.

The impact of the capital gains tax and the quarantining of farm losses will have a devastating long term effect on the capital structure of agriculture. This is not a political statement or scare tactics on my part. It is a view shared not only by the organisations representing these industries and a wide cross-section of the accountancy profession, but also by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics.

This blow to farmers could not have struck at a worse time for them. A BAE survey of some 130,000 farm businesses revealed an average debt load of $53 000, with the wheat belt farmers in Western Australia carrying an average debt load of $148 000. The capital gains tax will be levied at the marginal income tax rates, and the BAE points out that this discriminates against farmers holding single assets for long periods compared with those holding more liquid assets over the short term. In other words, the new tax regime once again penalises those generating real economic wealth and export income. It should concern all Australians as this nation plunges deeper and deeper into its foreign debt quagmire. It should be borne in mind that returns to farm capital are averaging about one-sixth of the current return to savings bank deposits.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us why.

—The honourable member for Hunter should ask his Minister. He will give him a lesson on it. Indeed, the real net value of farm production is expected to fall by a further 22 per cent this year. My office alone has received some 2,000 written protests against the capital gains tax.
—What did the Minister try to do about it?

—I do not know. I cannot speak for him, but he ought to speak for himself at some time. Perhaps the worst feature is the depressing effect of the tax on farm investment incentive. Long term gain in the value of farm property in many cases is the only real financial attraction to farming. Family farms comprise 90 per cent of all farm establishments and in most cases the farm property is their largest financial commitment. With record farm borrowings, any further erosion of land values will threaten the security of not only the farmers, but also the financial institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: The accountancy firm of Peat Marwick Mitchell and Co. has carried out a study of the tax liability that would accrue from the Government's capital tax on some selected properties. The figures show that a property in the New South Wales wheat belt which cost $80,000 in 1976 would have been liable for a tax payment of $26,000 if sold in 1984. The Government cannot hide from the discriminatory effects of this tax, which is certain to stifle capital investment in agriculture. The quarantining of farm losses from profits off-farm beyond the specified limit will compound the problem. It will dry up interest and investment in rural properties, accelerating a fall in land values. Income derived from off-farm work or other sources amounted to $7,600 per farm in 1982-83, representing one-third of average farm income.

The Government in its desperate effort to satisfy the demands of the Australian Council of Trade Unions has not studied the consequences of its package on agriculture. It seems to be unaware of the tremendous changes which have taken place in agriculture over the past two decades-the intense reconstruction involving aggregation of farms and the rising level of investment by people with outside resources and outside capital for investment. The widespread incidence of external farm income demonstrates that many family farmers have invested or worked off-farm in order to survive in financial circumstances where there has been an annual decline of about 2 per cent in their terms of trade.

I want to debunk the myth that Pitt Street or Collins Street farmers are somehow ripping off the system. They have invested millions of dollars into wealth-producing farm enterprises, which has helped to maintain rural land values and hold up the security against which all farmers have borrowed. Prudent family farmers who are earning substantial income off-farm are making a major contribution towards the development of efficient low cost broad acre farming and the development of industries such as grain, oilseed and cotton production, which are highly capital intensive and which require enormous capital outlays.

TALK.START.PARA: —Providing employment.

—Absolutely. They provide employment in country towns and for country businesses generally. These industries are high export income earners. Governments have acted to reduce effective assistance to Australian agriculture. There has been a two-thirds cut over the past decade in effective assistance, which is twice the rate of the cuts made to manufacturing industries. The Hawke Government has reduced Budget expenditure for primary industries by an accumulated $442m since 1983. The Government has systematically discriminated against the farmers with its fiscal and monetary policies. No sector is suffering more economic hardship than farmers and small business people. This quarantining proposal will compound the problems generated by the severe restrictions imposed on tax averaging and the tax benefits of income equalisation deposits since 1983.

SPEECH.PARA: Where is the equity for farmers when BHP-the big Australian-can offset losses in the steel division against profits from Bass Strait oil? Where is the equity when the proprietor of multiple retail outlets can offset losses against profits, but genuine primary producers are slugged with a new tax burden?

TALK.START.PARA: —They hate the farmers.

—They hate the farmers. The Treasurer makes no attempt to assess the cost of these changes in terms of declining investment, falling land values, rural adjustment and social welfare outlays. Foreign interests must be eagerly awaiting a chance to buy up cheap, highly productive agricultural land in Australia. Already this is happening in Western Australia. The discriminatory nature of quarantining of farm losses is highlighted by the fact that negative gearing proposals on rental properties will apply only to properties purchased after 17 July 1985.

SPEECH.PARA: I might say that the Treasurer today quite deliberately avoided answering the substance of my question during Question Time. He would not answer the question, and he has a good reason for not doing so. Quarantining of farm losses will apply to all properties from 1 July 1986 regardless of when these properties were purchased. It therefore has a distinct retrospective element. It is estimated that one in four Australian farmers in 1983-84 needed off-farm income to stay on the land, despite the fact that the drought had broken.

TALK.START.PARA: —What percentage?

—One in four. Labor justifies its action by attacking Pitt Street and Collins Street farmers, but these are investors who buy and develop land which in many cases would otherwise remain undeveloped. Their investment is helping maintain land prices and is bolstering regional economies through expenditure on farm inputs and services. This investment is especially important with rural unemployment already at 27 per cent. As the National Farmers Federation has warned:

SPEECH.PARA: Valuable investment in new agricultural enterprises will dry up. The investment funds will go to the many other high risk, initially low return on capital areas of investment in the economy.

The cost to farmers of quarantining off-farm income has been estimated by the Government at $105m in 1987-88 and $75m for the years thereafter. In addition to the anti-farm tax trifecta, we find the provision for the immediate write-off in the year of expenditure of on-farm water conservation improvements which are critical to their ability to withstand future droughts.

The taxation statement is a thinly veiled assault on the farm industries, small businesses and country people generally. Labor's discrimination against country people is abundantly clear. The Sydney Daily Telegraph yesterday questioned the fairness of continuing a 120 per cent investment allowance for film makers when compared to the changes affecting farmers. The report concluded:
One wonders whether the Treasurer considers that the film industry, and not the farming industry, is the backbone of our nation.

Labor is at war with farmers. If Labor thinks it can go on bleeding the productive enterprises of the Australian economy without causing immense long term economic damage, it is living in a fool's paradise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tax reform has been introduced in this country not because of the wishes of the Australian Council of Trade Unions or because of the accord or any other single element in this community. It has come about principally because of the deficiencies in the current income tax system. The current income tax system was collapsing under the strain of avoidance and pressure on wage and salary earners.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a sharp contraction in the relative contribution to income tax revenue from the upper income ranges. In 1984-85 income tax assessed to individual earning more than 1.6 times average earnings accounted for approximately 21 per cent of the total net tax assessed. In 1954-55 the comparable figure was 54 per cent. That situation could not continue. While deficiencies in our tax law, supported by a number of High Court decisions provided the opportunity for widespread avoidance and evasion, there is no doubt that the incentive of high marginal rates applying to an ever increasing proportion of taxpayers also contributed to major problems in the area of tax. Increasing levels of tax avoidance and evasion increased resentment on the part of those taxpayers, mainly pay as you earn employees, including my constituents, who had to bear an ever increasing share of the total tax burden.

It is important that the current tax reform package be evaluated against the reality that the existing system was becoming unworkable and was doing increasing damage to our economy. A central feature of the existing system was that it allowed many sections of the community to benefit, in an unintended manner, at the expense of others. The distortions which allowed this to occur are typically also features of the tax system which are damaging to economic growth. Any significant reform of the tax system will inevitably produce short term winners and losers, although these effects can often be cushioned to some extent by appropriate transitional arrangements. Equally, a soundly based reform will lead to a larger economic cake which will, in the medium to longer term, benefit all Australians. That is what this tax package is all about. It is not just directed at today. It is directed at providing a stable economic base for this country in future.

The tax issue has been talked about and reviewed over and over again during the last decade, but very little action has followed. There has been inquiry after inquiry-the Asprey Taxation Review Committee, the Mathews Committee of Inquiry into Inflation and Taxation and the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System have all contributed to this debate on the tax issue. There have been reforms in the United States of America, New Zealand and Ireland. We have had the White Paper on the subject, the National Taxation Summit, and finally we had the tax reform package which was introduced only a few weeks ago. So the community cannot say that it was not fully consulted on these issues. In fact, it has been very difficult to go through the whole process of consultation with the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the restaurants?

—I will come to the restaurant industry in a moment. In fact, I have had considerable consultations with the restaurant industry just today. This is a significant tax reform package. It significantly reduces marginal tax rates, it curtails tax avoidance and evasion and restores fairness to the tax system and it gears the tax system for economic growth by providing greater rewards for initiative. By any of these standards the package introduced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is fundamental tax reform. One of the most significant areas that is of great benefit to my constituents is the tax cut of half a billion dollars that we will be giving the Australian people in 1986-87.
—Who will get it?

—The people who will mainly get it will be my constituents-those people who have been PAYE workers and who have been making substantial contributions to the tax coffers. It is they who will be getting the benefits, because they will no longer be paying the high marginal tax rates, which will be significantly reduced. We are reducing that top rate of income tax from 60c in the dollar to 49c, which is a significant change. The intermediate rate of personal income tax will be reduced from 46c to 40c. These tax cuts will be paid for not by increasing the deficit, but by further expenditure restraint-a matter about which the coalition has talked but never had much success in delivering. Putting the matter in simple terms, we, the Labor Government, are giving the average Australian taxpayer a $15.20 a week tax cut. These measures do not stifle enterprise and initiative, as the Opposition claims, but enhance them. It is those people who have been fair taxpayers and who have been making such a great contribution to the tax coffers, without any of the rorts or tax shelters, who will benefit substantially from this tax reform package.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the areas I would like to address is entertainment expenses. The non-deductibility of entertainment expenses has attracted considerable criticism, some of which I have been exposed to just today from the restaurant industry. The first point to note in this debate is that the line between expenses incurred in providing income and personal expenses is blurred in a number of areas, not just in respect of entertainment. For example, in many private and public organisations employees are expected to maintain a certain standard of dress, but generally are not allowed an income tax deduction, while employees required to wear a uniform are allowed a deduction. The entertainment area, however, is a difficult one in which to draw the line. While the Government recognises that entertainment expenditure can assist business operations, it requires only a moment's thought and consideration for Opposition members and other members of this House to realise that administrative and conceptual difficulties would be involved in isolating for tax purposes the component of entertainment outlays comprising legitimate business expenses. We have yet to see a workable set of guidelines. As the Treasurer has put it, how can the Commissioner of Taxation be expected to verify whether two people having lunch together talk business? In reality, the choice lies between allowing all entertainment expenditure to be deductible and allowing none. In the Government's view, the equity and efficiency of the tax system are better served by the latter.

The abolition of entertainment expenses as a business deduction has understandably provoked loud complaints from the restaurant and hospitality industry. The claims about massive job losses concentrated among young people are obvious exaggerations. At this stage it is impossible to assess the impact that it would have. That is not to deny that reductions in the level of business expenditure on entertainment will affect the restaurant industry, especially in the short term. However, I believe that the effects, particularly in an area like Canberra, have been overstated. We are not forcing business people out of restaurants; we are saying to them that no longer will those lunches be subsidised by the taxpayers of Australia-that is all. It is difficult to estimate the size of this effect. For many businesses their existing practices are a fact of life and they will absorb the lost deduction and continue as before. Many people who have been doing business over lunch will continue exactly as they did before. Some others will choose to adjust, principally in the degree of lavishness, which could mean a shift in the pattern of market demand. Of one thing we can be absolutely certain-any restaurant closures in the foreseeable future will be blamed entirely on the tax reform package. As many honourable members know, there are consistent changes in this industry, and many people go broke for all sorts of reasons and would do so whether or not a tax reform package was in existence.

Any short run losses in the restaurant industry have to be viewed as one of the necessary costs of obtaining a fairer tax system. The fairness of the tax system should be particularly emphasised. This measure illustrates one of the difficulties of achieving tax reform. The losses are concentrated and are happening now, while the benefits will be widely spread and difficult to perceive and are for the most part in the future. Put another way, tax reform is, in part, an investment which requires incurring some costs now in order to obtain greater benefits in the future. I think that commitment to the future is important. It is also important that we as politicians, particularly those of us on the Labor benches, go out and defend the Government's position on this tax package because of the equity and other considerations for the future that will be ensured by this tax package. The business community as a whole has condemned aspects of the package. However, I would like to point out that this ignores a number of other aspects of the package. Business groups should start examining all aspects to assess its impact.

The decision to introduce imputation of dividends has been soundly welcomed by the share market. This decision will discourage traditional share market speculation. It will encourage investment in shares that seem to have the quality of paying consistently reasonable dividends. It will encourage companies, after so many years of decadent signals, to restore an emphasis on sensible dividend policies and sustainable yields. The important thing will once again be to establish a dividend position. There will now be a rational balance between various categories of investment. Some sanity will be restored to the share market.

The nation as a whole will benefit from the improved position which share markets now have in relation to their competitors for the investor's dollar. All the paraphernalia which has been set up to exploit the ramshackle structure of the previous tax system will become irrelevant. People will invest in equities on their own merits in terms of yield and growth. More importantly, companies which for years have been forced to devote desperate attention to the idea of capital gains can now concentrate more effectively on actual returns. As one share broker stated: `The genie is out of the bottle. The champagne corks may not be popping in the restaurant industry but they will be in share brokers' offices. What has been the share market's response since the tax package was announced? It has been record trading, record trading and more record trading. The dries in the Opposition have seen their own idol, the share market, give the tax package its full vote of confidence.

A tax system which encourages people to spend or invest their money in certain ways merely to reduce the tax they pay reduces the efficiency of the economy and causes it to grow more slowly than it otherwise would. I know it is hard for many members of the Opposition benches to comprehend, but this package means that our economy will be more efficient-that is, it will grow faster. Investment decisions will be made on the basis of profitability rather than tax advantage.

The Government has delivered to business the highest profits share since the 1960s. Business profits have increased after tax by $6.5 billion in the last two years. This package reduces that by only half a billion dollars, and this revenue is being channeled back into the community to promote further growth. The Government has delivered 2 1/2 years of industrial peace and two more years are coming up. Wages growth has been restrained and the parameters have been set for a continuation of 5 per cent economic growth. To describe the Hawke Labor Government as anti-business is ludicrous.

To sum up, the tax reform package will consolidate the economic growth that this Government has delivered since it has been in government. It will provide a system which will be much more equitable. It is now setting the basis on which people can make sensible, rational decisions about investment instead of just looking at tax avoidance measures. It will ensure that the pay as you earn taxpayers of Australia, those people who, over the years, have borne the burden of tax reform, particulary those in the top income range, will now get certain relief. I congratulate the Treasurer on this tax package. Although in the short term there will be some problems, particularly in the restaurant industry, I am sure that in the long term we will ensure economic growth and an equitable tax system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly), who has just spoken, got first hand experience today as to what the restaurant industry thinks about the tax package. The effect that it will have on that industry was put to her in no uncertain terms. Until today restaurants were considered to be part of our fast-growing industry. I will come back to that point in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: The second observation I want to make on the tax package is the extraordinary sensitivity of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on the matter. The honourable gent comes into this House and adopts his usual pratice of trying to pour scorn and invective on any views that differ from his own. I notice that he particularly adopts this attitude in respect of members of his own Party who dare to express a view different from his own. There are plenty of those members-the fourth formers he calls them. The Treasurer stands up, turns around and peers down his long nose as if anyone who dares to differ with him must be wrong.

There are a few things going against the Treasurer right now. The first one is the poor example set by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), his own boss, who cannot run his own Department. That criticism might not seem very relevant at the moment. However, the relevance is this: When things are going bad in any endeavour in life people look at the top. If things are not run properly at the top, everyone down the line is affected. If the Prime Minister is seen as incompetent, the Treasurer sooner or later will also be seen as incompetent. That is the first strike that the Treasurer has going against him.

The second strike against the Treasurer is his inability to get his policies through his Party. One has to look back only to the tax summit to see that. One has to look only at this tax package which is a half-baked mish-mash made up of a bit here and a bit there-some of which the Treasurer would like and most of which the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the unions would like.

The third strike, of course, is the predominant role that the unions play in this Government. Whether one likes it or not, there is a clear perception among the majority of Australians that the unions are running the Government. One only has to go out and ask the people to establish that this is the case. Just a few months ago every paper in the country reported the spectacle of the Prime Minister sneaking across town in the middle of the night to get some agreement from the ACTU. Of course, the Prime Minister did not take the Treasurer with him. However, he came back and told him just what the deal was. That is the third strike that the Treasurer has going against him. All of those criticisms are fairly formidable in terms of the honourable gentleman presenting himself as a competent Treasurer in a competent Government.

The Opposition is clearly opposed to elements of this tax package, and for very good reason. Indeed, members of the Opposition are not the only people to express opposition. Let me quote what was said by John Stone at a recent seminar which I attended. This is the fellow who worked for the Government; the Treasurer's right hand man. Let me tell the House what he had to say to the Australian Travel Industry Association Convention. Mr Stone called on the Government to reconsider the tax package. He talked about the spirit of anti-business vengefulness. He said:

Measures contained in the tax package . . . might gratify the class war hatreds of those in the ACTU and the Left and the Centre Left factions of the Parliamentary Labor Party but they were unworthy of a Governmemt which originally appealed to Australia in 1983 with the slogan of bringing Australia together.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was speaking in a telephone box.
—It was not a telephone box-he got a standing ovation from those who attended the convention. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: They would prove to have the most damaging economic consequences.

How right he was. Let me turn to the effect that the tax package will have on tax deductions for entertainment which are now to be disallowed. We have heard all the Labor rhetoric, mainly from senior Ministers, of rorts and bludgers. We have heard the abusing, insulting, penalising and condescending comments that have been directed at the wrong people. Those comments have been directed at those involved in the restaurant and catering industry. However, why should the comments not be directed at those who are abusing the system? The honourable member for Canberra, above all, knows that the people in the restaurant and catering industry are very angry at the implications which are being laid at their door. If I were she, I would beat a hasty path to the Ministers who are using those expressions and tell them: `For God's sake, use sensible language and stop insulting the people who have built up an industry in this country to meet a market'. If the Government wants to get into the rorters and the bludgers, it should direct its attention to the people who are abusing the system and get off the backs of the restaurant and catering industry. What is happening is that already 3,000 people have been laid off in Australia since 19 September. Over 2,000 apprentices are at risk in Victoria alone.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two thousand apprentices in Victoria?

—They are at risk. It is estimated by the industry that by February next year between 10,000 and 30,000 people might be out of a job. Even if it is 10,000 people, can honourable members imagine the uproar there would be in the car industry if 10,000 people were to be laid off? Of course, many of these people will be forced to go on the dole, with the accompanying expense. This week's survey by the Restaurant and Catering Association of Victoria states:

SPEECH.PARA: Over the last week we have carried out an independent survey of 130 restaurants. It reveals that business has declined to the point where at least 1,000 restaurant workers have already been sacked.
Let me go on and quote what some of the individual restaurateurs who were interviewed have said. One of the restaurateurs stated:

We have already laid off four staff and if this tax package goes ahead I'll be laying them all off. I'm now employing 15 people but if things don't improve I'll have to let them all go and just run the business with members of my family.
Maybe Mr Keating can tell me who I should fire first- the young apprentice trying to learn a trade or my chef who's got debts and a family to raise.
Another restaurateur has said:
As far as the hospitality industry goes, the kids going through the William Angliss College just don't have a chance.
Another restaurateur said:

I don't think he realises that it's not just us that will be affected but the dry food industry, meat, fish, paper with serviettes and laundry as we won't be using as much of these things as we used to. Everyone connected with the restaurant or catering industry will be affected.
The comments go on and on. I come back to Mr Stone, so beloved of the Labor Party. Speaking about the removal of business expenses, he said:
``. . . a model on how to write propaganda, rather than how to present a logical and reasoned case for a serious proposal by a Government which still wants to be taken seriously.
Senator Walsh has referred to:
. . . bludgers who have free lunches.

That is how he described the business community. That is Senator Walsh's opinion of the business community. On the best figures I can obtain-and I think the Treasurer agrees-may- be 15 per cent of business lunches are illegal. The Government is destroying an industry and putting thousands of people out of work to catch that 15 per cent, which can easily and should be taken care of through the tax system by making people vouch with receipts.

TALK.START.PARA: —How?
—The same as any other business expense.
—How?

—If the honourable member does not understand that, it is a bit late for me to explain it to him now. The Treasurer, in answering questions yesterday, virtually called people in the restaurant industry crooks and thieves. That is making them very angry. They should respond vigorously, and today in Canberra they did. I hope that such meetings will be held around Australia. This industry has been meeting the market. They are not part of the Treasurer's so-called rort. He should be moving to stop the abuses by those who are abusing the system through the tax system. The decision on this matter has been based wholly on figures which are nothing but guesswork. The Treasurer has said that deductions will be denied for genuine business expenses. What are the figures? How come the decision was made so hastily? If the Government were going to affect seriously one of the other industries in Australia, it would phase in the changes and give people some warning. In this case, without warning, bang-
—Rubbish!
—Of course the Government would do that if the changes affected the car industry in the honourable member's electorate.
—If it is tax avoidance you cut it out straight away.

—The honourable member knows nothing. There will be a spin-off effect on the hotels and resorts. They are all waiting to see what will happen before deciding whether they will go ahead with certain projects. Time does not permit me to dwell any longer on that point. It is very serious for the economy of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say a few words about the effect on rural industries and limiting the use of off-farm income against farm losses. Does the Government realise the huge amount of off-farm money which is going to the development of our rural industry? In many cases in Australia there would be no development in parts of Australia without such money. Does the Government realise how many people can remain on the land only because they have access to off-farm income? One must ask the question: Does the Government really want to see more rural de-population? That is what will happen if we pick out the rural industry. No other industry is being subjected to this imposition. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), who is sitting at the table, knows in his heart what will happen in rural areas. He knows how much off-farm income goes into the development of rural industries in Australia and how productive that has been in many parts of Australia. Today someone stupidly talked about macadamia nuts. What about the big expensive rural industries in this country?

Let me talk briefly about the racing industry and what the effects will be there. How will we develop? In the Budget the Government was as proud as punch about what it is doing for the racing industry. Now that it is limiting off-farm income, what does it think will happen? If the Government wants to know, it should try asking Mr Ken Cox of the Stockwell Stud or Colin Hayes what they think about what the Government has done to the racing industry. I have quotes of what they have said. Honourable members can come and read them.

I mention some of the other elements of the tax package. The fringe benefits tax is contrary to the very basic element of tax laws, which is to tax the recipient. The reason that was not done is quite simple. It is that the unions would not allow it. The stupidity of a capital gains tax being imposed in a young country which is desperately crying out for capital investment and the encouragement of entrepreneurs is obvious. On balance, the capital gains tax will be a disaster. The one advantage I can see of the great tax cuts, about which the honourable member for Canberra was talking, is two years away. In that time most people in Australia will have moved into a higher income bracket and, of course, they will not get the benefit. The only hope for this tax package is that, on past performance, it will be changed. I sincerely hope that it will be. If it is not, it will have dire economic consequences. Judging on the way the Labor Party runs these things, I hope and think that we will see significant changes before these measures are put into effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support unequivocally the tax reform proposals outlined in the statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in this House on 19 September this year. I hope that the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) remains in the House, because I have a few comments to make about certain campaign promises and statements that were made during the 1981 by-election for the seat of McPherson. I am proud to be a member of the Labor Government which is implementing the most comprehensive tax reform measures since the 1940s, when the income tax powers were transferred from the States to the Commonwealth. In stark contrast, the members of the Liberal and National parties have whinged, whined and opposed every progressive tax reform proposal this Government and this Treasurer have put forward.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at their record on taxation when they were in government. Let us look at the record of the Fraser Government when the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was Treasurer and in control of Australia's taxation policy. In 1977 the Liberal Party of Australia won an election with the `fistful of dollars' television commercials. The current Leader of the Opposition promised to provide full indexation of the tax scales and an additional income tax cut. Honest John broke both promises. Not only were the tax cuts taken away and tax indexation abandoned but a temporary income tax levy was applied to all Australians in Honest John's first Budget. It was a retrospective income tax levy. Treasurer Howard promised that the 1.5 per cent levy would be lifted after 12 months. Honest John broke that promise as well. The 1.5 per cent levy was not removed after 12 months; it was actually increased to 2.75 per cent.

Under the current Leader of the Opposition ordinary wage and salary earners were slugged with high income taxes and promise after promise was broken. While ordinary pay as you earn taxpayers were being slugged, the tax avoidance industry was booming. Under Treasurer Howard the tax avoidance industry was Australia's only growth industry as the economy was squeezed into the most devastating recession since the Great Depression.

When the McCabe-Lafranchi report documented the bottom of the harbour tax scandal the Leader of the Opposition dismissed it as a stunt. Commissioner Costigan and the Auditor-General also detailed the tax rorts which had developed because Treasurer Howard had failed to act. The tax avoidance industry spread throughout the high income brackets like a plague communicated by the smart spiv accountants and lawyers. As Treasurer Howard refused to act on the advice of the Australian Taxation Office, the plague spread and more of the taxation burden had to be placed on low and middle income earners because of the honourable member for Bennelong's inaction. That is the Opposition's record of achievement on tax reform. It is a record of broken promises, a record of higher income taxes for ordinary Australians and a record of failing to act to close off the tax evasion and tax avoidance.

In 1954 taxpayers with incomes of more than 1.6 times average weekly earnings paid 53 per cent of individual income tax receipts. By the end of Treasurer Howard's stewardship the top brackets contributed only 21 per cent of income tax receipts. Even though inflation was pushing people into higher tax brackets when the Leader of the Opposition was in control, high income earners paid a decreasing share of tax. Middle and low income earners had to make up the difference when high income earners turned to their accountants to minimise their tax. Income tax was virtually optional for high income earners by the time of the 1983 election.

Let me now turn to Treasurer Keating's proposals to reform the Australian taxation system. Every member of this House appears to agree that tax reform is needed but every special interest group insists that it not be affected in any detrimental way. The tax on fringe benefits is a courageous measure and it has my full support. Why should my constituents pay tax on every dollar of their income simply because they are ordinary middle income earners while some of the constituents of the previous speaker, the honourable member for McPherson, pay tax only on part of their income because they happen to be company executives?

In my electorate low and middle income earners do not have the option of receiving their pay in a package designed so that a third of their income is tax free. High income earners and their employers are the only ones who will be affected by the fringe benefits tax. In my opinion they deserve to be affected because they have an obligation, the same as every other Australian, to pay their fair share of tax. The Treasurer is proposing that all pay their fair share.

I am pleased that while the Opposition whinges in this House about the fringe benefits tax its Federal President, Mr John Valder, has different views. Earlier this year he was very candid on the private Westpac video show when he was asked to comment on the proposed fringe benefits tax. He stated:

I think again to reverse the whole disease if you like to call it, of fringe benefits which again has developed over a decade or more. I think Paul Keating is being very foolish and taking a massive risk in attempting to reverse that in one stroke. But if one attempted to reverse that in a series of strokes over three or four years, then I think it could be done and I've got to say I think that is the fair and just thing in this country.

The Federal President of the Liberal Party, Mr Valder, in his private and candid moments, was honest enough to say that the fringe benefits tax is fair and just for this country. Mr Valder exposes the hypocrisy and sham of the conservatives. In private they agree with our tax reform proposals but in public, to score a few cheap political points, they cave in and oppose the reforms.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are never game to do anything.

—That is right. As the honourable member for Eden-Monaro says, they are never game to implement any of their own policies. This Labor Government believes it is wrong that high income earners should be able to use tax shelters which low and middle income earners could never afford to use. My constituents, and the vast majority of Australians, cannot afford to run a farm at a massive loss just to reduce their income tax as can the Pitt and Collins Street farmers. My constituents and the vast majority of Australians cannot afford to divert income into afforestation, petroleum exploration, water conservation or negatively geared home units on the Gold Coast in the honourable member for McPherson's electorate. My constituents have not been rorting the system and using these tax shelters. They applaud this Government and this Treasurer's proposals to re-establish a fair and equitable taxation system.

SPEECH.PARA: While very few of my constituents have been disadvantaged by the closing off of tax loopholes, tens of thousands of them will benefit from the $2 billion worth of income tax cuts which will be implemented on 1 September 1986 followed by a second round of income tax cuts to be implemented on 1 July 1987 totalling $4.5 billion. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table detailing the income tax cuts.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. In September 1986 the tax free threshold will be raised from $4,595 to $5,100. By 1 July 1987 the top marginal rate will have been slashed from 60 per cent to 49 per cent. I have been contacted by several constituents and pensioner organisations in my electorate regarding the tax free threshold. While the tax free threshold is currently $4,595, single pensioners and veterans earning up to $5,533 pay no tax because they benefit from the $250 tax rebate in addition to the tax free threshold. Media reports that the tax free theshold will be raised for all taxpayers to $5,100 have confused pensioners who currently pay no tax while earning up to $5,300. The $250 pensioner tax rebate will, of course, continue to be granted to pensioners. As a result of the tax reform measures, after 1 September 1986 single pensioners and veterans will be able to earn $6,142 before paying tax. That is, pensioners and veterans will be entitled to earn an additional $609 before they pay tax. Married pensioners will also benefit in a similar way.

SPEECH.PARA: As all honourable members would be aware, the electorate of Dobell, which covers towns such as Long Jetty, The Entrance, Toukley and Budgewoi, has more pensioners than any other electorate in New South Wales. As a result my constituents, more than any others in New South Wales, welcome the relaxation of the three elements of the income test on pensioners which was announced in the Treasurer's tax reform statement. Firstly, on 1 November next year the amount which a single pensioner may earn in addition to his pension, before his or her pension will be affected, will be raised from $30 per week to $40 per week. The limit for married pensioners will be increased from $50 per week to $70 per week. Most pensioners who are receiving a part pension will benefit by $5 per week under the increase in the income limit before tax is paid.

Secondly, a very harsh, separate incomes test on rental assistance will be removed from 1 November 1986. Rental assistance of $15 per week will be added to the standard pension like other special supplements and then the general income test will be applied. Thousands of pensioners who are renting private accommodation and are currently ineligible for rental assistance will benefit by up to $15 per week from this measure alone. Thirdly, pensioners with children will be able to earn an additional $6 per week for each child and receive the same assistance. A single pensioner with two children in private rented accommodation will receive an additional $26 per week. I congratulate the Treasurer and the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) for implementing these reforms. The Minister for Social Security will be visiting my electorate later this month. I am sure that the members of my local Combined Pensioners Association will appreciate the November 1986 income test changes which the Minister has convinced the Cabinet are required.

SPEECH.PARA: After endorsing the Hawke Government's tax reforms and congratulating the Treasurer on the results he has already achieved, I ask what alternative the Opposition offers the Australian people. The Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Minister for Finance, Senator Messner, have supported the introduction of a flat tax on income. This, together with an increase in sales tax, is the Opposition's response to our tax reform proposals. I remind the House what the Leader of the Opposition thought about flat taxation in 1981 during the McPherson by-election, when the National Party developed a flat tax policy overnight in an attempt to take the seat of McPherson from the Liberals. The newspaper headlines reads `No flat tax-and that's final; and ``Blatantly discriminatory'' says Howard'. The article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 7 February 1981 states:
The Treasurer, Mr Howard, has ruled out the possibility that the Government will replace personal income tax with a flat rate tax such as that advocated by the National Country Party.
For a stinging criticism of the championing of the flat tax proposal by the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, Mr Howard said yesterday:
`The tax simply does not work and has the element of fairyland in it'.
The Leader of the Opposition continued:
I don't believe that the introduction of a flat rate taxation system could conceivably pass the test of equity and fairness which I regard as essential to a taxation system.
The plan is blatantly discriminatory and has a particularly severe impact on low-income and single-income families.

That is what the Leader of the Opposition thought about flat rate taxation in 1981. I will also recount the opinion of the former Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, Sir Phillip Lynch. I remind the House of what he thought of flat rate taxation. Under the headline `It's bunk! Libs blast flat tax', the article states:

The flat rate tax debate blew up into a major row between the federal coalition parties yesterday. Both the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, Sir Phillip Lynch, and the Treasurer, Mr Howard, strongly attacked the National Country Party proposal.
Sir Phillip said the proposal was `Economic bunk' and `a swindle of massive proportions'.

That article appeared in the Sun News-Pictorial on 7 February 1981. The current Leader of the Opposition was right in 1981. A flat tax would hit low and middle income earners the hardest. Flat tax policies would abolish the tax-free threshold. Currently, no taxpayer pays tax on the first $4,595 of income. After 1 September 1986, no taxpayer will pay on the first $5,100. Under a flat tax regime all income is taxable. The people who would be devastated by flat tax are the retired and pensioners. Like the flat earth theory, the flat tax theory is nothing but fantasy. On the issue of tax reform the Australian people have a clear choice: Under Labor, a package of reform, an attack on the rorts and ramps which the tax dodgers have been exploiting, $4.5 billion in tax cuts, and genuine increases in social welfare to those most in need; under the Liberals, delivered higher taxes, broken promises and a healthy tax avoidance industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to concentrate my remarks in this debate on the so-called `reform of the Australian taxation system' on the aspects of the capital gains tax proposal and its effect on small business. In doing so I thought it would be useful to look at the typical entrant into the small business sector, the reasons for entry into a business venture, the expectations of the small entrepreneur, and the likely consequences of the application of a capital gains tax.

SPEECH.PARA: I am reliably informed that the individual considering purchasing a small business-and in talking about small businesses I am referring to a business with a total value of under $200,000-will be in their 40s, have come from areas of previous employment such as banks, accountancy, the police force, the nursing profession or school teaching, or from other small business. They are likely to be married and looking to more than one member of the family being involved in the enterprise. They will have had a previous income in the vicinity of $20,000 to $25,000 and will have about $70,000 with which to purchase the business. The average purchase price for a small business in my electorate would be around $100,000, and I would think Corangamite, with its urban Geelong end, including Belmont, Highton and Grovedale, the coastal area of the Bellarine Peninsula extending to Apollo Bay, and the inner rural part centred around Colac, could be taken as a fairly average example of an electorate, excluding capital city electorates, and one in which an enormous variety of small businesses are situated. Such businesses encompass the tourism, manufacturing, service, farming, retailing and export industries.

The assets the potential purchaser is likely to have centre around the family home with a value of about $80,000 and with $20,000 owing. Our typical small business entrants will want to go into a business of their own because they will have worked for someone else for about 20 years and have now decided to become self-employed. They want to have a go, are prepared to work hard, make sacrifices, take risks, and apply their imagination and individual skills to an activity which at the end of all their efforts will reflect their personal contribution and the reward will be a profit realisation over and above their initial purchasing price. They will also want to have the business so that a spouse may be involved in the operation and quite often their children, who have left school and may be having difficulty finding a job elsewhere in this very tight labour market. It may well be seen as a way for the family to remain together. This is especially the case in provincial and rural areas, where it is almost inevitable that children will have to leave not only the family home but also their local community and even the State, in order to find employment.

We also know that our small business entrants do not normally start and finish in the same business. They will probably be involved in three or four businesses before finally realising their investment and retiring, using the end profit as a form of superannuation. During the period of his small business involvement our typical businessman will expect to work between 50 and 60 hours a week for a return of around $20,000 to $25,000-in fact, no more than the person was receiving when working a 38-hour week with little worry or responsibility. The wife or husband involved as a partner in the business will receive the same amount, but it is important to remember that their savings after tax, after living expenses and after meeting their borrowing commitments will amount to only about $5,000 each.

Their prime aim in going into the initial business was to achieve sufficient capital gain, combined with their savings, to place a deposit on a larger business. The Government's proposal to tax this capital gain will clearly act as a disincentive and inhibit the movement and development of new and improved small businesses.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has stated that a reason for this new capital gains tax was to prevent the flow of unproductive investment from property investment into more productive enterprises. It is my view that the tax, while it may inhibit property investment, will also inhibit investment and retard incentive in those areas where we all know investment and initiative are vital if employment opportunities are to be created and this country is to move ahead. So in this country where we need the activity and enterprise of more small business people to get the country going, we are now saying that we are further going to restrict opportunities.

Having made a major change in their lives by moving out of the security of a regular paid job, they have entered the world of risk and long hours for little gratification, only to find they are burdened with excessive regulations, massive levels of bureaucratic interference, licence fees and requirements of local, State and Federal governments. If they happen to expand and need extra employees, they find our rigid, centralised wages and industrial relations system forces them to employ people at uncompetitive rates and conditions. Now we are going to tax the last hope for small businessmen-their capital gain. This capital gains tax on small business owners is an imposition not so much on the concrete assets that they have improved with the business but on the guts, the determination and the initiative that these business people have employed to bring the business to the value it realises when they sell it. Who has helped them to build up this value? It is certainly not the Government. All the Government has done is to overtax, overlicense and overregulate them to a point where all incentive is destroyed. It is the small businessmen and businesswomen themselves who have lifted the value of their assets by their gutsy spirit, all so that the Government can raise $25m in five years time.
I turn to the tax statement itself and refer the House to the very categoric statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in relation to the capital gains tax issue. He said:
And here let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it; and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentation and distortion. There will be no new capital gains tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—It was the Prime Minister-and in September 1985 this package was presented to the House with a capital gains tax component. It has been suggested that under the capital gains tax proposal as presented in the paper the gains will be indexed to ensure that the taxing is on real gains. What will the indexing mechanism be, and will it truly reflect the inflation rate? Upon realisation, will these assets incorporate all the costs of realisation? The rate of tax as indicated by the paper will be the highest in the Western world, at company tax rates and high marginal rates. The paper indicates that it will not be a death duty, but if we read the fine print we see that it is a deferred death duty in a roll-over position. Further, with residences being excluded from the capital gains tax, we see the same problem arising that has arisen in relation to the assets test. Hopefully, capital losses will be incorporated in a true and correct manner.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Farmers Federation, which has been very active in recent months, has put a very strong point of view on behalf of the farmers of Australia. It has a membership of 100,000 to 150,000 farmers who are also small businessmen. The NFF is adamantly opposed to a capital gains tax. In long term investments with a low rate of returns, farmers are looking at something like a 30-year pay-off and would find that a capital gains tax would be the last straw in their problems. Mr McLachlan, the President of the National Farmers Federation, in observing the problem of the inflation rate and the capital gains tax that is about to be imposed, indicated the very bad effect it will have on the Australian farming community. I quote from his letter to the Australian Financial Review, in which he clearly demonstrated the anomaly that arises when the inflation rate is brought to bear on land valued in the State of New South Wales. He said:

Firstly, independent studies clearly demonstrate that rural properties have realised capital gains above inflation during most of the decade to the last year. In New South Wales for example the CPI rose 213.9 per cent between July 1976 and June 1984. Over the same period, according to the New South Wales Valuer General, western grazing lands increased in value by 334.3 per cent, other grazing lands by 280.4 per cent, wheat/sheep land by 322.5 per cent and dairy farms by 272.1 per cent.
It is therefore totally incorrect to say that farmers won't be affected by the new capital gains tax provisions.

There are two forms of capital investment. One is the speculative investment from which the Treasurer is so keen to collect some tax. The coalition is quite clear in its view that section 26AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act covers this area of speculative investment. In my view, speculative investment is good for Australia in certain areas. In the area of futures the speculator assists in evening out prices.

The coalition places great emphasis upon the productive area of capital investment. Australia needs capital. We have a population of 15 million people. We have export capital investments which support the export industries in mining and in agriculture. These are long term investments which sometimes have small rates of return. For instance, on the North West Shelf massive sums of capital have been invested, the risks have been high and there is a long term pay-off. Likewise in farming, the other important export industry, which has a high capital component, farmers are subjected to the current cost price squeeze and are now facing the possibility of a capital gains tax at the end, all for the sake of raising $25m in the fifth year of the operation of that tax.

The final point I make is that the Government is now about to put in place a mechanism for raising a capital gains tax. It has put about the view that it will be insignificant in the short term. We all know that in the longer term, once the mechanism is in place, the criteria will change and the effect of a capital gains tax will become apparent to small businessmen throughout Australia. The coalition is totally opposed to a capital gains tax. It will vote against it on this occasion and it will repeal it when it returns to government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Everybody knows the dangers inherent in taxation reform. Why else has every other government walked away from taxation reform in the past 40 years? Sure, governments have known that to ensure a prosperous and fairer Australia, taxation reform was necessary. But I guess that we Australians are more than a little selfish, and perhaps politicians who seek to retain office are a wee bit more selfish than the electorate in general. Also, the electorate is susceptible to fear and, where tax reform is concerned, it is not difficult for oppositions to spread unreasonable fear in the market-place.

SPEECH.PARA: When a taxation system is antiquated and unfair it follows that various people are advantaged by the existing scheme. Naturally, those groups can be mobilised quickly to resist reform. The groups which benefit from an unfair system are in a favourable position to spend large sums of money to preserve that system-and they do spend. They spend to preserve their advantages. They spend to protect their privileges-their avoidances, their evasions and their tax minimisation schemes. Even those who have not, the have-nots who are disadvantaged by an unfair tax system, are in a quandary. The disadvantaged know in their hearts that they are being ripped off, but they become uneasy when irresponsible Press reports and other subtle propaganda suggest that tax reform will worsen their position.

So genuine tax reform is not an easy task. Consequently, every Government member must have experienced some hesitation, some fear even, when this Labor Government embarked upon its campaign of genuine tax reform.
