Could this Government rid the taxation system of blatant abuses and create a system which was fair for all honest Australians? Would the Opposition cut the Government to pieces with distortions and half truths designed to scare the pants off the voters? Memories of the assets test were aroused. In the pre-Valder days such fears were fresh in our minds. Would a Labor government be resubjected to the greatest scare mongering campaign this nation has ever witnessed? Could this Government create a fairer tax system for all honest Australians-the haves, the pay as you earn taxpayers and the have-nots? Those of us who held such fears, however, were overlooking a couple of key points. We were overlooking the genius of the Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), and we were overlooking the dedication and expertise of those other Labor Ministers who brought their talents to bear to produce the most far-reaching reform of the Australian tax system in living memory.

The tax reform package was announced on 19 September. I waited for the fireworks to start. I waited for the Press and the Opposition to detonate the powder keg which would cause casualties amongst honourable members on this side of the House. I waited in vain. Not from the Opposition did I hear a blast reminiscent of Hiroshima or Nagasaki. Instead, I heard a bumbling burping, more akin to the fizz and flutter of a slightly dampened penny bunger. What did the Press say about Labor's reforms? In referring to the tax package, `brilliant!' said one; `The person who searches for flaws in this tax package will search in vain', said another. What did the people say? Into my electoral office poured hundreds of congratulatory letters and phone calls. There was not one message of condemnation. I passed Opposition members in the corridors of this building and their glum expressions reminded me of those famous lines of T. S. Eliot:
This is the way the world ends
not with a bang but a whimper.

My heart wept for the whimperers. My heart soared with jubilation for all honest Australians, who at long last had received a fair and just tax deal. They had at last received from a Labor government tax justice for which they had waited too darn long. However, it is hard to kill a false ideology. There is still a faint fluttering of life in those defenders of privilege-those supporters of tax cheats-who sit opposite. We have had evidence of that here today in the Opposition's amendment to the Labor Government's reform of the Australian tax system. The Opposition's amendment starts off by praising the Government. It states:
This House, whilst welcoming the promised relief of double taxation of dividends and the promised reduction in marginal tax rates . . .

Hooray, honourable members opposite praise us! Even those biased members opposite recognise and concede that Labor's reforms have good, praiseworthy features. However, honourable members opposite still seek to condemn us. How miserably their condemnations fail! Without doubt, the present Opposition is the weakest Opposition in the history of this Commonwealth. No Opposition has ever come within cooee of this Opposition's record and consistency for failure.

I ask honourable members to consider the recent record of the Opposition. Firstly, it has attempted to preserve loyalty and unity. That has been a failure. Secondly, it has attempted to prevent bitter factionalism. That has been a failure. Thirdly, it has attempted to develop coherent economic policies. That has been a failure. This Opposition's list of failures is surpassed only by its shameful record of failure when it was in Government. I am too much of a gentleman to remind honourable members opposite of their disgraceful performance which carried this nation to the brink of economic collapse.

In returning to the amendment which the Opposition has moved to what I would have to describe as the Government's immaculately beneficial tax reform package, we come to its first bleated complaint. Not surprisingly, the Opposition condemned the introduction of a capital gains tax. I will be quite honest: I too felt some concern about having a capital gains tax. I believed that a capital gains tax, although merited, could contain some electoral damage for Government members. However, the capital gains tax introduced has received overwhelming endorsement from the people of this nation. Within my electorate articles were printed in the local papers stating that I would buy a lottery ticket for any person who could prove, not to me but to the paper, that he was disadvantaged as a result of the introduction of the Government's capital gains tax. The headline read `MP puts his money where his mouth is'. Honourable members opposite probably imagine that I was inundated by a flood of claimants. However, they would be quite mistaken. I have bought not one lottery ticket. Not one person has contacted my Hunter electoral office to express concern regarding the capital gains tax. The honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) stood here and claimed that letters had flooded into his office. That is absolute bunkum. Every honourable member opposite knows that there has been a great calm and quietness out there in the electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the honourable member has cast an aspersion on the veracity of the Deputy Leader of the National Party and I ask that he withdraw.

—I withdraw. I have moved among groups from a wide social spectrum and not one word of criticism of that capital gains tax have I heard. I have been at country shows. I have mixed with people from the National Farmers Federation and from the Livestock and Grain Producers Association. This is a no-no as far as they are concerned. People who used to suck up to big business have lost its confidence. Where are they going now? They are going to try to scare the poor old farmer and try to delude and deceive him. Also they are going to try to get some support from the small business people. They are trying to get support from some other avenue.

SPEECH.PARA: The cry of the National Party is that Labor hates the farmers. What a ridiculous cry. Farmers are not fools and they will not believe that type of nonsense. Where is the anger in the electorate about a capital gains tax? Farmers and small business people know that they are better off under this Government, which is pursuing responsible economic policies, than they were under the lunatic policies of the Fraser Government when the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was Treasurer and those policies brought this country to the brink of economic disaster.

The Press has not condemned the initiative. The people have not condemned the initiative. The only people to do so are those honourable members opposite who have searched desperately and unsuccessfully to find a point of legitimate criticism about Labor's tax package. However, interesting things are happening in the post-Valder age. Post-Valder is a good title for the period. Since Mr Valder's revelation that not all members of the Liberal Party are opposed to an assets test, we find similarly that not all Liberals are opposed to a capital gains tax. In fact, recent statements by the Opposition's taxation and finance spokesman, Senator Messner, leave us in no doubt that the coalition would introduce a more severe capital gains tax than that introduced by this Labor Government. Senator Messner lends his support for the most vicious, the most punitive and most savage capital gains tax this country could possibly have. He advocates a full marginal tax rate on a full nominal gain. Senator Messner's statements deserve top marks for honesty, but reveal that the coalition's amendment to the Government's tax reform is hypocritical in the extreme.

Not surprisingly, given the form of the Opposition, there has been condemnation of this Government's attack on fringe benefits and entertainment expenses. Most unbiased Australians are fully aware of the inequity of fringe benefits and entertainment expenses and realise that there is no reason why this Government should continue to use the taxes of the poor to benefit the privileged few. Only the Opposition fails to recognise that the tax cuts will provide opportunity for entertainment expenses. I am sure that the position of restaurateurs will soon adjust itself. Need I add that the great majority of the nation, who derive no benefit from fringe benefits and entertainment expenses, will shed few tears about the removal of those privileges.

I am running out of time, but they are the two major points in the amendment moved by the Opposition. The other points in the amendment will not be dwelt on by me because they are either mischievous or untrue. For example, there is no validity whatsoever in the Opposition's claim that the tax package will have an adverse and discriminatory impact on rural Australia. Farmers are completely disillusioned with people who lie to them and appreciate, nay, applaud the honesty and the effort on their behalf by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). I am sure that farmers and the rest of the people of Australia will recognise that the hysterical and hypocritical bleatings by members of the Opposition are unworthy of serious consideration and will give enthusiastic endorsement to the Hawke Labor Government's reform of the Australian taxation system. Tax reform was needed. Everyone knew that and once again a Labor government has delivered the goods.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset of my speech, I congratulate you, Mr Deputy Speaker, on your appointment as a Deputy Chairman of Committees of this House. I am sure that you will serve in that role extremely well. The Government's tax package is a severe blow to the rural industries and small businesses of Australia. The Hawke Government has again demonstrated that it is insensitive to the needs of primary producers and those engaged in small business. Changes in the tax system which we are now debating are nothing short of clumsy and extremely negative. Major disadvantages will be imposed on primary producers, small business and those engaged in similar forms of enterprise. The honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon), who has just spoken, is completely insensitive to these major issues and has little and, obviously, limited knowledge of these matters and their effect upon the primary producer sector of the community and on the rural sector in general. The changes will stifle the already hard pressed rural communities.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed capital gains tax, which includes a deferred death duty element, will severely restrict the capacity, in terms of economic structure, of the rural industry. The imposition of taxes on employers for fringe benefits which they provide, such as subsidised housing, power, fuel, food and vehicles for family members working on farms, for share farmers and for employees, will very drastically affect the viability of many of our already hard pressed primary producers. The limiting of the amount of farm losses that can be written off against non-farm income where farmers are forced to take outside jobs to keep their farms going will be a serious imposition. Withdrawal of the write-off through tax concessions for expenditure on water conservation and water supply, for example, will be a serious impediment to the future of primary industry. Changes to the wholesale tax structures will increase costs.

The capital gains tax, although to apply only to gains on assets purchased or acquired from 19 September, will, in effect, contain a death duty element and will affect the vast majority of people in the community who enter into business from 19 September. In the March 1983 election campaign, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) stated categorically: `There will be no capital gains tax'. Again he has breached, and breached without any qualms, a firm undertaking given to the people of Australia. The statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) which we are considering says that liability for tax in the case of death will be rolled over to beneficiaries, which simply means, in effect, a deferred death duty. The stipulation appears to be that death duty will be imposed, however, if property is sold after transfer from an estate. That can impose enormous hardship on the family structure. There will be many circumstances where people of advanced age or infants, because of a death occurring in a family for a range of causes, will be seriously affected, in fact, very drastically affected by the imposition of a death duty of that kind. We will await the introduction of the legislation to discover just what the fine print tells us in this very important area of the so-called soft option on the introduction of a capital gains tax.

It is interesting to discover that the hot line so widely advertised in recent days for people to use for inquiries is unable to tell those who inquire whether property acquired in the circumstances of a contract exchanged before 19 September and payment of a deposit a day after 19 September will become the subject of capital gains in the future. The hot line-the answer to everything, according to the Treasurer-cannot tell one of my constituents the answer to that question. I hope that is something that will be cleared up during this debate. When the Treasurer replies to this debate, I ask that he specifically answer that particular question.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is only one of many.

—It is only one of many, as my colleague the honourable member for Lyne mentions. The tax on fringe benefits will seriously affect farmers and small businesses. It will increase employers' costs very drastically indeed, and this must have a flow-on adverse impact on costs as well as a subsequent inflationary effect. The limit to be imposed on the amount of farm losses that can be written off against non-farm income will hit very many small farmers severely. The reason is patently clear. The honourable member for Hunter just would not understand this aspect. Many small farmers find that, due to seasonal circumstances and unless they take outside work, there is no way they can continue to live on their farms and sustain their families. Very often, not only the farmer but also his wife find it necessary to take outside work in order to sustain a low income farm, but which is the place that they and their family live. There is no option. Do they sell? If they do sell, they suffer a severe tax imposition because of the reduced opportunity to allow off-farm income to be offset against farm costs, farm costs which are inescapable in the circumstances that arise due to whatever the nature of the seasonal conditions.

SPEECH.PARA: The sugar industry, the dairy industry and the fruit growing industry in recent times have all suffered the very severe impact of a fall in world market prices. Many of those farmers, in order to maintain their properties and to stay in existence, have had to take outside work. Naturally they have to offset their farm losses with incomes so derived. We are told that there will be an advantage because there will be a reintroduction of averaging. Those who have the responsibility in terms of an accountancy approach to assess these matters tell me that the farmers-the small farmers-of this country will still be the losers despite the endeavours of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), the Treasurer and others to state a case in support of their determination in this matter. It is a decision which I am sure will reflect as a very unsatisfactory and a very damaging implication as the whole picture of the tax reform package takes shape.

We then think, of course, of the direct impact on rural communities in terms of the changes that have immediately prevented those who see, as an essential part of the development of their small farms, the creation of an adequate water supply. As from the announcement on 19 September, no longer will there be a five-year write-off for the provision of an adequate water supply, water storage and all that goes with it. Yet we are told by this same Government-by those who sit on the front bench and by the Prime Minister-that the farmers should do more to provide for the difficulties which they encounter. It is being said: `Go out and provide water storage; provide against drought and bushfires. Don't come to us because you have problems later'. The very incentive that would make that possible has been taken away by the Government overnight without any compunction at all. So the long, sad story goes on in respect of this Government's care of the rural sector. It applies in those important matters not only to the rural sector but to the entire non-metropolitan community. Let us recall that the largest rally ever of farmers expressing concern in this nation was held outside this building on 1 July. The Prime Minister went out there and said: `I promise you a package in the Budget to meet your needs'. So what did we see? There was the Budget, a subsequent economic statement and now this tax package, and nowhere an adequate response from the Prime Minister, from the Minister for Primary Industry or from the Government in any way, shape or form that fulfils that undertaking. It is a reflection on the Government and on those on the Labor benches who support it.

This tax package turns out to be a further attempt at nothing short of dire socialisation, a stringent attempt by the Government to cover up what it had been unable to do. The tax options proposed in the great summit in this chamber have been a fizzer, and for very good reason. As the debate went on at that time, all sections of the community discovered that they were getting a raw deal. There just was not a deal in it. So the Prime Minister scampered off to the Lakeside Hotel to make a deal with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and then came back into this chamber and said-not to the Parliament but to a television audience and to other media outlets-`Ah, we have an answer to all this; we will have a different package altogether'. His Treasurer almost died of a heart attack at that moment, and it has taken him months to recover. During that recovery period he has gone for an option that is totally unsatisfactory in terms of the future management of the economy.

Let us remember that it is not only the loss of fringe benefits which the socialists, particularly the Socialist Left in this chamber, take some pride in making all sorts of assertions about. It is the impact of the loss of these fringe benefits that will be so adverse to the future of private enterprise. It has to provide the employment that is so necessary in this nation if we are to overcome the ills of unemployment and stagnation that are putting us in hock to an extent that our national debt is the highest ever. The servicing of that debt is a drag on the Budget to the extent that it is almost impossible for any economic adequacy in terms of solving the problem. When we come up with any sensible suggestion from this side of the House, it is ridiculed. It will be a short run to the time when people will realise that the four steps under the proposals in the tax changes that will take effect over the next two years will turn out to be phoney to the extent that at least a million of the taxpayers in the lower brackets will find themselves in a higher bracket. They will pay the same or more tax. The tax take will not be reduced. There is no attempt, as proposed by the coalition parties, for income splitting to assist families to give some relief of a practical kind that might help to overcome the ills or the failures of the Hawke Government which is dragging this nation into severe and irrecoverable debt. Reality must be reached. In this debate we have heard all sorts of references to taxation thus far today, but not a word about the Government's intention as to how it will reduce expenditure and, in the course of so doing, relieve the taxpaying community of Australia. This debate is just an attempt by the Government to pull the wool over the eyes of Australian taxpayers. It will leave us without any effective response to the needs of real tax reform and will ignore the proposals which have been put forward by representatives of the true free enterprise sections of this nation as to possible inputs to assist in the serious circumstances in which the Australian nation finds itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite the pseudo-pessimistic outpourings of the Opposition, I believe that all members of the House, including Opposition members, are aware of the wide range of reforms undertaken by this Government in the area of taxation. Previous speakers on the subject have provided a most thorough and comprehensive analysis of the various positive features of the statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on tax reform. I recognise, as I am sure do the majority of Australians, a need for a serious and committed approach to tax reform. It is past the time for politicking. I am also in no doubt that the majority of Australians feel that the Hawke Government is the only option as a government with the commitment, foresight, courage and economic knowhow to achieve real and lasting tax reform.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the leadership of our opponents, tax avoidance and evasion bit deeply into the public purse. They did nothing to stop it. A range of tax shelters, bottom of the harbour schemes and other tax rorts went uncontrolled while the burden of taxation fell more heavily on the average pay as you earn taxpayer attempting to earn an honest income. The former Government made much of its commitment to end tax avoidance but, in the cold light of day its record in actively achieving any sort of tax reform is deplorably deficient. It did not even try. In 1983 the people of Australia overwhelmingly voiced their opinion at the ballot box that the Hawke Labor Government was the only government capable of pulling this country out of the deep recession caused by our opponents.

In the two-and-a-half years since then Australia has been applauded internationally for effecting the most remarkable economic recovery in the Western world. We should remember that unemployment and inflation have been significantly reduced, economic growth is outstripping most of our rivals, and there is a confidence in the electorate that this Government is achieving what it set out to do when it inherited the economic woes of the Fraser-Howard leadership. Under the accord, sustained economic growth has been achieved and the benefits of an expanding revitalised economy will flow on to all Australians. However, economic recovery is not enough. The enlightened economic management of this Government may have healed some of the scars of seven-and-a-half years of virtual Fraser moratorium, but there are shortcomings in our economic system that have existed since long before the 1970s. The economic history of this country has been characterised by the presence of an inequitable, discriminatory and unwieldy taxation system which has hampered the development of the considerable economic resources of this country. As time has gone on, successive governments have recognised the inherent deficiencies which have progressively impaired our tax system, but no government has moved to implement reforms for fear of some electoral backlash-until now.

The Hawke Labor Government made tax reform one of its priorities after the 1984 election. The mandate provided by the people of Australia at that poll has ensured that tax reform will at last be achieved. The issue of tax reform is at the very heart of the principles underlying the Labor movement. The Labor Party has always been committed to the principles of fairness, equality and assistance to those in need, and every policy initiated by this Government reflects these aims. Under Labor, welfare has become a prominent part of government policy which, when combined with the innovative and responsible fiscal management of this Government, has ensured the advancement and full development of Australia. The principles underlying the Federal Government's tax reform proposals directly reflect this. For years our opponents neglected the difficult social and economic issues facing our community, preferring instead to take easy options which reinforced the inequalities and anomalies of our economic system. Put quite simply, our opponents underestimated the electorate for the Opposition's perception of Australia is one of a simplistic nature, not given to any commitment to serious social issues or a firm vision of a planned and viable future for Australia and for Australians.

The Opposition is hopelessly out of touch with the Australia of 1985, which represents an educated, aware, committed and sophisticated electorate whose concept of what governments can and must do is clearly defined. The Australian people expect a strong competent government with the foresight to anticipate the needs of the future. In 1983 and again in 1984 the Australian people got exactly that. This Government does not underestimate the electorate. We recognise its special needs. We recognise that it has a voice, and we gave it the opportunity to use that voice at the tax summit. The summit brought Australians together in a common quest for tax reform that could never be envisaged under a coalition government which sees such a get- together as merely hot air. Honourable members opposite are certainly experts on hot air. They do not understand that the underlying precepts of the summit were to give people the opportunity to tell their government what it was that they, the people, wanted. Out of that tax summit has come a range of proposals with which the Government has attempted to reflect the will of the community. This is important because ultimately the business of government involves bringing policy to the people. The tax reform proposals announced by the Treasurer last month achieve exactly that.

One of the major social issues this Government has not shirked is recognition of the unacceptable level of poverty in Australia. This Government, unlike its predecessors, has recognised that some people in our society are placed in very adverse economic situations. They are disadvantaged through no fault of their own. One of the prime objectives of tax reform must be an attack on poverty. The Government has built into its tax reform proposals measures which ensure that money recouped from those who have in the past abused the tax system will assist in the elimination of the poverty traps that exist in our welfare system.

Many people on social security are subject to extremely high marginal tax rates when they try to earn some extra private income for themselves and their families. When income tests overlap the tax system, people often find themselves caught in traps which limit their ability to earn extra money. The Government has recognised this problem and the fact that it most affects those who are in the greatest need of assistance.

Tax reform will, therefore, deal with the problems of these traps in three ways. Firstly, the amount pensioners can earn privately before they are affected by the income test will be increased from $30 to $40 a week for single pensioners and from $50 to $70 for couples. Secondly, the additional allowable income for pensioners with children will be doubled from $6 to $12 a week for every child. Thirdly, the separate income test for rent assistance will be abolished. Of course, everyone has a right to shelter and accommodation, not just those who were born or worked their way into an advantageous position. These three measures will ensure that the welfare payments we provide are not disincentives to earning income.

The assault on poverty traps is an important aspect of this Government's attempts at tax reform and typifies the commitment to fairness and equity that should characterise any welfare system. However, there are other important aspects to the package. The taxation system is no longer progressive. Tens of thousands of people have walked away from the system because it has been so easy to avoid. The current top marginal rate of 60c in the dollar has been paid by only a few of those whose income should place them in that bracket. The problem has been that in their place middle income earners have been forced to take up the load. These are people who have not been in a position to arrange their affairs to take advantage of the tax shelters, schemes and concessions. It is for these people, and for these reasons, that the major objective of tax reform has been to reduce substantially the heavy hand of marginal tax rates.

The package does other commendable things. A mild capital gains tax will ensure that those who choose to increase their wealth through capital gains rather than through income will pay their fair share of tax, not forgetting that for the great majority of taxpayers the new tax will have no impact, particularly when one considers the lack of retrospectivity and the fact that the tax paid will be discounted to compensate for inflation and the rising cost of living. The levying of tax on non-cash fringe benefits will ensure that the proliferation of remuneration packages with substantial fringe benefits will be brought under control and no longer will be a vehicle by which people can escape tax, as so many have. Members of parliament and public servants will, of course, be treated in the same way as everybody else, being the same as everybody else. The double taxation of company dividends will be largely eliminated and the tax free threshold will be raised. Provisional taxpayers will be able to pay their tax in quarterly instalments so that the burden of seasonal interest rate fluctuations is evened out.

The Opposition makes a great deal of noise about the capital gains tax, but it should be restated that the tax exempts the family home, life insurance and superannuation payouts, personal items of up to $5 000, and the family car. In addition, the tax will be wholly prospective from 19 September and will be indexed against inflation. No reasonable person could possibly find fault with the fairness or economic sense of this tax, particularly when one considers the state of crisis into which this country has moved, partly because of the policies of the previous Government and partly because of earlier world events. The point remains that large numbers of Australians have been severely disadvantaged. Money has to be raised to pay for the services that are needed to rectify these inequities. This Government is the first government to have looked at these problems, and it has been able to accept that there will be some electoral backlash to the introduction of tax reform. However, it is prepared to overlook party political expediency, and at least it is willing to introduce that tax reform. The introduction of the identification card system will save the people of Australia $540m in tax revenue and welfare benefits within seven years.

I particularly wish to mention one other area of the tax reform package, and that is the rationalisation of the wholesale tax rates. Some confusion emerges in some parts of the electorate when the word `tax' is mentioned. In the case of wholesale tax, some people are unaware of the fact that sales tax has always been levied on a number of consumer goods. There has been a graduated system of tax, with four levels from 7.5 per cent to 32 per cent. Within this breakdown there have been a number of anomalies and inconsistencies which have meant that a range of comparable goods are taxed at different levels. The Government has, therefore, moved to rationalise and simplify the sales tax levels by the introduction of a step system of 10 per cent, 20 per cent and 30 per cent. The Government could have to look at some anomalies there, but the adoption of this simplified system will be accompanied by a re-assessment of the levels of sales tax to reduce the sort of inconsistency that has seen a toothpick taxed at the same level as a fur coat or a diamond necklace. In future, the top rate of 30 per cent will be confined in the main to non-essential or luxury items and the more basic consumer goods used by most people will be taxed at the lower levels or exempted completely. The logic underlying the change to that system of applying wholesale taxes is indicative of the attitude of this Government when looking at the important question of tax reform.

The Government will issue guidelines covering vesting, preservation, contributions and control and will legislate to establish a safety net superannuation scheme to which employers will be required to contribute where they have failed to provide cover for their employees under an appropriate scheme. This is part of the package which the Government negotiated with trade unions and employers to ensure that genuine superannuation will be a reality for more working people. The Government intends to provide superannuation to those who do not have cover but wish to. It will introduce an umbrella cover to ensure that not less than 50 per cent of Australians are covered by superannuation. Our aim is eventually to give superannuation cover to all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the tax package today I have to say that, overall, it will be bad for Australia, bad for the people who have to get out and make a living and, from our point of view, probably bad for the Government. Unfortunately, Australia will have to live with it for the next two and a half years. It is remarkable that we are debating a tax package which will require several Bills and yet we have seen none of the Bills. I guess that this must be rather unusual. I do not know whether it has happened in this place before, but for us to have to debate legislation we have not even seen does seem to be rather unusual.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to look at the history of this so-called tax reform that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has placed before us. In fact, we see that three times he tried to put together a tax package and twice he failed to get approval from his boss, the Australian Council of Trade Unions. In fact, the Treasurer, in one of his more frank moments, in the House on 17 September, said:
Yes, I failed, but I tried . . .

I guess that that sums it all up. This time, on the third attempt, we have a hotchpotch of taxes which takes the worst aspects of all the proposals that have been put forward-the worst aspects from the White Paper, the worst aspects from the package announced after the White Paper and now, at the third attempt, the worst of all. Of course, the fundamental failure of this package is that it does nothing whatsoever to reduce government spending. We still have the highest taxing government since the last war. It is interesting that much has been made about the change in the mix of taxes. The Treasurer has made a lot of noise about this, but he has done nothing about reducing this burden of tax which is leading to many industries and individuals feeling stifled. It is a tax burden that has given this Government the title of the highest taxing peacetime government in Australia's history.

The other curious fact about this cure-all pronouncement is that most of the Government's factions talk about redistribution, but little is said about tax evasion in the cash economy. Whilst it is difficult to quantify the size of the cash economy, the best estimates are rather disturbing. Firstly, the estimates show that the size of the cash economy is enormous, and it is growing. It is estimated that it is in the range of 5 to 15 per cent of the recorded gross domestic product. On those figures, which are for the year ended September 1984, the cash economy represents between $8.5 billion and $27.5 billion. We hear much from the left wing faction in particular about taxing the haves in society, but these same members are curiously silent on what they will do about the cash economy. Does the left wing faction believe that those who evade tax through the cash economy are somehow less guilty than other tax evaders?

Why does not the Left maintain some consistency? We hear so much bleating about the need for this capital tax, but when the cash economy is mentioned there is nothing but silence. Honourable members should look at the size of the cash economy. It involves billions, maybe tens of billions of dollars. If the Government in general and the Left in particular are serious about tax reform, a major step must be to start collecting tax from the cash economy. Of course, one way of collecting this evaded tax is by broadening the base of indirect taxes. Yet the Left opposes this. One wonders whether the Left should not be dubbed the real champions of tax evasion.

In the short time available to me I will confine most of my remarks to the new capital gains tax. One of the worst aspects of this package is the introduction of a new capital gains tax. As everyone knows, Australia already has a capital gains tax under the provisions of section 26AAA and section 25A of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Under these two sections speculative capital gains are taxed. Most Australians accept that speculative gains should be taxed. However, I remind honourable members of the election promise the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made in 1983, just two and a half years ago. He said:
And here let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it; and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentation and distortion. There will be no new capital gains tax.

Now we have a capital gains tax, just two and a half years later. That promise, which was made before the 1983 election, has been very conveniently dropped. No wonder people get cynical about the Prime Minister. A new capital gains tax has been proposed. It is not on just speculative gains; it is on genuine gains of people who work, people who endeavour to help themselves, people who endeavour to make this country a better place and people who endeavour to provide extra employment. One of the worst aspects of this capital gains tax is that there is no time limit. It is obvious that people who will be caught by this measure may not know about it until after 10, 20 or 30 years or so.

It is obvious that the Government has agonised for months over how to introduce the new capital gains tax in what appears to be a relatively mild form. But never let anyone forget a couple of salient points about tax. When income tax was reintroduced in Britain in 1842, it was considered to be merely a temporary measure. It was levied at the rate of 7d in the #1. I remind honourable members that that was the old #1, when it took 240 pennies to make #1. So the tax was levied at a very low rate-something like 3 per cent. The point I am making is that history can show that when a tax is introduced it nearly always starts at a very low rate. Much is being made about indexing the new capital gains tax for inflation. But who honestly believes that this Government will go through all the criticism associated with introducing a new tax just to raise $25m over five years? Oh no, it will be like the history of other taxes. The Government will start at a low rate and quietly increase the rates after the noise has eased. I challenge the Treasurer to tell the House otherwise. I challenge him to state that within a year or so he will not attempt to tighten the screws on the capital gains tax.

Let us look a little further at the new capital gains tax. Firstly, the Treasurer admits that it will not raise much revenue in the overall Budget. Has anyone thought of the complexities of administering such a tax? Has anyone really thought of the complexities of complying with a capital gains tax? As I have already said, there is no time limit. Has the Treasurer thought about how people will keep for decades records of every asset they purchase after 19 September? Imagine the added difficulties of having to work out at the time of sale whether assets accumulated over half a lifetime or more are to be subject to the capital gains tax. Imagine the time and cost involved every time a commercial decision to sell an asset has to be qualified by the effects of a capital gains tax being applied after all those years. The complexities are enormous. This was recognised by the Asprey Taxation Review Committee in 1975 when, speaking about a capital gains tax, it said:
It is a tax which, in any administrable form, must be complex and difficult, and produce some anomalies and inequities of its own.
There is no doubt whatever that any revenue it raises could be more cheaply and easily raised in other ways.
By the criterion of simplicity it fails.

That is, by the criterion of simplicity, a capital gains tax fails. But the Government has prepared itself well for this capital gains tax. Let us look at the pensioners and at what the assets test has done. The Government has bullied pensioners to disclose all their assets. Many pensioners now have the value of their assets on a government register. Imagine how pensioners must feel now, knowing that any change in their assets from now on will mean that the capital gains tax will hang over their heads. Every change in assets will be recorded on the government register. Can we not leave older people some dignity? Apparently, in the eyes of the Treasurer, the answer is no.

Because of the sensitivities of the capital gains tax the Government is very quick to point out that the family home will be exempt. Let us examine what effect this will have. Already we are seeing pressure on pensioners to move their assets into more expensive homes in order to qualify for a pension. Exempting the family home from a capital gains tax would accelerate this move. The result will be counter-productive to the aims of those who want cheaper housing in Australia. Instead, more and more of a family's assets will be sunk into its home. In other words, more and more of Australia's capital will be diverted from productive areas to become tied up in non-productive houses. Think of what this will do to rental housing.

If nothing else, a capital gains tax which exempts the family home, when coupled with the pensions assets test, will mean that many Australians will end up with the best homes in the world. The other side of the coin is that it will lead to reduced investment in productive resources. Such a move could be disastrous to our industries and could have devastating effects in country areas. It must also reduce the opportunities for new investment, which is needed to create jobs.

What about the effects of a capital gains tax on farming? The Treasurer claims that farmers do not have to worry because the value of land does not increase faster than the consumer price index. As my colleague the honourable member for Corangamite mentioned earlier today, this has been shown to be a complete fallacy. The National Farmers Federation has taken out some figures which show that land values in farming areas increase faster in many cases than the rate of inflation. Rural land values move much more in line with commodity prices. For example, in the wheat belt land values go up and down roughly in line with wheat prices. Seasons also affect land values. Thus, if a farmer shows enterprise and buys a farm during a recession, he will be penalised for showing that enterprise, penalised for taking a risk, and this capital gains tax will hang over his head for years.

Let us look at some of the other effects of a capital gains tax. It has already been mentioned that it includes an element of death duties. The Treasurer has tried to ignore this, but when one analyses it one finds that with the rollover provisions someone who inherits, say, a small farm and then, showing industriousness and endeavour, expands it in order to be more productive and to create further employment could be locked into a capital gains tax which goes back over 10, 20, 30 years or more. Obviously such a person would be in the awkward position of wondering what to do. If he sold the farm in order to expand, the additional capital that he would need to buy a new farm would be whipped away by a capital gains tax.

The Treasurer makes much about the fact that the capital gains tax will not affect current land values. I suggest he will find things will be very different because current land values obviously will be affected. People know now that any block of land or farm they buy from now on will be subject to a capital gains tax. Obviously people will not seek to put their money into a productive asset such as a farm because they will have that additional burden. It has already been mentioned in this chamber today that farming is not a highly profitable enterprise. Many farmers are struggling just to break even. Nowadays the average return on farming capital is somewhat less than 2 per cent. The current figures of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics show that the returns on farming will drop by a further 22 per cent in the current year. I do not think that it can be argued that taxing an enterprise such as this will not have an effect on land values; it will have a very severe effect on land values. People who already own land and who have already borrowed in order to expand will find that they will lose a lot of their equity due to depressed land values, so they will find it even more difficult to service their loans. I assure all honourable members that many farmers are now facing an intolerable situation with the high interest rates that currently exist in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —The highest rates for 50 years.

—As the honourable member for Mayo has just reminded me, they are the highest interest rates for 50 years. With a reduced equity, it will be harder and harder for farmers to get out of their debt situation.

SPEECH.PARA: For those honourable members who want a more authoritative opinion on the matter of a capital gains tax, I shall quote an editorial of 18 March in the Australian headed `Capital gains must be ruled out'. The editorial stated:
The arguments against any new such tax are overwhelming.
It further stated:
Such a tax would probably have the overall effect of actually lowering the amount of tax revenue raised. This is because, like all taxes, it would affect incentive.
A new capital gains tax would automatically discourage the formation of capital and therefore discourage investment and new jobs.

There can be no doubt that a capital gains tax should not be introduced in this Parliament. The Treasurer still has time to withdraw the legislation since we have not even seen it. As I have stated, it would be extremely complex to administer, extremely complex to comply with and extremely costly. It would raise little revenue-the Treasurer has already admitted that-but it would lead to the diverting of scarce capital into unproductive resources.
The Treasurer has, in his own words, failed. Australia will not benefit by this tax package.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate first of all to praise the Hawke Government for the most significant tax reforms that have been undertaken in this country by an Australian government. These reforms have been well received by millions of Australians who believe in tax justice. I have listened to the comments put forward by the Opposition and I am not surprised that it is desperate to try to discredit the proposals. Whilst I will not cast aspersions on the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), who has just resumed his seat, I certainly wish to comment on other Opposition members, particularly members of the National Party of Australia. It is clear from Press releases that have appeared throughout Queensland that the National Party is prepared to go to any length to discredit the tax proposals put forward by the Treasurer, Mr Keating. Some most dishonest claims have come from the National Party. I am pleased that the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Conquest) is in the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: On 21 September in the Morning Bulletin, which circulates throughout central Queensland, the Premier of Queensland, Sir Joh Bjelke- Petersen, claimed that these tax reforms would bring about a death duty. Over many years I have heard of the sort of stupidity that the Premier of Queensland, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, can be linked with and heard some of the mad claims that he makes, but I would have thought that a member of this chamber, having had the chance to read the statement by Treasurer Keating, would not restate that lie. Instead, we find in the Morning Bulletin of 26 September the honourable member for Hinkler, Mr Conquest, in an article which I believe would have been prepared by National Party headquarters and which was headed `Budget blow to man on the land claims member', stating:
The proposed capital gains tax includes a deferred death duty.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.
—I am simply amazed that the honourable member now reiterates that lie. I hope that he will try to substantiate this statement because it is simply untrue.
—Order! I ask the honourable member to substitute another word for the one that is not considered parliamentary.

—The untruths told by the honourable member for Hinkler are blatant misrepresentations. There is no death duty in the proposals put forward by Treasurer Keating. There is no deferred death duty in the proposals put forward by the Hawke Labor Government. The Bjelke-Petersen Government, the National Party in Queensland and the honourable member for Hinkler stand condemned for their strategy of telling untruths in order, I believe, to engender fear and to try to gain politically. The new capital gains tax-it is really an extension of existing provisions-has been carefully designed after close consideration of community views. Its impact will be moderate, and that has been admitted by Opposition speakers. Its impact will also be very gradual.
—Are you still on the rural committee?

—Yes, I am. I spoke to grain growers in Biloela and Thangool last Thursday night. Once I explained the truth and told them what was really happening, they could understand why the Federal Government has introduced this provision. This proposed capital gains tax does not apply in any way to any asset owned by any person prior to 19 September. All the assets owned or acquired before 19 September are exempt from the tax and will remain exempt for ever and ever while that person owns that property or asset.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.
(Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension for dinner I was commenting on the outlandish claims, fabrications, blatant misrepresentation and untruths that have been propagated by Bjelke-Petersen in Queensland and the honourable member for Hinkler. They made out that the new capital gains tax is in fact a death duty. I pointed out that this is certainly untrue. There is no death duty in the package presented by the Treasurer. In fact, there is no way that properties owned at this time cannot be transferred. Honourable members will appreciate, as I continue my speech, that from generation to generation a property owned at this moment can be passed on. All assets owned or acquired before 19 September are exempt from tax. These properties or assets will remain exempt from tax in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: If a person dies, that property or asset can be passed on to a son, daughter or relative, and still not be taxed. It is an outright untruth to claim that we have imposed death duties. A person owning land now could pass it on to sons or daughters who could keep it until they in turn die. It could then be passed on to their son or daughter in 30, 40 or 50 years' time and there would still be no tax. I stress that the capital gains tax applies to assets acquired only on or after 20 September. Even then, it does not apply to the family home, farmhouse or to a reasonable amount of surrounding land. It does not apply to the sale of a motor vehicle or personal items up to the value of $5,000.

I note also that some National Party members claim that the capital gains tax applies to any increase in the value of an asset if it is sold. That is bunkum. It is totally untrue. That may be Liberal or National Party policy but it is certainly not the policy of the Hawke Labor Government. Under this Government the proposed capital gains tax will apply only to assets which increase in value more rapidly than the rate of inflation. Therefore, many people will make significant capital gains and yet they will pay no tax. Many others will pay a very small amount of tax. I will explain this by giving an example. If a person purchases a farm or a building on 30 September 1985 for $100,000 and sells that property for $150,000 in July 1993, and if one assumes that during those eight years the compounded consumer price index increases by 45 per cent that is, to $45,000-the real capital gain liable for tax will be only $5,000. Even then, if the taxpayer is liable for tax at a marginal rate of perhaps 40 per cent, the tax that that person will pay on the realised real capital gain would be $2,000, after having a property initially worth $100,000 which was sold for $150,000. That tax is peanuts.

We need to contrast that with the proposition being put forward by the National Party and the Liberal Party. First, we heard that the Liberal and National parties would repeal the capital gains tax. Now we are told by Senator Tony Messner that that would not necessarily be so. In fact, he said that the Liberal-National Party policy would be to use section 26A or section 26AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act to apply its capital gains tax. If that happened, the taxpayer would not pay tax on the $5,000, he would pay tax on the difference-$50,000. If farmers are concerned, they ought to be concerned about people such as the honourable member for Hinkler and the National Party cronies that surround him.

The Labor Party says very clearly that tax shall be applied to the actual realised capital gain. In the example that I gave that is an amount of $5,000, and the tax would be $2,000. That would be a totally different story under the Liberal Party, because it would apply tax on $50,000. Those opposite are hypocrites. On one hand, they say that there will be no capital gains tax, and on the other they say that there will be. I would be pleased to hear comments from the National Farmers Federation. It is always quick to castigate and argue against policies put forward by the Labor Party. I note that even today its representatives were speaking against the capital gains tax proposed by the Labor Party but they have not yet said anything about the proposals being put forward by the National Party and the Liberal Party. We will wait and see.

Let us further contrast the policy of the Liberal and National parties with that of the Labor Party. The ALP policy is not only to allow deductions for inflation-as I pointed out before there would be $45,000 of deductions for inflation on the sale that I mentioned-but also the money spent on capital improvements to the property would be indexed to the inflation rate and deductible from the sale proceeds when calculating the capital gains tax. So it is quite possible that when people sell their properties, because of the improvements that they have made, they would pay no tax. Furthermore, it is part of this policy that the capital losses in money terms can be offset against capital gains. Despite all the fear that the Liberals and Nationals have tried to generate in the community, they are telling blatant untruths. They are fabricating the position. Despite what the National Party says, the tax will not apply to any assets transferred at death.

So a farm can pass on from generation to generation without tax being levied. The tax applies only when the asset is disposed of. If someone inherits a property, he pays no tax. If he later chooses to sell, the capital gains tax will apply only to the actual real realised capital gain on the value of the property from when it was inherited. Again, I will use the example that if the property was worth $100,000 when inherited, and if it was sold some years later for $150,000, using the same CPI figures that I cited before, a tax of $2,000 would be paid under our policy. Under the Liberals and Nationals it would be far more than that. In fact, the tax would be about $20,000 on that gain.

People throughout the nation have asked: Why the need for a capital gains tax? That is a fair question because we have had a capital gains tax written into our tax law but it has not always been applied. I believe, as does the Labor Party, that any tax system should be even-handed. Everyone realises that for many years some people have got much of their income from capital gains. They have certainly got their income from this area but they have paid no tax. That is not the situation for the ordinary worker, the farmer or the small business person. They pay tax on everything they earn-but not these people. They have been able to make in many cases hundreds of thousands of dollars.

TALK.START.PARA: —Farmers do not pay tax. They do not have enough income.
—The farmer pays tax on everything that he sells-
—They do not have enough income. Don't you read the papers?

—Some of them do. I accept the honourable member's point. That is one of the reasons why this tax will not hurt farmers. We have had situations in which the lack of capital gains has helped tax avoiders. In the past people have dressed up their ordinary income as tax free capital gains. We are going to put an end to that. In the past also, we have had investments placed in certain areas only because of the tax advantage. No thought has been given to the benefit in terms of income earning capacity or to the fact that it might employ people; it has been done only to create a tax shelter or a tax advantage. A capital gains tax as has been proposed by the Labor Government will stimulate investment in the productive areas. It will generate more jobs and more profits for the whole nation. It will help the farmers also. I spoke to a group of farmers last Thursday night. They admitted that very often the price of land has been forced up because of the Pitt Street farmer-that person who goes into the tax shelter area, who has invested in properties and who would not know one end of a cow from the other. Such people go into this area simply to save tax or to avoid paying any tax at all. Years later they sell that property at enormous profits and push up the price of surrounding land. I believe that the proposed capital gains tax will put an end to that. It will put an end to the developers, the speculators and those professionals who have been investing in farm lands and other businesses just to evade tax. I was told of the case of a fellow on the Gold Coast who bought a unit when it was on the plan, later sold it at a profit of some $205,000 and paid no tax on that investment.
—He took a risk.

—He may have taken some risks. I believe in risk and reward, but I doubt whether there was any risk in that. He paid a very minor deposit when he went into the sale and later on he made a massive profit and did not pay one cent of tax on that money. He still gets the benefit from the nation; he still rides on the roads; his kids are still educated in our schools; he still gets the benefit of the health system; and he can still get all the benefits of the defence forces. He gets all the benefits of our society but he makes no real contribution to it.

SPEECH.PARA: So there is a need for change. We need to ensure that people pay their way. For the first few years, this tax will not derive very much-it is a matter of some $25 million-but it is a start. It means that we are going to make sure that our tax system is even-handed. We are going to make sure that it has that degree of justice and equity. I believe that the Hawke Government has shown enormous courage. It has shown that it is prepared to make tough decisions and to grapple with the problems. At the same time, it is prepared to acknowledge problems that can arise for ordinary people. That is why in this tax measure we find that there are exemptions for the farm house and the surrounding property, the family home, assets and motor vehicles. Exemptions will be provided by way of deduction for the consumer price index or inflation. There will be exemptions or deductions for the expenditure one might put into developing a property. This is the fair and proper way to administer a tax such as this.

In the closing moments of my speech, I reiterate that the capital gains tax which the Liberal-National Party now admits it is going to have will be on the actual capital gain. A person who buys something for $100,000 and sells it later for $200,000 will pay capital gains tax on $100,000. There is no reference in section 26AAA or section 26A-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the House in this debate on the taxation statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) from the point of view of those who have been the most disadvantaged in the Australian community-those from rural areas who have seen incomes falling while this taxation statement has been handed down. The only real statement of fact in this taxation statement occurs on the cover, the words on which, if one reads them vertically downwards, spell RATS. That is precisely what this package is.

SPEECH.PARA: This taxation statement by the Treasurer has been mere rhetoric, and the Treasurer knows it. This is not the document that the Treasurer wanted to introduce into the House of Representatives. It is not a document setting out real reform of the Australian taxation system. When the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) said that it was a matter of significant reform, he knew that he was deceiving the House and himself. What we have here is nothing more than a smorgasbord of minimal reform, a conglomeration of the compromises that the Treasurer was forced to make as he backed down from options A, B and C to the option he finished up with.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—This document is nothing more than an attack on the prudent people in our community. No one in this House has denied that there is a real need in Australia for taxation reform, and the need is best illustrated by the simple, inescapable fact that in 1954 or 1955 one would have had to have an income, in 1985 terms, of $400,000 before one had to pay tax at the rate of 60 cents in the dollar at which people with a salary of $35,000 currently pay tax. No one denies that there is a need for reform, but even the economically illiterate know that this document does nothing to achieve real taxation reform because there can be no real taxation reform unless we determine how we are to reduce government expenditure. Unless the Government is prepared to accept less and spend less there can be no real taxation changes. Even the economically illiterate know that. In fact, in spite of the protestations from the people opposite, the equally inescapable reality is that the Hawke Government has, during its time in office, increased the tax burden carried by all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that there are those anxious to interject with the word `rubbish'. So, let me quote not from some Liberal Party document but from a taxation statement which shows that the Budget Papers-the Budget Papers, if you please-show that the total Budget receipts, total government revenue, is at an all time high of 27 per cent of gross domestic product. That figure is even higher than in the first two Hawke Budgets. But, more pointed than that, the first three Hawke Budgets have increased taxes by an average of 5.7 per cent in real terms compared with an average increase of 3.4 per cent over the seven Fraser Budgets.

There are those opposite who have been anxious to point out that this is a Government of taxation reform. I wish to illustrate the number of taxes that have been introduced in Australia and the governments that have chosen to introduce them. On 27 May, I asked the Treasurer, on notice, the following question:
When were (a) personal income tax, (b) sales tax, (c) death duties, (d) gift duties, (e) pay-roll tax and (f) entertainment tax first introduced and by which government.
The reply I received was:

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) (a) Federal personal income tax was introduced in 1915 by the Fisher Government.
(b) Sales tax was introduced in 1930-
as a temporary measure-
by the Scullin Government.
(c) Estate duties, also known as death duties, were introduced in 1914 by the Fisher Government.
Subsequently, of course, they were removed by the coalition. The answer continued:
(d) Gift duty was introduced in 1941 by the Curtin Government.
It was subsequently removed by the coalition government. The answer continued:
(e) Pay-roll tax-
I indicate this to show that I am being as bipartisan as possible in this debate-
was introduced in 1941 by the Menzies Government.
It was subsequently passed over to the States. The answer continued:
(f) Entertainment tax was introduced in 1916 by the Hughes Government.

These measures covered the major area of taxation revenue. The record of those opposite in taxation reform is not as rosy as they would want us to believe. In fact, in spite of what has been said, we cannot escape the truth that no one did as much to tidy up tax rorts as did the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard).

I opened my contribution to this debate by saying that the taxation statement currently being discussed is an attack on the prudent. I reinforce it by focusing on the real attack that the taxation statement represents on rural Australians. Much has been made of the fact that this document introduces a capital gains tax. As we listened to the honourable member for Capricornia we could have been forgiven for imagining that a capital gains tax was some sort of tax that did not apply in Australia and therefore ought to be introduced. Of course, in reality there has long been a capital gains tax in place which has picked up tax on speculative gains and which has been supported by members on this side of the House. In addition, a major part of local government revenue comes from capital gains taxation. What we are debating tonight is a proposal for a capital gains tax that runs counter to a promise that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made when he said: `There will be no capital gains tax'.

I noted that the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) challenged the Treasurer to offer the House an assurance that he would not expand this tax. While I appreciate the sentiments behind the honourable member for Wannon's statement, I have to ask him what the promises would be worth in view of the Prime Minister's original promise not to introduce such a tax. I could not believe my ears when the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) stood in the House and said: `In my office there has been no criticism of the capital gains tax'. Furthermore, the honourable member for Hunter said that the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) was speaking an untruth when the honourable member for Gwydir suggested that he had had letters of criticism of the Goverment's capital gains tax. I am not quite sure what method of mail interception the honourable member for Hunter uses that allows him to keep an eye on the mail of the honourable member for Gwydir but I can reassure him that all of the mail in my office referring to capital gains taxation has been critical and has expressed the real concern that farmers feel about this new taxation measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —With good reason.

—The honourable member has interjected: `With good reason'. That is not because the capital gains tax involves a large amount of money but because the capital gains tax has to be the thin end of the wedge. There is no way that a Treasurer from either side of the House would introduce a tax to raise $25m over five years without intending to expand that taxation base. In fact, the Treasurer has refused to give a guarantee not to expand that base because he would not have introduced this measure if he had not intended to raise more than $25m in five years. The defence of the capital taxation measure that we have heard from the honourable member for Capricornia and other honourable members opposite has been nothing short of absurd. I repeat, for the benefit of those honourable members opposite who have chosen to be less than honest in their assessment of the policies espoused here, that the Opposition is committed to repealing this particularly offensive piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I have said that the capital gains tax in fact will generate nothing more than $25m over five years. While I am on the subject of lump sums of $25m, I refer to another portion of the tax package. That is the portion which looks to removing the opportunity for tax write-offs that existed as a result of money spent in water distribution and irrigation equipment. In fact, the Government has chosen to attack those irrigation farmers and water distributors across Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like yourself.

—The Government has chosen to take from them the sum of $25m. I am pleased that the honourable member for Dobell has chosen to interject, because he is quite right. I have used this particular facility. It is for that reason that I speak with some passion about what he is doing to South Australian irrigators. I do not know why the Premier of South Australia has failed to alert the Government to the damage that will be done to South Australia-I refer not only to South Australian irrigators, but also to South Australia and South Australians-as a result of this measure in the tax package. Nothing has done as much to improve water distribution in the water hungry State of South Australia as has this tax write-off measure. Furthermore, nothing has done as much to improve the quality of water available to all South Australians as has this measure.

SPEECH.PARA: This measure has meant that far from the awfully extravagant use of flood irrigation water we have had people choosing to apportion to plants the water those plants need. That has minimised the drainage inflows and the consequent saline build-up in the River Murray. It does not just affect the River Murray irrigators. Every farmer who chooses to improve stock watering facilities is now denied the write-off he once had for that improvement. Every farmer who chooses to be something of an environmentalist by planting trees and providing supplementary irrigation by drip irrigation loses the opportunity to sustain those trees adequately as a result of this tax measure. For what reason is that measure being introduced? It is being imposed for the sake of $25m. That sum will be paid by those farmers who are among the most struggling. Of course, it is this focus on the strugglers in the rural community that I turn to when I remind the House that the quarantining of farm losses also is a burden borne directly by struggling farmers. Too few people realise that it is those farmers on small properties who have often got on to those properties by being able to work off the property in the first instance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Starting off shearing.

—Of course, they are often people who have started off as shearers or contract fruit pickers and who are prepared to work no matter what the weather in order to get on to a small property. The opportunity to offset farm losses against the income they earn somewhere else is to be denied those people. The impression one has from the views espoused by honourable members opposite is that this is some sort of attack on the wealthy. The reality is that the people being protected by those of us debating the matter on this side of the House are rural people who are struggling to make ends meet. Their plight produces nothing but mirth from honourable members opposite. The honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) in his speech said that people in his electorate do not write off large incomes. I remind him that this offsetting of farm losses does not help just those on large incomes. It helps those who are endeavouring to get on to the land, often in a very small way.

SPEECH.PARA: This taxation statement by the Treasurer is an attack on the risk takers, the prudent and self-motivated in our community. It is being sold through an expensive advertising campaign that offers a hot line. However, my electoral office already has been inundated by people who have dialled the hot line and got no answer at all. If honourable members will pardon the Irish logic, those people who got an answer, got an answer that was not an answer at all. This statement attacks those who are already disadvantaged. It attacks the rural people of Australia who, having faced falling incomes, now face a further fall in their farm incomes as a result of the Treasurer's supposed reform of the Australian taxation system. As I said in my opening statement, the only honest statement is on the outside cover of the Treasurer's policy where this reform is referred to as `RATS'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I am pleased to speak in support of the taxation package announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 19 September. This package is the result of the commitment by the Government given to the people of Australia during the last election to reform the taxation system. The current taxation regime is an inheritance of neglect and deceit bequeathed by our political opponents, the Liberal and National parties, in 30 years of government out of the last 35 years.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government, when re-elected, embarked on a massive and far reaching review of the system, inviting public participation and widespread discussion. At no time was the Government's task assisted by the miserable members opposite in an earnest endeavour to achieve bipartisan support for a more equitable and fairer system. Not only did the Opposition spit the dummy out, and refuse to attend the Taxation Summit, but worse still-we have heard it here tonight from speaker after speaker-at each and every opportunity it attempted to obfuscate, to distort and to instil fear in the Australian public. Opposition members are truly the merchants of doom and gloom. No other government has attempted to inform the Australian people of the massive breakdown of taxation and the difficult options faced by this reforming Government. The success of the Government's campaign of public information and public education can be seen in the general acceptance by the people of the need to reform the system-I am very pleased to hear that the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) at least admits that there is a need for reform, although we would not have heard that before the statement-and indeed the acceptance of the decisions and the proposals contained in this package.

The package needs to be seen in the general economic framework. The Hawke Labor Government inherited an economy of double digit inflation, double digit unemployment, an economy which, far from growing, was actually contracting. That is the record of the Opposition. It is not our record. That is what the previous Government left us. That is what its good management for the high risk takers gave the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —How are you going with real interest rates now?

—Hello, the shadow Minister for sugarless jam has spoken. Welcome to the debate. The economy, far from growing, was actually contracting. We inherited an economy in full retreat and a deficit blowout of $9 billion. In that last fateful year, each and every day, 700 men and women of Australia were losing their jobs. That is the Opposition's miserable record. No wonder the outlook of the Australian people was bleak. No wonder the outlook of the Australian people was pessimistic. This was the situation presided over by the then Treasurer and now Leader of the Opposition, the so-called Honest John Howard.
—Dishonest John Howard.

—I cannot disagree with my honourable colleague. The Hawke Labor Government has consistently pursued policies directed towards restoring strong economic growth and creating a fairer Australian society. To the extreme discomfort of those few honourable members opposite, those born to rule, this Labor Government has been extremely successful. In the past two years Australia has enjoyed record growth rates. Indeed, growth projections for the current year show a growth rate twice that for Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries.

SPEECH.PARA: The package announced by the Treasurer includes income tax, reform of the marginal tax rates, moves to ease poverty traps, the closure of loopholes currently allowing tax avoidance and unfair minimisation, an end to double taxation of dividends, and a rationalisation of the existing tax scale regime. It is important that the people understand that when the package is fully in force, it will cost the Government $4.5 billion, which is considerably more-I have to emphasise that for my friends opposite-than the $1.5 billion which will be actually raised by these reforms.

I would like to talk about some of these changes. I am pleased that the tax free threshold has been increased to $5,100. This will be of considerable benefit to the people of my electorate. In a two-stage reduction of marginal rates of personal income tax, the lower rates of taxation will be cut from 1 September 1986 and the higher rates from 1 July 1987. Too many workers and too many people in Australia have been pushed into the marginal rates of 48c in the dollar and 60c in the dollar. I remind the House yet again that it was honourable members opposite who allowed this disgraceful situation. The honourable member for Wakefield actually compared the situation in 1951, when he was in government, and the situation today. We have only been in government for two and a half years.

TALK.START.PARA: —The do nothing government.

—The do nothings. They say a lot but they do nothing. These high marginal rates of taxation will be reduced to 40 cents and 49 cents respectively. No Australian, whether he be a farmer, a worker, a manager or a business man, will pay more than half his income in tax. The need to reduce marginal rates was often talked about by the Opposition and now will be achieved by this reforming Hawke Labor Government. Typical taxpayers will get an income tax cut of $6 a week from September 1986 and more from July 1987. This is in addition to the average tax cut of around $7.60 a week in November last year.

SPEECH.PARA: I have spoken before on the issue of poverty traps, and I am very pleased by the measures announced in the package. Some 450,000 social welfare recipients currently receiving a part rate pension will receive an increase of up to $5 per week. This is because the amount of private income a pensioner may earn before his or her pension is reduced under the income test will be increased by $10 per week for single pensioners and by $20 for pensioner couples. The Government will abolish the separate income test on rent assistance.
