This will reduce the marginal rate of income withdrawal faced by some 700,000 pensioners and beneficiaries receiving rental assistance, in most cases from 50 per cent to zero. Further assistance will be given to pensioners with children. At present the weekly income a pensioner may earn without a reduction of pension is $6 for each child. This allowance is to rise to $12 per child. These measures will be of particular benefit to the large number of social welfare recipients in my electorate and have been well received. This measure will increase the pension rate of all part rate pensioners with children by up to $3 per week for each child.

We on this side of the House often get accused of betraying a lack of interest in the business community. There are a number of measures which I believe were long overdue and which in my experience have been well received by the business community. Business will benefit from the introduction of the imputation system, which will remove double taxation of dividends.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not even know how it works yet. Your Treasurer doesn't.
—What has the honourable member's Party done? What can the shadow Minister for sugarless jam say his Party has ever done in government to reform the system?
—They promised imputation.

—The Opposition promises things but it never delivers. That is the difference between his side of the House and this side. In 1988, when the people come to judge who has actually managed the economy out of the recession, who has the proven track record of success, who has the track record of failure, as the Leader of the Opposition has, the people will decide. It will be clear cut. They will know in their minds instantly who is credible on economic management and who lacks credibility.

SPEECH.PARA: I was talking about the issue of double taxation of dividends. I want to make it clear from this side of the House that I am very pleased to see that the Government has undertaken this long-overdue major reform. It will allow the strengthening of the corporate sector capital base and will allow for the development of a broader and more efficient capital market. This proposal has been little understood by the Opposition. The share markets of this country have responded favourably and dramatically, and one only has to look at what the indices have been.

In the brief time that is left to me I want to return to the point that was made by the shadow Minister for sugarless jam, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), about performance. As my colleague the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) has reminded people constantly in this House, the Leader of the Opposition has a miserable track record on taxation reform. He was part of the dishonest campaign of a fistful of dollars and when he became Treasurer he removed that. The Opposition promised indexation and it removed that.

On the issue of a capital gains tax, I would like to refer to statements made by Senator Messner. I am surprised that no Opposition members have in any way discussed what seems to be a confused position among the Opposition. On the one hand, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) is saying `We will introduce a consumption tax', and on the other hand the shadow Minister for Finance says: `No, a consumption tax is out'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Misreported.

—The Leader of the Opposition was saying in the McPherson by-election-was this misreported?-that he was against a flat rate taxation system. Now he is saying: `I was apparently wrong then. I have had another rethink. It is right now. We are all in favour of flat rate taxation'. The Leader of the Opposition says `No way' to a capital gains tax, and his shadow Minister for Finance says: `I think we will have to have a capital gains tax, and it will not be on the real increase, that is, the nominal increase less inflation, and then at the marginal rate'. I hope that Opposition members will tell their constituents and their farmers that they intend to put a capital gains tax on the nominal increase at the full marginal rate. Let the people of Australia know this conflicting and confusing story that comes from the Opposition. I wish now to conclude. There are a number of matters I could have dealt with in this package, but my time in this debate is limited. I am proud to be part of this reform package that has been announced by the Treasurer and, I believe, accepted by the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to take part in this debate on this iniquitous reform. Having heard the remarks of the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), I wish to make the position clear to the 170,000 farmers listening to the radio out there tonight. I wonder why any of them would ever want to support what the Australian Labor Party represents in this debate, particularly the iniquitous capital gains tax which the Labor Government has introduced. Never let any Australian forget that it was the ALP that introduced this tax. No other party but the Labor Party has seen fit to put this iniquitous new tax on us. Who needs a new tax in Australia? Not one individual Australian wishes to see any new taxation. Yet this Hawke socialist Government sees fit to introduce a brand new tax which militates against the farming community and puts it at a tremendous disadvantage.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important for the Australian people to understand that this is the fourth Labor Budget we have had in the past six months-and it is the worst of the four Budgets. We told our constituents that after August there was worse to come. We have certainly copped it in this so-called reform. There is nothing reformist about this package. All it amounts to is a whole range of new tax measures. The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) understands that. Where is his package on tourism? He promised that six weeks ago but he still has not brought it into this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which package are you talking about?

—The Minister promised new tax incentives to the tourist industry. He said that he would put them before the House, but he has done nothing about it, and that is still the case. The real increase in taxation in the last 12 months under this Government is 7 per cent. There has been a 12.5 per cent increase in the amount of tax people are being asked to pay. Keating comes in here day by day and tries to hoodwink the Australian population into believing that there has been no increase in taxation. I repeat that there has been a 12.5 per cent increase in the amount of tax paid on average by every Australian in the last 12 months. It is disgusting that people are expected to pay more and more in taxation when we are in the depths of a recesssion.

SPEECH.PARA: The great white leader, Bob Hawke, had a summit in this chamber. Indeed, the Labor Party is still abusing this chamber in that it is still having summits. I suggest, and continue to suggest, that we need a summit on expenditure. Until we get down and nut out exactly where we are going and how much money we want to spend, we shall get nowhere. We shall just see increasing taxation. The country has got itself into a sad state. Not just this Government is to blame but governments in the past, probably in the last 10 to 15 years. There has been an enormous increase in the move from the private to the public sector in that period. This is the problem not only with Australia but also with New Zealand. I have just paid a visit to New Zealand with my family and that country is in an incredible economic mess. It is even worse there than it is here. In New Zealand farmers are being asked to pay 30 per cent in interest. The going interest rate in New Zealand is 23 per cent. A video recorder costs $1,500 and costs are enormous. Unfortunately, the people there are suffering under a socialist government, the the Lange Government, in the same way as we are suffering under the socialist Hawke Government. The people there are feeling the pinch in the same way as we are here.

There must have been some reason why 40,000 farmers came to the doors of this Parliament on 1 July. When Keating and the Labor Government commenced the so-called reform of the taxation system for the people of Australia, for small business and the farmers whom I represent, 40,000 to 50,000 of them turned up outside this building. They did not leave their homes throughout Australia without feeling concern about what was happening to them. They came here to plead to this Government to do something sensible. But what did this Government do? In this reform package it brought down a whole range of tax disincentives against the farming community. It totally discriminated against farmers, and I regard that as incredible. One of the worst things that has happened concerns the Income Tax Assessment Bill (No. 4) 1984. Sections 80 and 80AAA in that Bill, which was introduced by a Labor Government, allows companies to transfer both losses and profits within themselves provided that they have a 100 per cent common interest. What do we see in the tax reform? Mr Keating takes the view that farmers-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I am reluctant to interrupt the honourable gentleman in full flow, but I ask him to refer to Ministers by their correct titles.

—The Treasurer-Mr Keating is the Treasurer, unfortunately for the people of Australia-introduced this reform package and one of the many sections contained within it relating to the transfer of profits and losses on or off the farm means that farmers are being totally discriminated against. They can own a farm as individuals but can no longer go off the farm in their own persons and earn incomes and put either profits or losses against the income of the farm. Yet BHP and all the big companies in Australia are allowed to do so. Labor introduced a Bill in this House in 1984 to allow companies to take that course. Although Labor members regard this tax package as reform, I do not call it reform. I cannot understand why one farming family in Australia would want to vote for the Labor Party at the next election.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard a great deal about capital gains tax. Most people have talked about it. It is a new tax and again is discriminatory. The Treasurer says that there will be no distortions in the system, but what does the great white leader, Prime Minister Hawke, say? In Perth he said that the family home will be exempted from this wonderful new reform package. We shall see palaces built around Melbourne and Sydney. The Prime Minister lives in a pretty decent sort of place in Melbourne, but no doubt we shall see him living in an even better home in Melbourne. It is a total distortion of the system. It is ridiculous. It is a move from one side of taxation to another. The worst aspect of the capital gains tax, as has been pointed out by many speakers in this debate, is that it is just the beginning. How long will the inflation component in it last? I suggest that it will not be very long. I give it to the next Budget, if not before. The inflation component of the capital gains tax will be abolished in the next Budget.

The Government says that there is no death duty component in the capital gains tax. Most families in Australia have to sell their assets that they are left and this Government will tax those assets. Most assets will be sold within 12 months or 18 months of the death of a family member. As if people are not in enough trouble following a death in a family, this Government will hound them. These people will have to pay an indirect death duty because the assets of a deceased family member will be sold and split up. As soon as this happens people will be paying 49 cents in the dollar in tax. I ask honourable members: What is fair and reasonable about that? The answer is nothing. The Government cannot be trusted.

We know that all taxes increase. Sales taxes go up and down. The level of tax paid on capital gains will go up from year to year as each Treasurer comes in and needs more funds. Unfortunately we do not seem to be able to stop injecting ourselves with the hypodermic needle that makes us spend and waste money. Dick Smith talked to us tonight about the aviation industry. It costs $450m to run this industry, and the plane per pilot cost is enormous. These are the problems that we have to look at in this country.

I think the other problem of off farm income tremendously disadvantages people who are trying to buy a farm. The Labor Party does not seem to understand that there are a lot of battlers out there who actually support the Labor Party. Many people in the electorate of Maranoa still actually vote for the Labor Party. Why they ever would I do not know. Mind you, there are not many of them left, but after this package is implemented they will all be voting for me and the National Party of Australia. There are still some people such as shearers and kangaroo shooters who still want to go out to earn an honest living and who wish to own a block of land. But this Government will stop them from doing this by taxing their off-farm income. I will be very pleased to be able to come back to this House after the next election with an even greater majority. I can tell honourable members here and now that my majority will go up because there will not be a Labor supporter left in Maranoa who will give a second thought to voting for Bob Hawke and his team at the next election.

We now have the highest real interest rates since the last Depression as a result of the deficit spending of the Government. The honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) and other honourable members try to get up and tell us that we do not have high unemployment. The unemployment figure is not down on the figure that applied under the Fraser Government. The figure is static because we have to take account of the enormous public expenditure of funds that are being made available to keep people in jobs. This situation cannot last. New Zealand is right down the tube; we are half down the tube. Unfortunately, we will be right down with New Zealand by the time honourable members opposite are finished with us. This is a very sad state of affairs. Interest rates in New Zealand are running at 30 per cent. Mr McLachlan from the National Farmers Federation spoke to us last night. It is amazing how the Prime Minister gets up in this place and tells us that he is the friend of the farmers. What rot! The NFF does not agree with one section of this package-not one. Mr McLachlan listed a whole range of things. He told us why it was that the Labor Party ought to be put out of office.

I would like to make a suggestion that I have put forward before. I am not saying that farmers will reduce the high interest rates by creating their own bank but at least if they had such a bank they would have things in their own hands and be able to control some of their destiny. I cannot see why foreign banks should be allowed in this country while farmers are forced to sit back and do nothing about their banking arrangements. I know that the big commercial banks do not like what I am saying about farmers creating their own bank. However, one needs $25m in capital to set up a bank. The farmers of Australia would easily be able to raise that amount if they transferred their funds from the present banking system into their own bank. A gearing ratio of only 6.5 per cent is needed for funds to be lent. In other words, one is allowed to lend $150m if one has capital of $25m. I believe that such an arrangement would make a lot of sense.

Before I conclude my speech I would like to mention the claim by the Treasurer that the fuel tax has been of benefit to farmers. I would like to tell the farmers in Maranoa, Gippsland, Mallee and the other good places around Australia that on average farmers are paying $3,300 in fuel tax whereas the householder is paying only $1,300. This is another example of total discrimination by the Australian Government against the farming community of Australia. Not only is the Government imposing higher taxes on farmers but also it withdrew the fuel freight subsidy a few weeks ago. I ask the Treasurer to re-introduce that subsidy.

The time available to me in this debate is almost exhausted. Before I conclude I would like to give my good friend, the Premier of Queensland, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, my full support for advocating the only real tax reform in this country, and that is a single rate of taxation. No other real reform has been mentioned. The only reform with any semblance of merit that came out of the tax summit was Joh's single tax rate. I believe it will not be until that tax is introduced that we will see good government in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —In December 1975 Australia elected a political coalition to power which had told the people that it would form a government which would stand up to the unions and lessen strikes, reduce inflation and straighten out the tax system. It would be tough and decisive. But what happened? There were seven years of toughness, the toughness of a jelly; seven years of decisiveness, the decisiveness of a sheep separated from its herd. In those seven years strikes became far worse, not better. Inflation improved little following the effect of the 1975 Hayden Budget. But, worst of all was the hidden attack on Australia's taxpayers-tax rorts, money to the bottom of the harbour, people forced into tax avoidance through the failure by the Fraser-Howard Budgets to face up to the need to reform the tax system. Who was left with the baby? It was the ordinary wage and salary earner, the bulk of the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not heard one Opposition member mention the effect of this package on the wage and salary earner. Wage and salary taxpayers will be on average $9 a week better off when the new tax system is introduced next year. Without doubt, wage and salary earners who have taxes deducted from their wages have borne the brunt of taxes while other people have developed strategies to try to avoid their share of tax. The reduction of the 60c margin will make it less worthwhile for high income earners to take up expensive tax evasion and avoidance strategies and will increase the number of people paying their fair share of tax. The raising of the threshold by $500 to $5,100 before any tax is payable will assist people who are at present trapped into poverty by the tax system. The $12,500 threshold will be increased to $12,600. These changes will apply from 1 September 1986 when the Government's receipts start to come in as a result of its attack on avoidance. Further changes will take place from 1 July 1987 when the final tax rates will drop even further. The previous Government talked about the need for reform of the tax system for a long time but it was never game to effect reform.

Another aspect of the tax package will help small business. The non-taxing of dividends has been requested by business for 30 years and at last we have a government that is prepared to do it. The tax on dividends from shares in a company no longer applies. Half the cost of doing that will be borne by a higher tax on companies and half by other government savings through anti-tax evasion measures and reduction in error through the introduction of identification cards. While large corporations are complaining, I am sure their shareholders are not; nor are small companies whose shareholders are small in number and control the amount paid in dividends. Most complaints come from corporate executives who are inclined to favour retention of funds for further investment rather than the distribution of dividends.

I note that some Opposition speakers, in spite of the fact that the capital gains tax has been explained by speaker after speaker on this side of the House, still talk of the capital gains tax as if it is a threat to the farming community. So, I am forced into repeating what previous speakers on this side of the House such as the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) have said: This new tax will apply only to assets acquired after 19 September 1985 and will be imposed at ordinary rates of personal or company income tax on realised capital gains adjusted for inflation. The tax will not, therefore, apply to capital gains derived from assets acquired by a taxpayer on or before 19 September 1985, notwithstanding that the asset concerned might not be disposed of for many years to come.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the thin end of the wedge.

—For the purpose of determining the amount of a capital gain derived by a taxpayer, the cost of the asset to the taxpayer will be adjusted upwards to reflect the increase in the consumer price index over the period during which the asset was owned by the taxpayer. Another point that has not been acknowledged by the Opposition is that realised capital losses will be able to be set off against capital gains realised in the same year or, in the absence of capital gains in that year, may be carried forwarded indefinitely and offset against gains in subsequent years.

SPEECH.PARA: The principal residence owned and occupied by a taxpayer will be exempt from the tax. Only one residence may be treated as the principal residence of a taxpayer and his or her family. I note that honourable members opposite are calling the capital gains tax the thin end of the wedge. I am sure that they do not really need to be reminded that the thin end of the wedge is already in the legislation. In fact, one Opposition member, Senator Tony Messner, actually advocated a continuation of the capital gains tax and a strengthening of existing provisions which would provide for a tax, not on realised capital gains, not on capital gains adjusted for inflation, but on capital gains increases.

The previous Government, we ought not forget, talked about the need for reform for seven long years, seven years which yielded nothing. The need for reform of the tax system has now been faced up to. It is an important working part of this Government's economic management. I support the proposals. I have noted the continuing support from the electorate, without any criticism of the capital gains tax from the many farmers or small businesses in my electorate, and with strong support from the people who have been helped most by the reform, namely, the wage and salary earners of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Labor Party's obsession with wealth distribution and its negative and destructive opposition to society's small business and rural wealth creators have come through only too clearly as the principal theme in the tax reform package. It is the Hawke Government's greatest monument so far to the politics of envy. The evidence for this is simply that the wealth creating business sector is being asked to bear the bulk of the burden created by this package. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) pointed this out quite clearly in his statement of 19 September. He quite surprisingly recognised the link between wealth creation, profits, jobs and growth. The Treasurer, in Attachment C to his tax statements, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Ultimately, of course, the corporate burden will be shifted to individuals. The burden is likely to be borne by corporate shareholders via reduced dividends and/or slower growth in the value of shares reflecting lower retained earnings.

What the Treasurer is saying is that the tax package will reduce profits and the effect of that fall in profits will ultimately flow through to the rest of the community. Community wealth, as every bush economist knows, is created by productive investment. Funds for investment come either directly or indirectly from profits; even loan funds must be repaid ultimately out of profits; and equity is unlikely to be invested in an unprofitable firm. The tax package makes a direct assault on profits and on investment. It is a quite alarming and savage attack on business, on Australia's wealth creators.

Let us look at just a few of the details. First, there is the invidious tax on fringe benefits. This tax is a direct assault on wealth creation for a number of reasons. It is a tax misdirected against business rather than against the beneficiaries of the benefits-and, therefore, it attacks corporate profitability. On this latter point, the Treasurer's taxation White Paper stated:

The best approach, in principle, would be to include the defined value of fringe benefits in the employee's assessable income so that tax would be paid on total remuneration, whether received as salaries or wages or by way of fringe benefits, at the employee's personal tax rate.

Why did the Government not follow the `best approach'? We all know the answer: The Australian Council of Trade Unions would not accept it. Simon said no. The result is an anti-business tax which will cost the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd alone $15m a year. It is a tax which discriminates against small businesses, which have less capacity to meet the higher wages bill than big business. Consequently, the more talented employees in small business will be attracted to big business, which can put together better salary packages. Small business, about which the Labor Party does not care, will be the loser.

This tax is also a breach of fundamental principles of tax law-that is, the tax liability incurred by an employee is being borne by a non-beneficiary. It is the first time in Australia's history that such a basic principle has been stood on its head. But it is the detailed aspects of the fringe benefits tax which principally weaken the wealth creation mechanisms of Australia. The tax is obviously a tax on employment. It will force up the cost of jobs to employers and thereby will make a contribution-the Labor Party has never worried about this-to unemployment. In taxing those employers, in taxing business and in forcing people out of jobs, it is attacking ordinary Australians, not just the rich. It is doing that in a lot of other ways.

For example, those employees who receive low interest loans, such as employees of banks, typically earn less than average weekly earnings. If the employer, the bank, refuses to pay the extra tax which the Labor Government has imposed on it, that will reduce the income of those employees by 14 per cent. Let us take the example of those employees who are provided with cars by their employers. Seventy per cent of these people receive cars in the Commodore-Falcon range. These employees are not the rich. They are not people with Rolls Royces and BMWs. These are people who are earning approximately average weekly earnings.

The effect also on employees in the car industry and on the car industry as a whole will clearly be deleterious. The Australian Automobile Dealers Association has forecast a loss of 50,000 units a year. That forecast may well be an exaggeration; I do not know. But the point is perfectly clear. John Spalvins, the chief executive of the Adelaide Steamship Co. Ltd, made that point only too clearly when recently-just two days ago-he said that, as a result of this tax, 4,000 cars in his fleet will no longer be provided. That will be at a cost of $50m to the automotive industry. Its effect on South Australia which is moving towards a State election will clearly be particularly harmful.

I believe the fringe benefits tax will disrupt the Button car industry plan-the plan which has generally been welcomed by members of this Parliament-because employers will move away from the larger car market and buy smaller cars for their employees. Honourable members opposite will certainly not know that, by moving towards buying smaller cars, employers will be moving towards cars which have a lower local content. Moving towards cars with a lower local content will disrupt, if not destroy, the Labor Party's own car plan.

A further deleterious effect of this absurd fringe benefits tax has been the wrangle over whether the States will pay the tax. All the Premiers, except Mr Cain, who presumably has been preoccupied with manifold crises of his own, have said that they will not pay the tax. South Australia has said it will not pay the $5m that the Commonwealth will try to extract from it. This is the first time in Australia's history that the Commonwealth Government has run the constitutional gauntlet of trying to extract taxation from State governments. All I can say is that that underlies the complete absurdity of the fringe benefits tax, a tax which, as I have pointed out, will undo generations of taxation laws, create absurd anomalies and weaken the wealth creation sectors of the economy. The capital gains tax will also have this effect. Honourable members have spoken about this at some length.

Let me make one simple point. Capital accumulation is central to economic growth. Income does not come out of thin air; it comes from the combination of capital and labour. Capital is the source of jobs; it is the source of wealth for the future. Any sensible, intelligent government should encourage, not discourage capital accumulation. That is why the American Government is reducing its capital gains tax rate. That is why the Canadians, and even the Socialist Mitterrand Government of France, with all its faults, are doing precisely the same thing.

The Labor Party argues that this capital gains tax is a mild capital gains tax and that it will not affect current asset holders. As the honourable member for Forde (Dr Watson) has pointed out, that is utter and arrant nonsense. It will depress the value of existing assets. As the honourable member also pointed out, who would deny that an asset bought on 18 September would cost a higher price than one bought on 20 September? In other words, the value of farmers' land, the value of property in general, will fall, but so will the value of the capital stock of small businesses. That is capital which is needed for future trading. It would have created growth and jobs. It is also capital which is reasonably needed for the provision of adequate retirement funds, a point repeatedly made by the Small Business Corporation of South Australia, which was established by the Bannon Labor Government.

The capital gains tax will also distort investment patterns, particularly in housing. I admit that it will force up some prices. Those prices will be the land and property prices in places such as Toorak and Vaucluse. People will sell the properties they are renting and put those investment funds into the one thing that is free of the capital gains tax-their own homes. Clearly, the effect of selling those other properties will be a shortage of rental accommodation, a rise in rents-because there will be less investment in rented accommodation-and a shortage of rental accommodation which already exists to a very serious extent. For example, in Sydney the problem will be exacerbated and again the losers will not be high income earners or the rich people. The losers will be the low income earners and those who are dependent on social security who have to use rental accommodation.

Of course, the biggest losers from the Labor Party's tax plan and its capital gains tax will be small business people. They are the people who ultimately will lose the incentive to invest, lose the incentive to create jobs and lose the incentive to build the economy of Australia. That is why ultimately this aspect of the tax package is little more than a savage attack on wealth creation.

I would like to refer tonight to one other aspect of the tax package. It is one which perhaps has not been debated very much so far. I refer to the foreign tax credit system. Again this is part of what the Labor Party is all about-undermining wealth creation. The measure has been around for some time. It has been opposed by the business community, it has been opposed by business associations but the Treasurer and his Party have been deaf. The effect of this tax will be perfectly clear. In the main it will impose a higher tax on those companies which have overseas earnings, on those companies, for example, which invest in the United Kingdom where they would pay 35 per cent company tax or in countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations where the tax is 40 per cent, or in the United States of America where it will be reduced to 33 per cent. Such companies will now be hit with a tax rate of 49 per cent whereas their competitors from those countries will still pay the lower company tax rates charged in those countries. To make this point perfectly clear, let me quote what the Business Council of Australia has said about the foreign tax credit system. It stated:

. . . the imposition of a foreign tax credit system will have a serious and negative effect on existing overseas business operations of Australian companies, and restrict desirable future investment with an attendent depressing effect on Australia's trade growth through development in and commitment to, overseas markets.

It will inhibit the ability of Australian companies to expand by seeking economies of scale beyond the constraints of the Australian domestic market. Ultimately, this will result in lower economic and employment growth within Australia.

The Labor Party does not care about that. It is not even listening to the points that the Business Council has made. We all know why. The Labor Party hates multinationals but we never guessed that the multinationals it hated the most were Australian multinationals.

Finally, I express my deep concern about the quarantining of farm losses, a point that other members have made quite solidly. This quarantining is an ignorant assault on primary producers who have already been brought to their knees by the big spending, big taxing madness of Labor. I say `ignorant' because the Government makes two false assumptions: Firstly it assumes that investment by Rundle Street or Collins Street farmers damages the rural community. The reverse is the case. Those people provide much needed investment capital for country towns and communities and their withdrawal will depress land prices and economic activity, thereby lowering the level of the assets of primary producers.

The second false assumption is that the practice of earning additional income and offsetting it against farm losses is conducted only by wealthy doctors and airline pilots. Many farmers need extra jobs especially during a rural depression which, of course, they are experiencing at present. Many of them shear part time or even full time; many work as truck drivers and do all sorts of other activities many of which the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) referred to earlier. In the United States 60 per cent of farmers earn income in this way to supplement the very small incomes they get from their enterprises. It is an economically irrational measure because it is inconsistent. Elsewhere, the losses in one part of a business can be offset against the profits of another. For example, if one had a delicatessen and a dry cleaning business one could offset the losses of one against the profits of the other but when it comes to the rural community and rural investment, the Labor Party hates them. It has discriminated against them and it is reducing still further rural incomes and rural investment.

I end where I began. This is the tired, tried formula of the politics of envy which is so much part and parcel of the tried and tired Labor philosophy. The Labor Party has never been interested in wealth creation; it is interested only in wealth distribution and redistribution and that is what this tax package is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace Mr E.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I congratulate the Government on its efforts to reconstruct the taxation system. During the 1984 election campaign the Hawke Government made a commitment to change and restructure the tax system which, for many years, has been favouring those on high incomes. Honourable members will also recall that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) set out nine principles on tax reform and before any reform took place all nine principles had to be met. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) was relentless in his efforts to change the system which exists today.

SPEECH.PARA: One must stop and think why we need tax reform. Why reduce personal income tax rates and introduce new taxes? Why? Because people with large disposable incomes have been avoiding paying their fair share of tax. The middle income earners with salaries between $19,500 and $35,000 have had to bear the brunt of the tax burden. They are the ones paying more and more tax. What do the two words `tax reform' mean? I will try to explain them. Tax reform is about creating a fair and equitable society for all Australians, not just a few who, because of their privileged positions, can decide that they do not want to pay tax. This practice has gone on for far too long and the Government has set about correcting those anomalies so that every person who works pays his fair share of tax, whether it be through wages and salaries or through a capital gains tax.

The capital gains tax is a very interesting part of our package. From 19 September 1985 it will apply to those who have bought property or invested their money for the specific purpose of gaining capital income. This violates the horizontal equity principle since it favours those who take their income as capital and discriminates against those who earn their money through wages and salaries. It also undermines the progressivity of the tax system. Honourable members opposite and the poor little rich farmers say that they will be discriminated against, but they will not be. If they already own their own property and wish to pass it on to their children without having to pay tax on it, they will be able to do so.

Farmers will also benefit from the reduction in the marginal rate of income tax and the lifting of the tax threshold. Only the Pitt Street and Collins Street farmers, who invest in farming because of its attraction as a tax shelter, will suffer. An example of this is the quarantining of farm losses. This provision will help genuine farmers. It will also help those farmers who may need to acquire additional properties for grazing and it will help people who wish to start a new life on a farm. Apparently many people in Australia are willing to do that, but because the Pitt Street farmers have taken up land as tax shelters land prices have been at a premium level. Because land will not be worth buying for taxation purposes more properties will come onto the market, so obviously land will be cheaper. We will also reduce the top rate of income tax from 60c in the dollar to 49c in the dollar. The 48c and 46c marginal rates will be reduced to 40c.

TALK.START.PARA: —They didn't do anything, Ted.

—Those changes will be introduced over two years. As the honourable member for Chifley has remined me, the previous Government did not do anything. Of course, the two lowest rates will be reduced by one per cent. These reductions will mean that no taxpayer in Australia will pay more than half his salary or wages in tax. As I have travelled around my electorate and visited my local branches of the Australian Labor Party I have noticed some dissatisfaction with the way the Government has reduced substantially the higher rates while reducing the rate for those in the low income bracket by only one per cent. I say to them what I will say here tonight: It is not those in the lower bracket who can afford to set up tax shelters, invest in property and write it off. We want to reduce the higher rates so that people on high incomes will be discouraged from avoiding paying their fair share of tax.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out to the House that we have not forgotten the low income earners. In November last year we gave low and middle income earners tax cuts averaging $7.60 a week, which cost the Government in the vicinity of $2.5 billion. We have helped low income families under the prices and incomes accord and through the introduction of Medicare. Since we came to power those on incomes of $240 have had an increase of around 13 per cent over and above wage indexation. We are gradually eliminating poverty traps, having taken major steps in that area, and we have taken positive steps in this most recent reform package. We will increase the allowable earnings of pensioners so that single pensioners will be able to earn up to $40 a week and married pensioners up to $70 a week before their pensions are affected. Along with the increases in the tax free threshold and the indexation of pensions in line with the consumer price index, this will go a long way towards helping those unfortunate people.

Social security beneficiaries who are renting in the private sector are entitled to rent assistance, which is now subject to an income test. We will abolish this income test, which was one of the most severe traps this Government inherited from the previous Government. In effect, the application of the income test deterred pensioners from earning any further income because of the threat of losing some of their benefits, therefore they fell further and further behind average worker income levels. We have helped restore some form of dignity to those people. In the last two years of the Fraser Government social security beneficiaries were far worse off than they are now. Since we came to office we have increased the unemployment benefit by $27, in line with the CPI. That is helping those people who were put out of work under the previous Government to survive while this Government sets about creating new job opportunities for them.

I turn to fringe benefits. Millions of dollars go back into the pockets of big companies, company executives and high-ranking officials. Fringe benefits, offered in the form of packages, are used to attract employees. This is a shameful practice. Let me outline some of the deals that have been done. Let us look at a marketing executive. He may be paid a salary of $50,000 per annum and he would be offered a package as follows: A car worth $30,000; overseas travel worth $10,000; either education for his children or a low interest housing loan, worth roughly $4,000, a grand total of $94,000 yet he pays tax on only $50,000. As well, he is able to claim on his tax return each year entertainment and expense allowances such as providing drinks, business meals-or so-called business meals-cocktail parties, staff social functions, sightseeing tours for the wife of a client or someone he wishes to impress and entertainment allowance for his wife just to hand around the gin and tonics. Honourable members opposite would be very familiar with this practice. The ordinary worker in the street does not have access to these deceitful and shameful practices which mean that such people pay little or no income tax.

The Government has not stopped here. It is going further to catch those who abuse the system by claiming more than one social security payment or the cheat who has one job during the day and another during the evening under an assumed name. To eradicate yet another deceitful practice we will introduce a national identification card, commonly referred to as the Australia Card. I believe that this is probably one of the most important parts of our taxation package. It will be a card along the lines of the Medicare card. It will contain only a name, an address and a person's signature. I must admit that I would have liked to have seen us go the whole hog and put a photograph on it-but that is a personal opinion. To guard against improper use of the Australia Card, legislation will be introduced to assist in combating tax evasion and to reduce the scope of abuse of the social security system and other government allowances. It will also help identify illegal immigrants and others working in Australia who are not entitled to do so.

The card will also be used to aid in the identification of participants in certain financial transactions, such as opening, closing and operating bank accounts and the payment of interest. It will also help to identify persons lawfully entitled to undertake work in Australia for tax linkage purposes and persons entitled to government benefits, pensions and other income support. The introduction of the Australia Card will provide the long overdue means of ensuring that everybody pays his fair share of tax. An increase in the amount of taxation revenue will be the major benefit derived from the introduction of such a card.

I will now discuss the next part of this Government's tax reform package. When wage and salary earners earn their money, tax is taken out by the employer. What do we do with those other people who earn income throughout the year? At present they pay tax in one lump sum. We will introduce a system whereby compulsory quarterly provisional tax will be paid at the beginning of each quarter. Only about 800,000 provisional taxpayers will be affected, being those with a provisional tax liability of over $2,000 per year. The amount of tax payable will not be changed-only the date on which it is to be paid. People with fluctuating incomes will be permitted, under special circumstances, to undertake an alternative pattern of instalment payment. This will be available to any taxpayer who can prove to the Commissioner of Taxation that he will receive more than three-quarters of his gross yearly income after the earliest due date for the second instalment of provisional tax; that is, in December.

I am proud to be a member of the second Hawke Government-a government that has set about ensuring that we have a fairer and more just system of taxation which will help those who are more disadvantaged in our community. Along with other Government members, I do not want our constituents to be subsidising with their hard-earned money people such as those honourable members opposite whose constituents have been taking advantage of a system set up by the Liberals for the Liberals and who do not worry about anybody else.

The then Treasurer and now Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) failed to bring in any reform that would ensure that all Australians benefited from being in such a rich nation as ours. It is in the self-perpetuating interest of honourable members opposite to oppose this tax reform package, but they know in their own hearts that what this Government is doing will be of benefit to the nation as a whole in the future. I give my full support to this package and commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a source of wonder to honourable members on this side of the House to hear two lines coming from the other side again and again. The first is the parrot phrasing that this great reformation of the Australian taxation system that the Government has brought about is what the Government and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) intended to do. We all know that it was not what the Treasurer intended. It just happens to be what the Treasurer ended up with. The second point is the attack upon the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) to the effect that he was unable to get radical tax reform proposals through. We all know that the option which the Treasurer wanted was denied to him. What happened? He was unable to get through the radical tax reform proposals on which he had set his heart so dearly, and in respect of which he allowed the possibility, which he did not finally carry out, that if he did not get his way he might leave and go elsewhere. He has not left. We still have him. That is bad for the Australian people but good for those of us in opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The need for reformation of the tax system is undisputed. The history of this package is known-I have just referred to it. It was sired on a talk-back show when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), as a passing idea, decided that a tax summit would be a good idea and Ben Hur, as the Treasurer described himself, got over the line with half a chariot intact, looking as though he was a refugee from a natural disaster. The objectives of a reform package for a tax system should be to improve growth, foster initiative and promote international competitiveness. Those objectives are desperately needed in this country, as a survey of principal economic indicators will show.

We have a deficit on current account for the past financial year of $10.1 billion. We depend on the inflow of foreign capital to keep the money system afloat. Last year, $9.8 billion of foreign capital flowed into this country. The gross overseas debt has escalated in a manner that can only be described as astonishing and deeply worrying. In June 1975, it was about $6 billion. By June 1984, it had grown to just on $45 billion. By June 1985, it was just on $68.5 billion, an increase in 12 months of over $20 billion. Does anybody really believe that we can afford to continue to borrow at this rate and that the financial system of this country can stand those kinds of strains? Apparently the Treasurer and this Government do, as they treat these indicators with a disdain which is as astonishing as the ignorance displayed is frightening.

Public debt interest, again, is reaching astonishing proportions. If one looks to the detail, one finds that in 1984-85, excluding payments to the States, it was the fourth largest item of Budget outlays. For the 1985-86 financial year it is estimated that it will be equal second, so that before we can do anything we have to pay a steadily increasing proportion of income tax to meet the interest on our public debt. Real interest rates are historically high. I will give the figures for public debt interest. In 1984-85 interest on our public debt was $5,656,000,000. In 1985-86 it is estimated that it will have increased by more than a billion dollars to $6,724,000,000. As I said, it will be in equal second position, putting to one side the States grants. It is now ahead of defence in terms of outlays. That amount is just to keep government borrowings afloat. Of course, that is not just government borrowings of this Government but accumulated borrowings which are being made very much worse and are at a very much higher rate because of the economic policies entered into by this Government.

Real interest rates are historically high, the highest since the Great Depression. Apparently this is a source of pride to the Treasurer. He has said in this House: `Look, people are borrowing now to invest, not like when you were in power, when they were borrowing to stay afloat'. Does anybody really believe that people are borrowing at these historically high interest rates simply for the purpose of investment? It is the most transparent nonsense. What about the value of the Australian dollar? If one ever wished to see a vote of no confidence in this country's currency and its financial management, it is to be found there. In the 12 months since September 1984, our currency has dropped by just over 14 per cent against the United States dollar, by just on 25 per cent against the Japanese yen and by just over 19 per cent on the trade weighted index. What a marvellous performance; what a performance that we can be proud of! Perhaps we can bring our dollar down even lower. Perhaps we can get an Australian dollar which will buy us 50 cents in the US dollar market.

For another vote of no confidence in this Government's economic management, let us look at private Australian overseas investment. It is another first for the Hawke Government. In 1983-84, Australian private investment overseas amounted to $1,953m. In 1984-85, in the first full financial year after the exchange controls on overseas investment had been virtually wiped to one side, private overseas investment amounted to $2,980m-and this at a time when our currency was going downward. What are people saying? They are saying that it is better to invest out of Australia than in Australia. It is not overseas investors who are saying that, but Australian investors. Effectively, therefore, we are borrowing ourselves into oblivion. We have currency which is going downhill and we have a flight of capital from this country for the very good reason that people believe that they can do better overseas and are worried about what will take place here, about the consequences of this Government's economic policies.

Let me say something about a few of the specific measures in this taxation package-the capital gains tax, death duties, the foreign tax issue and entertainment expenses. As to capital gains, we are told that we will be taxed only at the marginal rate. Is that not perfectfully marvellous? When we look at how the system works, what does it mean to us? It means effectively that almost everyone will be taxed at the highest rate because, if a person has a capital gain of any sort at all that will be lumped in with his other income for the purposes of determining the rate at which he should be paying tax. If this Government is lucky enough that the rates can ever be brought down to 49 per cent-it is making some assumptions about growth that many commentators dispute-we will see a top rate of 49 per cent and a capital gains tax at that rate. This tax will be disincentive to Australian entepreneurs, a disincentive to small business and a tax on small business. It will be an incentive to cheat, to invest overseas and to engage in off-shore tax aviodance. The Treasurer has breathed life back into the tax planning community in a stroke. For foreign investors it is a marked disincentive to investment in this country, because the capital gains taxes in other major countries such as the United States of America and Britain are lower than here. What would one do? One would invest where one could get the best possible rate.

I turn to death duties. It has been said-I heard the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) say it-that there is no death duty in the package presented. What absolute nonsense! The only charitable thing one can say of him is that he has not understood it. The Treasurer, in his statement, said:
The Government has decided that the deemed realisation at death proposal, outlined in the draft White Paper, will not apply.
That is reassuring, one would think. Then, when one turns to the fine print, one sees the following statement:

Capital gains tax will not be levied following the death of a taxpayer unless his or her assets are actually realised by the administrator of the deceased estate or disposed of by a beneficiary of the estate.

Does the Treasurer not understand what happens when people die? They either leave a will or die intestate. If they die intestate, the whole of the estate is realised. When they leave a will, almost invariably they make some specific bequests but the bulk of the estate is sold up and divided amongst those they want to benefit. In most cases those persons are members of their family. What does that mean, therefore? It means capital gains. What will the taxation rates be? In most cases, if we are looking at an estate, we are once again looking at a capital gains tax at a very high rate. What does that amount to? It amounts to death duties, pure and simple, at a punitive level. We are given this bogus and despicable argument that no death duties are involved in this package.

The foreign tax credit system has been extolled by the Treasurer and by honourable members opposite as though it was going to be of some marvellous benefit to this country. Let us look at how it will work. At present, foreign source income on which tax is paid is exempt from income tax. What does the foreign tax credit proposal mean? It means that investors will be taxed on their overseas earnings at the same rate at which they would pay tax on Australian earnings. What will that do? It will encourage Australian organisations to disinvest. It will prevent us from building up overseas Australian-owned business which will repatriate dividends into this country and help us to shore up our current account. Some would remember that it was a major reason for Britain's former economic strength that it had major overseas investments. The loss of those investments has been one of the reasons why Britain fell into such parlous economic conditions. Therefore, the medium to long term effect will be a contraction of our overseas investment. As has been made apparent, that contraction may take place very much more quickly than some thought. Indeed, Sir Tristan Antico of Pioneer Concrete Services Limited has raised the question of the disposition or flotation of the company's foreign-owned organisations because of these great reforms in the tax system.

We also have the abolition of entertainment expenses. Of course entertainment expenses can be abused. Nobody would dispute that. But if we look at what has been done elsewhere such as in Britain, we see that they have been specifically curtailed and that they can be curtailed. Those here who would say that entertainment expenses have no part in business have not the least idea of the way in which business operates, particularly business that has to deal with overseas customers such as the Japanese. It is an integral part of dealing with the Japanese that we entertain them. What are we going to do? Are we to wipe away entertainment expenses because of the politics of envy and push another impost on to business? This proposal has been attacked by different elements of the Australian community across the nation. It is deceitful in the way in which it seeks to tell the community that there will be no death duty. There will be a death duty. It betrays the thrifty, punishes families on death, taxes small business and, above all, exemplifies the politics of envy which, despite some of the modern protestations of the Labor Party, are embedded into it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that the speech we just heard was particularly elucidating for all those people in Australia who are now being accused of being envious-those hundreds of thousands of Australians who over the years have had to support those people who have had the opportunity to defraud this country through all forms of tax evasion. So far today we have heard this Opposition proclaim the virtues of tax shelters, non-compliance schemes and the maintenance of privilege for the privileged. That is what we heard espoused just a moment ago-the maintenance of privilege for the privileged. Those people who demur in that regard are called envious. These people who have been paying the larger burden of tax in this country are called envious because they do not wish to continue to do that on such an inequitable basis. All this talk is about making certain that there is some equity in the system. The tax reform package is not about revenue raising; it is a matter of ensuring that those people in the community who have not been meeting their tax responsibilities actually do so.

SPEECH.PARA: At no time has the Opposition indicated any commitment whatsoever to the tax burden imposed on those who have had to shoulder the burden for so long, largely under conservative governments. It is not particularly surprising-to the contrary-that this state of affairs has developed in the many years of conservative government in this country. Had there been some concern to ensure that the tax burden should be shared equitably we would have seen at least some evidence over the years that there was some desire to implement reform. Not only have we not seen that but also the Opposition, when in government, had the political means to implement such a policy because it controlled both houses of the Parliament. There were no impediments, except a lack of will, a lack of courage and, in fact, of course, a perception by some people who thought because of their privileged position that they should be able to avoid taxes. The Opposition turned away from the issue and allowed non-compliance in the area of tax responsibility to be refined into an industry of evasion and avoidance.

We now find a belief that the new class of the privileged should be protected at the expense of the great majority of Australians-those who are the pay as you earn taxpayers. The privileged people are now screaming because they are being asked to pay their share. The representatives of these people on the Opposition benches are screaming with them. For them it makes no sense to try to right the wrongs in the system even though it is irrefutable that reform is long overdue. The tactic that we are now witnessing from the Opposition is to look at the supposed manifestations of endangered jobs. We recognise, of course, that some of these jobs have been created-in tax shelter industry. If these people were honest they would come to the nub of the matter. Since they have allowed the imbalance in the system to develop, even though they have been aware of the inequities, they could at least say what their actions imply, namely: `We believe that the PAYE taxpayer should be prepared to support those whose incomes are made otherwise'. Why do they not say this? Obviously they believe that the PAYE taxpayers do not deserve to be protected against those who use the non-compliance devices to minimise tax payments. Why do these people not come clean and admit that they believe that there are two classes of citizens where tax payment is concerned, those who are PAYE taxpayers and those who can choose to pay tax if they so desire?

During the 1950s Federal taxes collected from income taxes represented 30 per cent of government revenue. Today it is more than 50 per cent. Because of the unchecked bracket creep PAYE taxpayers have been pushed into higher brackets. At that time 30 years ago it was necessary for a person to be earning nearly 19 times the average weekly income to be taxed at the top rate. However, today that person would have to earn only 1.6 times the average weekly income. That is not something which has happened overnight; it has been evident for years. There has not, however, been any preparedness on the part of the Opposition to do anything about it. In 1955 the person on the average weekly income would have faced a marginal taxation rate of 19 per cent. Today that person would be taxed at a rate of 46 per cent. Hence we have the need to address this issue and to reduce the marginal rates. This drift upwards took effect unchecked and unrelieved during what was largely the reign of the Liberal and National parties.

I repeat that during that time the privileged people in this society were able to take advantage of devices which were developed by the tax evasion and tax avoidance industry. This was done quite deliberately and was known to the Opposition when in government. Those people in government in 1977-some of whom might be listening tonight-will recall having promised, in the course of an election campaign by the Fraser Government, to give relief to all PAYE taxpayers. We all know what happened following that election. The Government said: `Terribly sorry; can't deliver'. It dealt the Australian electorate a massive confidence trick. That Government then compounded its deception by refusing to tackle the main problems in the system. Only under the impact of a concerted campaign by the Australian Labor Party was that Government dragged screaming into a belated attempt to block the use of bottom of the harbour devices.

There is no denying the fact that governments of today now require greater revenue than did governments in earlier times. Even though the Government is determined to reduce the deficit it still has major outlay imperatives to meet. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) deserves to be congratulated on the product of his labours. He has attempted to reform the tax system, as far as the community could be expected to adjust to it, while at the same time he has moved in this package to ensure that the poor in this country are given relief. All this cannot be done without some people being required to relinquish some of their privileges. Whether they be politicians, journalists, unionists or businessmen and women they cannot expect to continue to receive the benefits of a system which increased their purchasing power outside the taxation system. For the great majority of PAYE taxpayers these devices, known as non-cash fringe benefits and related devices, are simply not available.

Back in 1955 people who earned 1.6 times the average weekly income paid about 54 per cent of income tax collected. What is the situation we face today? That group earning 1.6 times the average weekly income now pays only 21 per cent of total taxes collected. Who now pays the remainder? Obviously those on lower and middle incomes pay. Those on higher incomes often really have a choice as to whether they will pay tax at all. The Opposition has never been concerned about these matters.

The Opposition has been crying out about the proposed imposition of a moderate capital gains tax. The previous speaker, the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), tried to fool the people of Australia by calling that a death duty. This capital gains tax is only a mild broadening of the existing capital gains taxes already in place. It is not essentially a revenue earning device. We have been asked why we are doing it. If honourable members opposite are honest in asking that question, they are either thick or they cannot read. The capital gains tax is an economic device to redirect investment capital into more productive areas. To see whether or not this is likely to be achieved, I suggest that people look at the activity on the nation's stock exchanges since this annoucement. I feel sorry for honourable members opposite because they are embarrassed by the Government's courage in tackling the taxation scandal when over the years they have done absolutely nothing because, as I said, they neither had the courage nor the will.

Some honourable members opposite are saying how sorry they feel for those who make money by capital gain but who might have to pay a tax on it if property is bought after 19 September 1985. It is a rather pathetic pleading for the retention of the bastions of privilege. Such capital gains increase the purchasing power of those people. Everybody else in the community whose purchasing power is increased is required to pay a tax. We are now being asked for the ordinary taxpayer to subsidise these people. That obviously will not do. There is little appreciation of the inequities in the present system and little honest endeavour to examine the real benefits of the measures that the Government has introduced. It would be easy for us all to be misled into thinking that the misuses or the measures were all about cutting down on tax evasion, imposing a new capital gains tax and cutting out the advantages bestowed by the lurks and perks. However, we must also see that the Government is firmly committed to assisting that section of the community caught in the cycle of poverty. This is a difficult area to tackle, but the measures to alleviate some of the problems of poverty traps will give considerable relief to these people. The pension-free area of income will be raised by $10 per week for single pensioners to $40 per week. That is up 100 per cent since we assumed office. It will be increased to $70 per week for a couple, which is up from $40, again since we took office.

The removal of the separate income test on rent assistance will mean for 300,000 social security pensioners and beneficiaries an increase of the equivalent of $15 per week. The increase in the income disregarded for each child of a pensioner is increased from $6 to $12 and is a real buffer against the poverty trap. I am very proud to belong to a government which has had the guts to tackle an issue which was long overdue to be tackled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the last week the Parliament met, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) submitted to the House the tax reform package. This is the subject that we are debating tonight. I wonder, when we see most of the legislation, whether there may be some changes to what the Treasurer has already actually determined within the package. My mind goes back to the assets test legislation when the Government changed its mind three times before we saw the final legislation passed here by the Parliament.
—And it was still a mess.

—It was still a mess. I hope they have learned from some of the mistakes that were made at that time. I look upon this tax package as more or less a band-aid affair. I think that any government entering the tax reform field would look first of all to the years ahead to see what its expenditure would be and impose a tax accordingly. The Treasurer and the Cabinet must have a very firm idea about the funds they have to raise because of the responsibility they have when spending that money. It is interesting to look at the history of the Government since the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said in Perth during the last election campaign that a taxation summit would be held. That summit was held. It was a disaster. It was a disaster because the packages that the Treasurer placed before it were unacceptable, not only to the unions and to industry, but to everybody who was represented at that summit. My friend the honourable member for Page (Mr Ian Robinson) said only this evening that the farmers who rallied outside Parliament House were promised by the Prime Minister that there would be relief for the primary producers of Australia in his tax packages. But what relief have we seen? I do not have a lot of faith in what this tax reform will produce for Australia. I refer in particular to the capital gains issue, the fringe benefits issue and negative gearing.

SPEECH.PARA: Compared with the rest of the world, Australia is a young developing country. I would accept that in Europe and maybe in the United States of America-they may even do away with their very small capital gains tax-a capital gains tax is suitable because they are developed countries. Our country is not developed to the potential that many Australians would like to see. We do not want to create any impediments, either by way of legislation or by any other way that will stop this country from developing and producing the food, the minerals and the necessities of life for the rest of the world and to encourage the personal initiative and motivation that this country needs and which is not being given by this Government. I cannot see that and certainly nobody has convinced me of that.

One has to look only at the growth in the gross domestic product which the Prime Minister and the Treasurer talk about at length every Question Time. Forty-two per cent of that comes from government initiative. This is not what this country wants. We want a situation where people are encouraged to do things. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren), spoke about the pay as you earn taxpayer receiving a reduction in tax. We welcome that. We think that that is a wonderful initiative. However, I wonder whether it is as good as the Treasurer said. If one does a little mathematics, one finds that a person on a gross salary of $15,000 as at July 1985 paid tax of $2,726, resulting in a net pay of $12,274. Allowing for an 8 per cent increase in salary by July 1987, that person will receive a salary of $17,496-an increase of 16.6 per cent. His tax will be $3,219, an increase of 18.1 per cent. His net pay will be $14,277, an increase of 16.3 per cent. If the growth of 8 per cent in wages were to continue, this same tax payer would be pushed into the higher 40 per cent tax bracket by the end of 1988. They are the PAYE taxpayers of this country.

So far as this Government is concerned, there is no indexation of taxation. A million workers in this country will enter higher tax brackets. Place upon them the extra sales tax in certain commodities that they have to meet, and the PAYE people in Australia will be no better off under this Goverment. They are the people who this Government should be helping. I ask: Why does this Government always support big unions, big business and the Left? This is a typical example. It is no use the Government talking about the PAYE people. It is not going to assist them. It never did. It always hurts the working man.

I challenge the Treasurer to bring us out of his ideological bondage with socialism in this country. I challenge the Treasurer to continue on the path that he spoke about when he presented those papers to the National Taxation Summit in this chamber. I challenge him to do that. If he wanted the consumption tax, why was it killed? Why were other initiatives killed-initiatives that were possibly acceptable to the bulk of the people of Australia? The answer was no because the unions said no, big business said no, and the Left here agreed. That is why there has been a rape of the taxation system.

I spoke a little while ago about initiative and the 730,000 small businesses within Australia. They comprise people with initiative who have to be encouraged. They are the people in relation to whom Labor considered imposing a special service tax, but there was pressure and the Government had to yield to it. The Treasurer did a deal with the unions on a 2 per cent reduction in pay until 1986. People in the 730,000 small businesses work up to 60 or 70 hours a week and they do not depend on any government to pay them an age pension or to give them any assistance. Are they not the types of people we must assist?

I should like now to deal with capital gains. The honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) dealt with this matter very clearly in terms of the effect of such a tax on primary industry. The Treasurer should know that negative gearing and a capital gains tax will rob the little investor of the incentive to provide housing and other services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—It is all very well for the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) to take that attitude, but many more people will be seeking his assistance, if he is still here. This will kill the incentive of people to erect accommodation for low income earners. The Real Estate Institute of New South Wales was correct in saying that there will be a great rise in the cost of rental accommodation-and who will pay? It will be the young family, the working man who has not yet had the opportunity to purchase his own home or unit. Let us consider the position of the farmer. I appreciate that the capital gains tax is not in place now, but it will be. It is all very well for Government members to say that it will yield only $25 million over a five-year period.
—It is the foot in the door.

—Yes, the primary industries do not trust the Government because it has its foot in the door. That is the important thing. Labor members can talk of Pitt Street and Collins Street farmers. Let them not forget that 42,000 farmers are estimated by the National Farmers Federation to have to work off their properties in order to pay off their farms and get sufficient money on which to live. What does the Government intend to do? Does it intend to tax those people? Labor has an embedded hatred of people who own anything. Why is the primary producer, who is responsible for so much of this nation's income, under attack, besieged the whole time by a Labor Government? I cannot understand it. Primary producers employ people and create the affluence within the community that allows Australia to develop. They are the people this Government is out to knock.

SPEECH.PARA: There is the question of death duties to be considered. Let it not be said that there are no death duties because there are. Death duties are embedded in the Government's capital gains tax. If Labor members look at the tax, they will soon find out; and if they do not know, the primary industries, business and the ordinary man in the street will tell them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense!

—The honourable member for Calare will know it, because he has people in his electorate who will be affected, as has the member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow). They will both realise what will happen before long. As to the quarantining of the primary producer, I do not know what those words were conceived to mean, but we will find out before long because, once again, the farmer will be knocked.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Education Funding-United Nations Declaration-Telecom-Proposed New Army Base-Sri Lanka: Tamil Population-Privatisation-Emergency Relief-Petrol Prices-Parents Without Partners-Production of Hansard

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.15 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the adjournment tonight I wish to speak briefly about the planning and funding policies for new non-government schools in relation to yesterday's announcement of those schools which were to receive funding. I wish also to refer to a news report about the schools that would not receive funding as a consequence of this Government's decision. I wish particularly to speak in support of a school just outside my electorate which is attended by students from my electorate. I refer to Our Lady of Lebanon School, Harris Park. It is one of the schools that applied for recurrent funding for the secondary school curriculum it seeks to develop in a new junior secondary school at Harris Park. The school has operated for some years as a primary school and now seeks to extend its operations with a year 7 program for next year, with additional years being added to the program in subsequent years. We now have the first evidence of the restrictive new guidelines approved by the Hawke Labor Government for the establishment of new non-government schools. This indicates the Government's philosophy and its approach, and there are case studies that one can examine.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has determined under its guidelines, and perhaps with advice from committees it has set up, that with declining enrolments at government schools, particularly in the Parramatta area, it is not appropriate to allow this particular non-government school to expand at this time. All that the critics have said about the Labor Party and its attitude to non-government schools is now being proved to be correct. This decision is nothing more than an attack on the basic rights of all Australian parents to choose where they want their children to go and the schools they should attend. The Labor Government has consistently refused to recognise the legitimacy of a dual system of education. We now have the evidence in relation to Our Lady of Lebanon School as to the way in which the Labor Party is responding in this situation. The school is in Parramatta, the electorate of the Minister for Sport, Tourism and Recreation (Mr John Brown), and I would like to think that he will take an interest in the plight of this school, and certainly in the desire of parents to have their children enrolled in this very special and unique school.

We have here evidence that the Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, who failed in her attempts to cut off funding generally to non-government schools when she got rolled by her more pragmatic colleagues, is now trying this back door method to put the lid on the funding of new non-government schools.
