The Labor Party is still trying to meet its debt to the teacher unions, which have consistently feared competition and have resented the fact that parents have been voting with their feet. With the collusion between this Government and the unions, we have seen the consequences of the barriers that are being erected to new non-government schools. This denies parents the right to educate their children according to their religious beliefs. In the case of the Lebanese people in the western suburbs of Sydney, we must consider their desire to see their children educated in a unique multicultural environment which preserves the language of their own nation. This will bring considerable benefit to Australia over a long period of time.

The government school system will ultimately survive, not because of the protective barriers erected by this Labor Government but because parents have confidence in the quality of education it offers. They should be prepared to meet the competition. If the Labor Government fails to recognise this, it does a grave injustice to the government school system as well. I wish to put the matter in that context. Our Lady of Lebanon School is unique. It is a Maronite Catholic school offering a special sort of education to its students. It meets the needs of the multicultural objectives which this Government says are important. Because of the extent to which enrolments have been falling in government schools, in which parents, particularly Lebanese parents, do not wish to see their children enrolled, we see the Government responding in this discriminatory way.

I have mentioned already the emphasis on language teaching at Our Lady of Lebanon School. I also want to mention the fact that the school has been approved by the New South Wales Government authorities and would be eligible to take students notwithstanding the fact that the Federal Government has refused recurrent funding for it under the schools program for next year. I want to make a plea to the Minister for Education to reconsider the situation in relation to Our Lady of Lebanon School at Harris Park. I want to make a plea on behalf of the parents; I want to make a plea on behalf of the sisters, whom I know well; I want to make a plea on behalf of those who believe that there ought to be choice in education and who believe that this special school is deserving of the support and encouragement of every member of this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to support a proposed declaration of scientific responsibility in relation to nuclear weaponry for submission to the United Nations. The declaration has been drafted by Professor Weeramantry, the Professor of Law at Monash University. Because of the text and the time limitations in this debate, the best I can do is read into Hansard the text of the draft submission.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —If honourable members opposite listen they might learn about peace. The document states:

SPEECH.PARA: Recognising that in age dominated by science and technology, it is essential that science and technology should be devoted to the service of mankind.
Gravely concerned that the development and production of nuclear weapons and the nuclear arms race are endangering the future of mankind and indeed of life on this planet.

Conscious that the most recent and meticulous scientific inquiries have established the probability of a nuclear winter with disastrous consequences to mankind and our planet in the event of a nuclear confrontation.
Realising that the nuclear arms race would be impossible to sustain without the active cooperation of scientists and technologists.
Taking account of the fact that the general principles of international law as contained in
(a) International custom
(b) The general principles of law recognised by civilised nations
(c) Judicial decisions and the teachings of jurists
(d) Inernational covenants.

place beyond doubt the illegality of the use of nuclear weaponry having regard to its violation of the principles of proportionality, discrimination, aggravation of pain and suffering, nullification of a return to peace and non-destruction of neutral states.
Aware that the use of nuclear weaponry would undoubtedly result in ecocide, genocide and, if there are any survivors, in massive intergenerational damage
Convinced that the concept of a limited nuclear war is unrealistic and a nuclear war once started is totally unlikely to be contained

Persuaded that the concepts of self-defence and deterrence have become meaningless in the context of nuclear weaponry and thus afford no justification for their production, possession, testing or deployment
Mindful that the use, production, testing, possession and deployment of nuclear weapons thus constitute a violation of international law and a crime against humanity

Recalling that this Assembly by Resolution 3384 (XXX) of 10 November 1975 proclaiming the Declaration on the Use of Scientific and Technological Progress in the Interest of Peace and for the Benefit of Mankind and has since taken numerous steps towards the implementation of this resolution, including the passing of Resolution 37/189A of 18 December 1982 calling upon all states, specialized agencies, intergovernmental and non-governmental organisations to take the necessary measures to ensure that the results of scientific and technological progress are used exclusively in the interests of international peace, for the benefit of mankind and for promoting and encouraging respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms

Noting that the Human Rights Committee of the United Nations at its 563rd meeting (twenty-third session) held on 2 November 1984 in its general comment 14 (23) c/ (article 6) declared that the production, testing, possession, deployment and use of nuclear weapons should be prohibited and recognised as a crime against humanity

Noting also that the said Committee in the said general comment called upon all States, whether Parties to the Covenant or not, to take urgent steps unilaterally and by agreement to rid the world of this menace

Persuaded that the legal and moral responsibility borne by scientists participating in such activities is today infinitely greater than at the time of the creation of the first nuclear weapons by reason inter alia of the greater knowledge now available of the disastrous atmospheric, agricultural, medical and social impacts of the use of nuclear weaponry, the possibility of nuclear retaliation, the enormously enhanced destructive power of current nuclear weaponry and the vast nuclear arsenals now available in the event of nuclar war
Deeply moved by the consideration that the power of science is such, in the words of the Russell-Einstein Manifesto, as to open the way to a new paradise or lead to the risk of universal death
Believing that the participation of scientists and technologists is crucial to the determination of the choice between these alternatives
Convinced that the principle of individual responsibility for crimes against humanity is well established in international law
Convinced also that superior orders do not constitute a defence in international law in regard to crimes against humanity

and Determined that in the light of the above circumstances a consideration of the responsibility of scientists and technologists engaged in the nuclear weapons enterprise should no longer be further delayed by the international community.

The proposed declaration continues but time prohibits me from putting the active part of it. However, the declaration calls on all scientists and technologists to cease involvement in the production of nuclear weaponry and to seek peace throughout the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the honourable member for Fisher.
—He is an excellent member.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Gippsland for his comment. Many honourable members may recall receiving recently a booklet entitled `Service and Business Outlook for 1985/86' distributed by Telecom Australia. What a self-serving publication it is. In it there is a glowing reference to Telecom's first 10 years of operation. The Chairman, R. W. Brack, goes so far as to say that this organisation is `proud of the substantial achievements that have been made during this time with the help of new technologies and continuing productivity improvements by management and staff'. It is a pity, however, that the Chairman could not visit my electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: Residents of Caboolture and nearby areas cannot get a telephone installed at any price until lines finally become available late this month or early November. There are many people in this district who have been waiting many months for telephones. Telecom had the ability to make these lines available. The fact that it chose not to do so is a disgusting example of the inefficiencies associated with a government monopoly. Bell Canada would not have subjected its customers to similar treatment-it would not have been tolerated in Canada.

I would like to provide to the House an example of the problems that have arisen. Some installations at last have been finalised after numerous delays, while others are still waiting. On 27 February this year a business applied for a connection of three lines and a commander system in new office facilities at Morayfield. On 27 March the system was installed minus two of the lines requested and the business was advised that the lines would be provided prior to the end of March. As a result of this advice the organisation employed staff and set up its office at considerable cost. In April, Telecom suddenly changed its tune, advising that lines would not become available for some three to four months.

Such a situation should not have happened and a number of problems need to be addressed. Why did Telecom sell a system that could not be used immediately? Why was the business told that there would be no problem associated with the allocation of lines? Why should installation and rental be payable on a useless service? Why has Telecom not acted upon the need for a rapid development of facilities in growth areas? In this instance, lost business was estimated by the company to be approximately $100,000. Will compensation be paid by Telecom? I very much doubt it. Such a situation should not have been tolerated. Caboolture is not a remarkably isolated area, being on the northern highway less than 30 miles north of Brisbane.

By August this year my office had been inundated with inquiries from constituents seeking the immediate connection of phones. At one stage the number of inquiries reached such a point that two days a week in my office were designated for contacting the regional Telecom office in order to forward individual complaints. The reply from Telecom was courteous but to the point. It was claimed that financial restrictions prevented the updating of facilities until the introduction of improvements to Caboolture exchange early in 1986. Understandably, many constituents were not too pleased with this reply.

During August, my office was contacted by a Brisbane current affairs program with a view to finding out the true extent of the problem. A number of constituents indicated they were quite prepared to appear on the show. Within a week of hearing of the proposed program, Telecom had suddenly found the ability to bring forward the development of lines in the area. Honourable members will understand that late October is a far cry from early 1986. What I would like to know is the decision-making process that allowed such a rescheduling of priorities. In an article in the local media on 22 September the district Telecom manager said the exchange had been exhausted five months earlier than predicted due to a combination of numerous sub-divisions and equipment delays. During this time the area recorded an increase of 17 per cent in the call for new lines. Surely such a progressive increase would not go unnoticed. Forward planning should have been implemented. The district Telecom manager in the same article said further that he felt it would now be intolerable for people and businesses to have to wait up to five months. Unfortunately, Telecom has already had its effect upon the Caboolture area. People preparing to set up business ventures have moved elsewhere, real estate development has been hampered, and the economic growth of the area has been harmed accordingly.

Telecom must make itself efficient. It must give the service that the people of Australia require. I do not wish this speech to be interpreted as an attack on Telecom staff, as I personally have found them courteous and helpful. But Telecom must shape up or ship out. the people of Fisher and Australia demand it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —on 24 September I challenged the Leader of the National Party, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), to produce documentary evidence to prove that he rejected the Bathurst-Orange area as a possible site for an Army base while he was Minister for Defence. I maintained that claims by the Leader of the National Party that, while Minister for Defence, he rejected proposals for the siting of the Army base in the Bathurst-Orange area or any of the other proposed sites lacked substance in the light of documents I have obtained under the Freedom of Information Act. In all of the documents obtained under the Act, not once did he state his rejection of the Army's proposals. He was well aware that Bathurst-Orange was one of the most favoured sites of the Army, yet he did not ask the Defence Department to reappraise its proposals in any way. The Leader of the National Party visited the Orange area-
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I wonder whether the honourable member has had the courtesy to give the right honourable member notice of his intention this evening.
—Yes, I have.
—Order! That is not a point of order. That is a matter of practice.
—How could you? He is not here.
—That is his fault. I rang his office at a quarter to nine.
—Order! I call the honourable member for Calare.

—The Leader of the National Party visited the Orange area on 22 September in an attempt to make cheap political points. In the light of his visit to the region and the statements he made while there, it is even more interesting that not once did he ask for a study to be made of the possibility of Crown land being used for a base and not once did he question the productivity of the land in the proposed regions. The right honourable member for New England may rant, rave and make attacks on me, but he cannot deny what is contained in official ministerial papers. He has made numerous protestations of his innocence. However, these lack any credibility, considering the information contained in the documents. In Parliament on 6 June 1984 the Leader of the National Party said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have acknowledged that I was aware of the sites. I have confirmed today that I believed them all suitable for a school area.
He went on to say:
Any one of the areas would be suitable for an infantry or artillery school.

The Leader of the National Party knew about the Army's proposals from the early days of planning, yet he failed to voice any disapproval while he was the Minister responsible for defence; nor did he alert any of the people likely to be affected by the Army's plans. I contend that his whole behaviour, in the light of his recent stance on the Army base, is highly questionable. It is most unfortunate that while he was in a position to influence the planning for the base he failed to do so. Yet, more than two years later, he is seeking credit for leading a fight against the proposed base.

It is the clearly accepted practice for Ministers to have all their directives and policy decisions in print; so it is surprising that the Leader of the National Party, the right honourable member for New England, should claim that he rejected the Army proposals. In the complete set of documents relating to the Army base issue while he was Minister for Defence, not once did he question the Army's proposals. I have all the documents with me. His comments on 22 September while he was in Orange are full of political rhetoric. When it comes to the facts, he has no defence. His protestations of innocence hold absolutely no water. What upsets me is that this matter is too important for him to use as an issue to boost his flagging support. The emergence of the Rural Australia Party, the growing appeal of the National Farmers Federation and the drop in support for the National Party of Australia are obviously worrying him. His appearance in the region can be construed only as being politically motivated and not as a genuine concern for the people in the proposed area.

Following the visit to my electorate by the Leader of the National Party, I challenged him to back up his claims by producing documents which proved that he did direct the Defence Department to study other alternative areas and that he objected to the Bathurst-Orange area being considered and ordered it off the list of proposed sites. If he can produce documentary evidence to back up his pleas of innocence, I will be more than happy to withdraw my claims. Otherwise, he should acknowledge his role in the Defence Department's plans. When I received the documents under the Freedom of Information Act in April of this year, I was assured that they were the only ones the Leader of the National Party, while Minister for Defence, saw in relation to the Army training facilities project. I therefore call upon the Leader of the National Party to prove that he has not misled the people of the central west. He should either produce documents proving that he rejected the proposed Army training sites or apologise for his deliberate misleading of this House and the people of New South Wales.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) for giving me the courtesy of making me realise for the first time who is the honourable member for Calare in this place. It is important that the people of the electorate which he currently and temporarily represents understand that his mark is very slight and, consequently, his impact is insignificant within the Federal Parliament. It is also important that we comprehend that his actions with respect to the Orange-Bathurst land base have been totally contrary to the interests of several causes. The first is the interests of those who own land and are concerned about continuing to operate land and who have owned that land not just in their own names but for successive generations. Indeed, in my experience there are few areas of Australia where land has been so strongly and well held for so long by so many people. In the area there are a number of families who, through their forebears, have been there ever since the first settlement. The honourable gentleman has failed to represent them. Secondly, he has been quite prepared-
—What about these documents?

—I will come to that. The honourable member should just wait. Many people in the area have quite properly expressed concern that their continued operations are seriously prejudiced because the Government, which the honourable gentleman supports, has been prepared now to place an embargo on normal commercial transactions. There is a virtually total hiatus in investment, rural development and the normal circumstance of people conducting their business. The honourable gentleman, as their member, is really trying to ensure that this Government, of which he is a supporter, continues in its irresponsible way.

SPEECH.PARA: The third action for which the honourable member has been responsible is that, in terms of trying to encourage the transfer of the Army base to that area, he has seriously led business people in Bathurst and Orange to believe that there will be some genuine benefit to them. I say to them now, as I did when I was in Bathurst and Orange, that it is likely that the principal contracts will not go to people in the district. They are more likely to go to people in Sydney. It is more likely that the continued benefit will be not to people in his community but to people in the capital city. If the facility were to be established in his electorate, it is unlikely that there would be any continuing benefit, as most of the soldiers who would be there would be there on short term postings and would be returning to the city and would be spending their money there, not locally.

The honourable gentleman has made a number of allegations. He is very anxious for me to produce the evidence. Let me explain the circumstance. His Minister for Defence at the time, the present Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes), took action immediately after his election to ensure that there would be a processing of an investigation into three areas in New South Wales. He appointed consultants-Dames and Moore-who are still there inquiring into this site. I refused to accept that advice. The honourable gentleman, if he has-

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not.
—I did, I am afraid, my friend. There has been no action anywhere which shows my endorsement of that proposal. I rejected that proposal.
—You did not.

—I did. I am afraid that the honourable gentleman not only is prepared to mislead the people of his electorate but also, by asserting that something happened which did not happen, is trying hard to mislead this House. I did not process that claim. I did not accept the statement that was submitted by the Department of Defence, in order to get a joint statement from the Premier saying that we would go ahead with it, because I did not accept that it should proceed. I say to my friend that if it had proceeded I would have gone ahead and made sure that the statement was renounced. I did not do that. I did nothing with it.
—You did not say `No' either.

—No. I say to my friend that what happened was that there was no way I would accept the proposal. Nothing happened while we were in government, because I rejected the proposal. The falsity in the honourable gentleman's claim is that I would have processed the representations from the Department if I had accepted them. I did not accept them, and the reason nothing is in print is that I rejected them. It was not until Labor took office it was prepared to destroy private rights. Labor ignored the interests of landholders. I am as opposed to the Army land base going to Orange and Bathurst now as I was then. There is adequate Crown land in New South Wales which should be investigated before private land is acquired anywhere in that State. There is reason for the Cobar area also to be considered in relation to an area outside New South Wales. There is no basis in the honourable gentleman's claim.
—Order! The right honourable gentleman's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not the first time that I have risen in this House to express my concern about events in Sri Lanka. I first expressed my alarm in the wake of mob violence against the Tamils in 1983 when thousands of innocent people, whose only crime was that they were Tamils, suffered death or injury and their property was burned and looted in a government that orchestrated and condoned riot. I felt then, as I feel now, that it is my duty to speak out against racist violence wherever it occurs. I wonder what happened to that tranquil island once called Ceylon so well known to tourists because of its image of peacefulness.

SPEECH.PARA: My wife and I spent a day in Colombo in early 1954 when we, as migrants, were heading to settle in Australia. Since then I have learned a lot about the history of that beautiful island and the oppression of the Tamil minority there since 1956 when the Sinhala language was introduced as the only official language. It negated a place for the Tamil language in the country. However, the world at large knew little about the discrimination against the Tamil minority in Sri Lanka until the large scale racial violence in 1983. The world knew very little about the fate of more than a million Tamils who were disenfranchised and made stateless even though they had worked and lived in Sri Lanka for generations.

The human rights situation in Sri Lanka today is as bad as, if not worse than, it is in South Africa. The only difference between South Africa and Sri Lanka is that in South Africa a small minority is oppressing the large majority of the population while in Sri Lanka it is the majority that is oppressing a large minority, since the Tamils represent about 18 per cent of the population. Both regimes-South African apartheid and the regime of President Jayawardene in Sri Lanka-are based on racial violence. Both regimes are depriving people of basic human rights and are using state terrorism to oppress their population. In this case of South Africa, our Government has undertaken actions in domestic and international forums to stop the racist policies of that state. Yet at the same time we have done very little to persuade the Sri Lankan Government to stop the racist violence against the Tamil minority.

The state organised terrorism against the innocent Tamil civilians never ceased after the 1983 racial riots. Detention without trial, arrests, torture and killings continue under the organisation of the Minister for National Security. His security troops, trained by Israeli experts, are committing atrocities daily against the Tamil population. I have a score of cables reporting those atrocities. Yet our Government continues to supply aid to Sri Lanka, including military aid. I hate to think that Australian bullets may be used by perpetrators of racial violence against the innocent Tamil population. Of course the continued oppression and racist violence by the authorities forced the Tamil youths to organise in self-defence to resist the terror. Notwithstanding that, our Government can no longer say that the problems in Sri Lanka are internal matters. When state organised and state condoned racial killings take place there is an obligation on the international community to intervene and take action to stop it. Let me remind the House of our duty to intervene by stating:
First they came for the Jews
and I did not speak out-
because I was not a Jew.
Then they came for the communists
and I did not speak out-
because I was not a communist.
Then they came for the trade unionist.
and I did not speak out-
because I was not a trade unionist.
Then they came for me
and there was none left
to speak out for me.
I think that we as a government have a duty to speak out against the persecution of the Tamil minority in Sri Lanka.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is most interesting to listen from time to time to the way some Government members talk about privatisation. If one did not listen carefully one would think that they were talking about fiction. They are certainly not talking from a well-informed basis or a considered foundation. Instead, they wish to use only scare tactics in an attempt to deceive and frighten the Australian population, and in so doing they deny people the opportunity to participate more meaningfully in their jobs. I will explore some of the reasons why the concept of privatisation-even though it is a big word and one which we would probably prefer not to use-will gain acceptance throughout the Western communities of the world. The reason it will gain acceptance is the three or four factors which people notice are happening and have been happening for a long period.

SPEECH.PARA: The first measure is the growth of government. I will indicate a little about the growth of government from 1969 to 1985. In 1969 the number of persons in Australia in receipt of welfare per 100 private sector employees was 26 and in 1985 it is 66 people. We have to support that number of people. That is a big increase. People in the Australian community are concerned about it. In 1969 the number of government employees per 100 private sector employees was 25; now we have 34, an increase of 36 per cent. The number of persons in receipt of government incomes per 100 private sector employees in 1969 was 51 and in 1985, 100. The figure has doubled.

TALK.START.PARA: —That includes you.

—I realise that that figure includes me. People in Australia realising that this process cannot go on because ultimately the private sector, the people who are productive in this community, will not be able to afford it.

SPEECH.PARA: People see that the functions of the Public Service have changed. Instead of just having the traditional Public Service functions, for example, policy advice and implementation, tax collection, the armed forces and law enforcement, which take up 30 per cent of the people who are employed by the government, we now find the government is now into trading activities such as Trans Australia Airlines, Qantas Airways Ltd and other major operations. That is where 70 per cent of government employees are now operating. In other words, government is performing functions for this nation which could well be handled by people in the private sector.

Over the years people have heard governments say: `Let us cut back the size of government'. Governments have used various tactics such as efficiency drives, elimination of waste, elimination of unnecessary programs and limits on expenditure by government departments. However, these measures have not worked. People in the Western world know that a different tack must be used. This is why the people of Australia will take up the concept of privatisation. As they do I believe we will find a much healthier economy. Privatisation is about increasing personal independence and freedom. It will give workers and unionists a greater opportunity of creating wealth for their families. It will enable more people to have the opportunity to be owners; it will encourage competition; it will reduce the powers of monopolies; it will help break the present arbitrary divisions between owners and earners; and it will hold taxes to a minimum. The reason the Government is concerned about privatisation and the capacity-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, we still have a long way to go before it can be said that we have reached that goal of adequate support for those in genuine need. Although the 1985-86 Budget has accelerated the process, an issue which is reflective of the fact that many people in Australia today are living below Henderson's poverty line, is that of the crisis in emergency relief. The general view of the State Ministers for Community Services and councils of social service is that emergency relief no longer constitutes emergency payments to meet crisis situations but has become a form of income supplementation for social security recipients, who make up 90 per cent of those applying for emergency relief. Emergency relief as an income supplement has been criticised by State governments because of the added demands on their social welfare expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: The councils of social service are critical of the continued funding of emergency relief as they believe that, firstly, it is stigmatising and can be described as institutionalised begging; secondly, it does not address the real issue of social security pensions and benefits being significantly below the Henderson poverty line; and, thirdly, it draws agencies away from their stated aims into delivering emergency relief.

The Standing Committee of Social Welfare Administrations, representing the State governments, recently resolved that the State and Territory administrations should cease providing emergency relief payments used as income supplementation from 1 January 1986. The New South Wales Government has already withdrawn, that withdrawal having taken effect on the 1 October 1985.

The indications are that other State and Territory governments are reviewing their emergency relief delivery policies to produce more restrictive guidelines to reduce expenditure. The Northern Territory Government is introducing new guidelines from February 1986 and the Queensland Government is making arrangements for emergency relief to be taken over by the St Vincent de Paul Society and the Salvation Army. In Western Australia new guidelines, which are retrospective, are being introduced and non-government sector is being asked to take up the slack in this area.

I turn to the Commonwealth role. Until the financial year 1979-80, the Commonwealth Government played no role in providing funds for emergency relief. In that year the Commonwealth made an initial contribution to the funds of non-government agencies of $0.5m. On its return to office in 1983 the Government doubled the then Commonwealth contribution to $5m. This contribution increased to $6m in 1985-86. Notwithstanding this increase in funding by the Commonwealth to non-government agencies, the latter have been placed faced with ever increasing demands for emergency relief. The Victorian emergency relief project, which represents some 350 agencies giving emergency relief in that State, indicates that the average value of assistance has fallen significantly in recent years. The agencies state:
Despite a tenfold increase in Federal Emergency Relief grants between 1981-1984 the average value of assistance given to a family in Victoria has fallen significantly.

There is a need, therefore, for some urgent measures to be taken. I feel that this is something which should be done by the Commonwealth, by State governments and by the non-government sectors. I should like to see established a working party to look at the issue of emergency relief in relation to levels of social security pensions and benefits and in relation to concessions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I read with interest today, I think in the Melbourne Age, that Senator Gareth Evans had been reported as saying-I shall not be unkind to him-that Australia had the second lowest price for petrol in the countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. Senator Evans said that it was an average of 51c a litre. I thought to myself that the price of petrol in Tasmania is 60c a litre. This comparison is always made and it is said that Australia has the second lowest price. It seems to substantiate the argument that we are the second lowest in price, and it sounds great. But everyone seems to forget that Australia is a very large country. When compared with prices in other countries, our prices do not add up because we are 70 per cent self-sufficient. So the argument does not mean anything. The point is very significant. The average price of petrol in Australia is 51c a litre, yet the Tasmanian people are paying 60c a litre. I know that others in Australia are paying even more than that. So the whole matter is very clearly highlighted.

SPEECH.PARA: Another thing that is most annoying relates to liquid petroleum gas. Motor vehicles can be and are driven economically and efficiently on LPG. In Victoria it is about 17c to 19c per litre, yet in Tasmania it is 33c a litre.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?
—It is 33c a litre; nearly twice the price charged elsewhere.
—The petrol companies are ripping them off.

—There is a monopoly in Tasmania by Boral. I shall write to Boral. I shall give Boral a chance, first; but I have a very good tongue in this House and I shall say exactly what I think: `You have the monopoly in Tasmania. LPG is 33c a litre-about 17c a litre more. You cannot add that up in freight charges, so something is wrong'. I think of the many people who have turned to the alternative of LPG-taxi drivers and suppliers. When the price of petrol to farmers and everyone else in Australia is increased that increase flows right through the economy. Therefore, the people of Tasmania are being disadvantaged.

SPEECH.PARA: I touch on another subject very briefly. I have been involved as the patron of the Tasmanian Parents Without Partners for a long time. Many people knock Parents Without Partners without realising that it is doing a very good job behind the scenes. Young children who are reared by single parents have a cross to bear. We should give them as much support as is humanly possible. I know that most of us do so. People with a little charity and common sense would say: `Things have changed. There are a lot of marriage break-ups today. Many people die and many children are left to be reared by single parents, and if they are given love by one good parent at least they will have a chance in this complicated world'. Therefore I urge everyone who hears people running down these unfortunate parents without partners because they meet and try to make a better life for themselves and their children, to defend them. There are many knockers in the world. Many people talk about girls who have young children to rear on their own. I have even heard anti-abortionists-just like myself-saying: `You should not give the benefit to the single woman'. These arguments do not add up.

One must be very sincere and not hypocritical, because one will be found out. It is useless for someone to plead with me on the one side saying `Fight against abortion, Bruce' yet on the other hand saying: `You should not give the benefit to that poor single girl'. What would such people rather have? Would they rather have the child aborted than have the child given the chance to be reared in a decent, respectable way?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I should like to draw to your attention the unsatisfactory situation that we have had this year with Hansard. I know that you are aware of it. I find it very difficult to work in this place when Hansard is consistently delivered one day or two days late. It makes it extremely difficult for back benchers to answer effectively arguments or criticisms that have been directed against them. It must be extremely difficult for Ministers to deal with matters about which they have been criticised. You have made a couple of explanations, Mr Speaker. I cannot stress my concern too strongly, and I wish you to take action about this matter.

—I shall answer the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) in the 15 seconds that I have. There is no action that can be taken by the Parlimentary Department. Every necessary act is carried out by the Parliamentary Reporting Staff. The difficulty is with the Government Printing Office, which is not under my control.
—Thank you, Mr Speaker.
—Order! It being 11 p.m. the debate is interrupted.
